video_description: #stitch with @MK🤍 | Romance Author #iykyk #booktok #author Best Friends — First Dance — First Love — Dreams — Choices — Second Chance? Rachel and Jordan were supposed to chase their dreams together, but things don't always go according to plan. They made promises to each other, but when their paths diverged, those promises were put to the test. Now, years later, they find themselves back in their hometown and must decide if they want to revisit the past or continue on with their separate lives. But when the heart gets involved, nothing is ever simple. Rachel: I always thought I knew who I was, but now I'm not so sure. I fell in love with my best friend and ended up with a broken heart. Can I trust myself to follow my heart again, or should I stick to the safe and comfortable version of myself? Jordan: Country music was my first love, but Rachel was my best friend. I never wanted to risk losing her, but now I realize that staying true to my heart might just be the biggest risk of all. Will we find our way back to each other, or is our story already written? If you enjoyed Nicholas Sparks' "The Notebook," you'll love this heartwarming tale of love, friendship, and second chances. Don't miss out on this emotional rollercoaster! Available on Amazon, Kindle, Kindle Unlimited, and jcarrwrites.com #romance #cleanromance #cleanfiction #booktok #author #indieauthor

#stitch with @shakiah tips on how to power through when writing a book is HARD #booktok #writerstok #writingtok #amwriting #booktokfypage
voice_to_text: question for writers on days you don't feel like writing do you force yourself to write yes I do I think writing's a job like any other whether you are writing full time or squeezing it in around a day job and I find that if I push through then I get my flow back again I've had loads of jobs where I haven't always loved it I've been a waitress and not felt like dealing with people that day there were definitely days when I was a police officer where I didn't want to go to work and the same applies to me now that I'm a full time right so when that happens to me here are few things I tried that help me No.1 I sometimes jump ahead to a bit in the story that I'm really excited about No. 2 I will take a step back from writing and instead spend some time doing some character development working on my setting or doing some research No. 3 I've quite often got more than one project on the go so I'll put one to one side and I'll work on something else No.4 I find that going back and reading over what I've written on previous writing sessions especially ones where it really flowed will help me capture my voice again and get me excited about the project and finally No. 5 go easy on yourself you don't have to write for hours and hours you don't have to hit the word limit that perhaps you're able to hit on a good day even if you just write for 20 minutes even if you just get down a couple of hundred words you'll feel so much better for having done it and the next time Writer's Block hits you you'll know that you've got the strength to bash through it

#stitch with @Thom We love Thom! PSA for my US practitioners. An old friend of mine once tried to make a flying ointment from American Mayapple and it was not a pleasant experience for them. No shop should be labeling or selling this product as "Mandrake" and I've even seen some label the plant with the scientific name for true mandrake - a frankly dangerous and seriously underhanded practice. These plants don't even have similar root structures, hence the reason the "mandrake" you get from most herbal shops and occult stores is small and twiggy. These plants are both poisonous, but their poisons affect the body very differently, with true mandrake being used for centuries as a deliriant and inxoticant, as well as a highly valued medicinal plant. My #PSA for you, if you find a shop labeling this plant as mandrake, especially if they are using the scientific name "Mandragora officiarnum," they need to be reported for purposefully mislabeled their products and potentially harming consumers. This is a very unfortunate yet common practice amongst occult and herbal stores, with many knowing full-well what they are doing. . #witch #witchcraft #witchtok #witchtalk #vvitch #vvitchcraft #witches #vvitches #vvitchtok #witchery #traditionalwitchcraft #wicca #vvitchery#witchbook #witchbooks #bibliophile #witchy #vvitchy #books #booktok #magic #magick #spell #spells #ritual #rituals #rite #rites #spirit #spiritual #spiritualtok #spirits #animism #animist #folkwitch #folkvvitch #tradcraft #divination #diviner #mandrake #mandragora #root #roots #knowledge #caution

#stitch with @MK🤍 | Romance Author  Learn more about Commander Rell and others in Law of Aurornova - 7.25 Law Everstorm has reached the end of his primary studies and like most nineteen-year-olds should be focusing on choosing a role within his colony, Fort Kelly. However, following the news of his father, Maxwell's mysterious disappearance his plans for the future a upended when his godfather Tiberius summons Law and his twin sister, Jamie, to the mysterious Zoa Region to retrieve an encrypted lockbox left by their father.  Determined to find answers, Law, Jamie, and his best friend, Charlie embark on a journey to the other side of their planet, Aurornova in hopes of learning the truth about their father and his work. Rather than finding closure, Law and his companions are plunged into the middle of a conflict far beyond the confines of their world. Together they uncover secrets that may not only be the answer to their father's disappearance, but could also be the key to turning the tides in an ongoing war no one knew existed.  Does Law have what it takes to stand between two powerful forces threatening the fate of his world? #lawofaurornova #cyharold #scifibooks #speculativefiction #booktok

voice_to_text: what do I pack?  as a rule for all book festivals you should wear something with pockets and the reason for that is never know whether the microphone situation is going to be they give you a microphone to hold or they give you a microphone that is hooked onto you somewhere and they need to put a mic pack on you and this is another Hay (book festival) story for me I told one yesterday uh about a time that I didn't have a dress with pockets on my second year at Hay Book Festival Lucy Worsley the historian of whom I'm big fan was also speaking however just because of the way that timings worked out I wasn't going to be able to see her I was on stage directly before her she was getting on stage after so when I was signing she was gonna be on stage and then my train was at the point that she would be signing so I wasn't gonna be able to get her to sign my book I love Lucy Worlsey she's a fabulous historian I am a historian so nerd I've watched all of her shows um and so I wanted to meet her but I probably thought I wasn't gonna get the chance on stage I was wearing a dress that did not have pockets and as such for the Mike pack what the sound guy ended up having to do is unzip my dress hook it to the back of my bra and that is how I got on stage zip my dress back up over it cut to I'm done on stage I'm getting off and then Lucy Worsley is getting on after me and is standing there in the wings and I knew I wasn't gonna get to say hi properly or see her talk so I just decided to stop and talk to her even though I was supposed to be at signing like I'm gonna just take 5 seconds and tell her I think she's awesome so I'm doing this and I'm like oh my gosh I've watched all your shows I love you she was being very sweet as I'm talking to her because they are such a tight turn over at Hay the sound guy just comes up to me and unzips my dress and starts taking my mic pack off because I am engaged talking to Lucy Worsley and literally  as I'm talking to famous television historian Lucy Worsley a guy was just like unzipping me and taking my mic pack off I don't know what she thought would was happening but she pretended nothing was happening like these things go down um so yeah uh that is my reason why you should always wear pockets to book festivals

voice_to_text: what do we actually know about Shakespeare he was a businessman a producer and an actor why is it always so surprising that a man from humble origins can write I appreciate the gish gallop here from Picoult in the sense that she's creating a bunch of pretty weak arguments individually but in aggregate they sound a little more convincing for instance there's no record that he didn't collaborate with others musicians his fellow castmates it's just that his name appeared on a lot of title pages of plays because he was given credit for them and Shakespeare was famous in his day not superstar famous but he printed a lot of books a lot of people had read his poems and we don't know if he didn't own any books during his lifetime there was no books in his will so it's possible that he just gave them away before he died or just didn't include them in his will or he used the library or had access to a friend's library and to say that Shakespeare couldn't have written about Egypt because it wasn't in travel books of the time and he didn't go there it's kind of silly I mean plenty of people went to Egypt there were plenty of books that talked about Egypt and travelogues  he definitely could have read about it or talk to people that travel to Egypt in order to write his plays or just made a lot of stuff up I mean all of this is kind of silly plenty of people from humble origins can read or write and be creative and she's going to monetarily benefit from this conspiracy theory because she's promoting a fiction book that will soon be in mass market paperback she's not a scholar she's not a professor she's not a researcher she's an ad and you shouldn't listen to a walking ad just because it proposes that a woman was behind it all there are plenty of amazing incredible women writers out there contemporary and of of Shakespeare's time so just read some of those
video_description: #stitch with @Jodi Picoult  It seems like every few years someone with a new book claims that Shakespeare didn’t write his plays because (some noble aristocrat) did instead.  It seems that a frustration with the relatively limited personal details of Shakespeare’s life in contrast to the impact of his plays leads to this kind of speculation.  It genuinely feels classist with a pseudo-feminist twist to claim this other rich lady wrote the plays instead of Shakespeare.  There are plenty of women writers out there. We know women are more than capable of writing just as well as men can. A different set of social moraes of the time would certainly have allowed a woman writer to reach prominence in the way men were. Yet even with the oppression that women faced there are many incredibly women writers to celebrate instead of a false one.  #jodipicoult #byanyothername #booktok #shakespeare

voice_to_text: I don't even know why Penelope likes Colin besides the fact that the plot said that she's supposed to back in season you have to remember a couple of things about pen and Colin they have had years of building friendship during a time when Penelope was not even perceived by the time this is such a relatable romance to so many one women who have been cast aside for one reason or another or who haven't been given the time of day by society for so many reasons and a lot of us feel that way or have felt that way at some point in our lives and so you have this handsome charming nice guy of previous seasons Colin who becomes really good friends with Penn and there is a trust that grows between them and it's an unspoken trust it's not just by what they say to each other it's just by the fact of sticking together and being present with each other the very fact that Colin perceives pen in a positive light and sees her sees her true self and doesn't just make her a fantasy or cast her side because she doesn't fit beauty ideals of the time whatever the fact that he actually sees her and and embraces who she is is the hottest thing a man can do for a woman who has been through those situations in her life this isn't just like friends to lovers this is like friends to saviours to lovers and in a sense they are saving each other but Penn only clicks into that saviour model for him once she is desired by more people namely one more person so it's a it's a complex thing and I've been where Penn is and I think a lot of women have where we have this friend or a friendship or a really close connection with a man and then he becomes like the toast of the town or he changes and so now he thinks more highly of himself and so there's a tinge of like loathing there there's a tinge of resentment where it's like oh so now you think you're the shit and now you're becoming one of them so I actually don't think this season is friends to lovers I think it's like friends to enemies to lovers and if they switch roles constantly and I think it is one of the most authentic and real world and relatable connections of any of the previous seasons which is what I love about this season the most like that carriage scene he they have consent like express consent shown in that carriage scene they have true friendship shown like after everything goes down and the carriage stops they laugh together just like they were friends like they've always been friends so they click back into this kind of like best friend connection together and ugh I love it and it's so obvious to me why she likes him it's so obvious to me it is it was not obvious to me how he couldn't see it with her although that's a totally different conversation

voice_to_text: this is so important for combating imposter syndrome amongst writers and not just when you're thinking about your style versus the authors that you love but also the readers that are gonna connect with your work her video is amazing I've already reposted it go back watch it like it give it all the love that it deserves but she's talking about the fact that we obviously compare ourselves and our work to the authors that we grew up with the authors that we read now that we love and you know we read their work oh my gosh their descriptions their characters everything is so beautiful and you look at your work and you're like oh this is how is this ever gonna be that good um an imposter syndrome is heavy on that front um the other key of course is the fact that theirs has already been published it's sold well it found its way to you and you love it so obviously it's kind of got that bias going towards it where's yours hasn't yet um but an important thing to keep in mind is that your work can be just as beautiful in sometimes a very different way than theirs and their work speaks to you in the similar fashion there is someone out there who is going to stumble across your words one day and it's going to speak to them in a way that some of these other even the big huge names their work while enjoyable and entertaining might not have quite sunk in and spoken to them in the way that yours will because your lived experience the things that you wanna talk about the themes you want to explore the ideas you wish to convey there's someone out there who for them it's the perfect mixture and they're going to love your book just in the same way as you love all of these authors that you're reading

voice_to_text: So Cami is looking for more influencers for books and beaches. I'm gonna be there. Um, Deanna's gonna be there already. Baker's gonna be there, Teresa Sharon's gonna be there. Britt Stark is gonna be there. There's a slew of other amazing indie authors that are going to be there. Um, so since she's looking for more influencers, I was wondering if anybody would be interested in spending a weekend at the beach with us? So if you're an influencer, if you have a little account or big account, we don't care. We don't care how many numbers there are. We care if you love books. We care if you love supporting indie authors. So if you Wanna join me and all these other amazing people at books and beaches, reach out to me. I'm going to also tag, um, Kimmy's account and books and beaches, of course. Reach out to either one of those and come hang out with us for a weekend. There's gonna be a bonfire, there's a book convention, there's a slew of other things that are going on. Um, and I just want someone, like, I genuinely wanna meet some of you guys in person. So if you're interested in being an influencer for books and beaches, let me know. Comment on this post, get my inbox. Whatever you gotta do, whatever you wanna do, do it that way. I have reached out to a couple of you guys personally to see if you guys Are interested? Um, yeah. I just think it's gonna be a really good time, so if you're interested, let me know.

voice_to_text: it is absolutely culty I totally agree with you and when I was in prison the cult madness spread to the federal prison yeah story time guys this was crazy so in 2,017 Trump had just become president there were rumors going all around the prison that Trump was gonna close the camps and we were all gonna go home when in fact the guy Trump put in charge for um drugs and substances he had just changed what Obama had done where Obama was letting non violent first time drug offenders you know get two points off you know in their point system this guy Trump's guy turned it around so that drug dealers were getting the max we were having bus loads of first time drug offenders you know 10 years mandatory minimums they were showing up in bus loads but these women who had years to go you know they wanted to hold on to that little bit of hope that Trump's gonna close the camps they would have prayer circles every night praying for this man even though it was right in front of their face you know that people were getting sentenced way more harshly the cops made this worse and they would throw few on the fire and you know say things to make inmates believe it even more and they thought it was funny this nonsense finally hit the fan and a woman who had only been there a couple months at the beginning of a five year bid who was absolutely desperate to go home her husband basically told her if she doesn't get her appeal to go through within a year he was gonna leave her she was not emotionally okay she convinced herself that the camps were closing on a particular date she called her family told them to get her a plane ticket she packed her bags and the staff knew this they had been monitoring this entire situation and they allowed it to get to this point she tries to leave and they stop her at the door and haul her off to the show they have a town hall meeting where everybody gets together and they have an announcement and they told us Trump is not closing the camps if you try to leave before your release date before you are allowed to you will get another charge desperate people tend to join cults and there are so many desperate Americans right now like it's no wonder this this cult took hold you can read about all this craziness and more in my upcoming book no justice just us um the website is up the Linktree is in my bio

voice_to_text: so when I first saw this video um I screamed a little because I was at work um and I'm a nurse so hopefully I didn't scare my patients haha and the reason I screamed was because I have never seen anybody on book talk holding my book this is the first time first time so I was very excited as you could imagine and I'm just excited uh for someone else to be talking about my book on book talk and um reviewing it I'm excited for the good and for the bad if there's any of that um I'm just excited in general so thank you Cassie from the bottom of my heart and I can't wait to hear what you say about it

first of all wolfgangs thank you for that video that is an excellent question and a really heartwarming story to um aside from all the wonderful people i've met here on the book talk community and of course a select few friends whom I communicate with on a daily basis who help you know support me and keep my head above water when when i'm drowning you you know what i mean one friend of mine in particular uh we've known each other for twenty plus years we used to bowl together uh she's a huge music fan huge sports fan like i am and you know she was really ecstatic when she found out i was writing again and she read eddie the legend and she loved it and she went back and read being made and she loved that one too in fact my short story for the sinful signings anthology i dedicated to her she sent me this email a while back and it really struck a chord with me congratulations on all that you've accomplished and continue to accomplish i think i know i speak for everyone in the bowling hockey group when i say we're proud of you you know it's things like that that make it all worthwhile for me and of course you know getting to interact with you know people like samantha moran and evie black you know that they they mean so much to me and that they make it all worthwhile too and when i'm going through my my issues you know i have the demons like everybody else does the IS, the depression and things of that nature you know i think about a few of the younger authors out there you know that people whom i've befriended and who who have either written their first book recently or writing their first book you know because you never know who's looking at you and who's thinking you know what he's a really great guy and he's a great author i wanna do what he does i know that sounds a little presumptuous but seriously you never know who who really admires your work and i say to myself if i gave up what am i saying to those people who are just trying to make it work who are trying to follow their dreams i need to follow my dreams and i'm going to and it's people like my friends Sue here who emailed me and it's people like Sam and Evie and everybody else who is in my corner who make it all worthwhile for me so thank you very much all of you and and thank you wolfgangs for that wonderful video that's why i do what i do this is what i do

voice_to_text: Decide how the characters are pronounced in your incarnation of the book. You can even say, this character doesn't look. I absolutely love this, because there are characters that I can see exactly the way he writes and other people write. And then there's some characters that just doesn't work. I cannot for the life of me imagine breeze being portly. I know that he is. I know that that word is used several times when describing breeze. I can't picture it. For me, he is always a thinner, older dude. And, like, when I say older, he looks like he's 60 in my head. I know that he's only 40 in the book, but I imagine, like, an old grandpa who's very snarky but also very able to do things, like, very active. I don't know why. That's just what I imagine.

voice_to_text: Hey, you have to promote that thing that you're proud of or else no one will ever find it. We're here. This is the Worry Dragon. It's a picture book that demystifies anxiety for little ones. 100% of the profits go to the charity place to be, that supports mental health counselors for kids in the UK and schools. I couldn't find books that really supported the fact that being scared, being anxious is totally normal and actually it's our body trying to help us and tell us things. Um, this book is all about how to know your body and to trust yourself and to just really realise that everybody feels anxious, everybody has these big feelings. But it's not the end of the world. We are more than just our emotions. Everything goes to a good cause. So if you are interested in the worried dragon, please pick up up a copy from Amazon. If not, please go and support place to be there, a fantastic charity trying to do better for this generation. Coming up.

#stitch with @Gina Denny What is an English degree for? #college #academia #englismajor #gradschool #publishing #booktok #author #books #book #fyp
voice_to_text: I get the feeling from a lot of the questions I see surrounding what an English degree is that a lot of people don't really know what it's for and they take it to mean that it's for getting into publishing getting into being an author learning to write and those are all tangents of it let me explain the point of any Liberal arts degree whether it is English or history or any of those subjects is not necessarily to do that thing as a career in English you are learning to read critically you are learning to do some research on what you are reading critically you are learning how to structure arguments in essays and so what I mean by I think people have a misunderstanding is that these are degrees that help you to think they teach you ways to think and to ask questions and then you can go on and pursue future degrees based on that if you want or you are free to enter the workforce applying those skills I think one of the things that we have done irreparable damage to is the concept of a Liberal arts degree um you know for the last 40 years people have been saying get it going to stem get a stem degree get stem don't worry about the humanities and now we're wondering where did all these fascists come from but it's in the humanities that we learn to read argument to understand rhetoric to critically think to ask questions to find solutions that are not necessarily within the box and so if you are the kind of person who likes learning and likes going to school and you want to learn to write then you would probably pursue an MFA which is a Masters in Fine Art focused on creative writing that usually comes in the flavor of poetry or fiction however that is absolutely not required to be an author to get published um it's it's just not you there are many many very successful authors who have never gotten a terminal degree or sometimes even a college degree it's just not required but you will learn things in college that you're not going to learn necessarily unless you really seek it out things like history of literature and various styles various ways that we can analyze literature concepts like reader response theory and the lenses of feminism and Marxism um what have you the other great thing about getting a college degree in English is you're going to read a lot you're going to read a lot of books from a lot of different places using a lot of different theoretical lenses and just experiencing a lot of different writing without that you're not necessarily going to branch out that much unless you're a very driven person and want to but there is some value to doing this in a classroom setting and be involved in these discussions with other like minded people trying to understand and learn something and you know the right professor can really help you out with that now I I do wanna be clear I'm not saying this is the best path it is expensive it is exploitative in a lot of ways if you enter grad school your labor will very likely be exploited to teach classes but you're also going to learn a lot and a lot of what you learn is going to be how driven you are to continue pursuing it if it's not something you wanna pursue I cannot trust this enough don't do it if you wanna write the best advice is to get out there and write to sit down every day and write with intent or even if you can't write with intent just write anything just sitting down and writing that's what's going to be helpful but I think if we can kind of change the way that we think about an English degree a humanities degree to stop thinking about what what job can you get with an English degree and start thinking about what skill set are you building with an English degree because you're learning how to conduct research you're learning how to read critically you're learning how to problem solve you're learning how to read deeply into something see what makes it tick explain it find a solution for it if it needs one and that is #stitch with @Demetrius fields #greenscreen I have NOT read this yet I just wanted to share:: Lore, legend, and history tell us of the Vikings: warrior kings on epic journeys of conquest and plunder. But the stories we know are not the only stories to tell. There is another story, one that has been lost to the mists of time: the saga of the dark queen. This saga begins with Yafeu, a defiant yet fiercely compassionate young warrior who is stolen from her home in the flourishing Ghānaian empire and taken to a distant kingdom in the North. There she is thrust into a strange, cold world of savage shield maidens, tyrannical rulers, and mysterious gods. And there she also finds something unexpected: a kindred spirit. She comes to serve Freydis, a shy princess who couldn’t be more different from the confident and self-possessed Yafeu. But they both want the same thing: to forge their own fate. Yafeu inspires Freydis to dream of a future greater than the one that the king and queen have forced upon her. And with the princess at her side, Yafeu learns to navigate this new world and grows increasingly determined to become one of the legendary shield maidens—to fight not only for her freedom but for the freedom of others. #fyp #fypシ #book #booktok #booktokcommunity #willowsmith

voice_to_text: Claiming me, branding me. All right, we're gonna bring you, I moaned, then tilting my head back to give him better access. Just kidding. We're gonna raw dog this. His hands clamped on my waist, then moved, one going to cut my rear, the other sliding between us. This. This moment when it was him and me and nothing between our bodies. His tongue scraped the roof of my mouth as he dragged a finger down the center of me, and I gasped, my back arching. Fair, he said against my lips, my name like a prayer more devout than any Ian had offered up to the cauldron on that Dark Souls this morning. His tongue swept my mouth again, in time to the finger that he slipped inside of me. My hips undulated, demanding more, craving the fullness of him, and his growl reverberated in my chest as he added another finger. I moved on him, lightning lash through my veins, and my focus narrowed to his face.

What would have happened if the villain had won? This is a really interesting question, and for the sake of this discussion I am going to talk about my Baker Street Legacy series. I just finished writing the last one and this series will be complete in August. Thr villain in the series, which I have to be careful so thatI don't give away spoilers.  He is the hero in his own story, which is often the case of villains. H believes he has the right to revenge and the right for restitution. And he is highly intelligent, but he is also highly mentally unstable. Delusional in some aspects. And that drives his vengeance and his retribution. He had a plan and that's the first book is the launching of that plan, and he did a very good job b cause he's very intelligent, he did a very good job. However, he did too good; too good of a job. I can't give away anything. But if he had succeeded at any point in the process in the series, if he had succeeded to do what he wanted to do, he would have left a man absolutely decimated and changed forever. And probably, I would imagine, had it worked would have turned him — for lack of a better phrase — to the dark side. He would have become a very very dark and dangerous reflection of who he was meant to be. There you go.

video_description: #stitch with @Chris Williams, author lets make misogny a public conversation. Regularly. #horror #horrortok #horrorbooks #booktok
voice_to_text: we're heading into the weekend where stokercon is going to be on everyone's mind go back and watch Chris's video we are once again talking about msgyny in the horror book community it has been reported that author Otis Bateman and author Steph he Cooper have been exchanging photos of women without their permission this is what is known as Revenge Corn Otis has deleted all of his accounts except for his Reddit accounts um and you can go and look at that for yourself and Steven issued a very I am an insult apology I'm not a bad person I was just lonely I need a woman etcetera it is very easy for these bad players to make a home in the horror community and they hide right in front of our faces but many of you have to wait until it gets to this point to call out the bad behaviour there are signs and when some of us in the community point out these signs we are met with you don't even understand the genre and so like Chris said stokercon is happening this weekend and there won't be a lot of chatter about this there probably won't be much chatter about Tphobia although Hellbound books will still be tabling at the event though if I had to wager I guess I'd say this will probably be their last year there won't be a lot of chatter about racism and the difficulties that BIPOC creators and authors deal with such as review bombing and award should be a place for Celebration but this is not just an award show it's also a convention and what better place to address these issues than at a place where fans are conveening  if we don't start addressing these issues in a more meaningful way things like this are gonna continue to happen I would love to sit on a panel in 2025 with other female creators and female authors in the horror space and talk about msg y in this community as a final note I am happy to see more authors speak up and speak up quickly but we need you to start this when the warning signs start to present themselves so it doesn't escalate to this point

voice_to_text: what are some book pet peeves that you have I realized this is a really hot take but my answer is all things pregnancy one I don't wanna read pregnancy tropes so please list it in the blurb or in the list of tropes or whatever but put it somewhere easily findable because if I get halfway through the book and now somebody's knocked up especially if it's a main character I'm annoyed and I don't wanna finish it I probably will because I have to see how it ends and I love happily ever afters but and with that being said not every happily ever after needs an epilogue or an extra couple chapters just to tell me that they're gonna start a family or that she's knocked up like I get it that is a given for most people but for me as a child free by choice human I don't need every book to end in in a pregnancy to know that it ended happily or that they're going to be happily ever after

voice_to_text: it's a trope that doesn't make any sense and it's a trope that actually gets on my last goddamn nerve medieval stasis is something that is really only useful if you're trying to talk about a very specific thing in a very specific way the wandering inn has medieval stasis as the only example of medieval stasis I've ever experienced that was actually genuinely interesting in the wandering inn the reason why there's medieval states isn't why there's all these universities like the Magic School to go to is Wistrom Academy if you go there and you can make it you're one of like you have a shoe in for any kind of magic based job in your specialty because mages are rare in the sense it's very expensive to become one here's the thing and here is the reason why there is such a problem with medieval stasis in the wandering inn the universe quite literally will not allow them to progress the Wandering Inn is a LitRPG for the uninitiated a LitRPG is a uh book usually fantasy or scifi sometimes both uh that has RPG elements there is a progression system people level up their stats the wandering inn doesn't actually have a way for them to view their stats they just innately know that they have abilities and they know what their level is they don't have like an interface screen like most LitRPG and in the wandering inn the way that anybody gained any knowledge is they gain it from skills they gain it from abilities so if you're say a carpenter your entire carpentry skill like this is just skills capital s in brackets skills you don't actually know how to build anything you're not a carpenter in like as far as we would consider you are unskilled labor you are the intern you're the gopher but because you have skills bolstering your everything you just know how to do it and this is a problem because nobody knows how they're doing anything Erin regards this how whenever she's making something that she knows how to make through one of her cooking skills she just kind of goes into a feuge state she quite literally is not in control of herself while she is doing it one of the other point of view characters Ryoka Griffin can't level she refuses to level so every skill she has is one that she trained naturally and actually carries that information and there is a stark difference between her and a lot of the other characters going on that is touched on in the Bolaros arc I'm not getting too deeply into it the people down in Bolaros realize that after they have been isekaied into this world they are forgetting things about our world like it's not being erased but it is being suppressed one of the characters realizes that like he's not thought about his wife and child and like months and it upsets him greatly because he misses them he loves them and he might not ever see them again he wants to but he doesn't want to forget them like his daughter was a baby when he got transported into this world so they're all trying to figure out ways to remember things about this world and other characters who are isekaied into this world are bringing things from our world into theirs because we know how to do it things are wild advancements because we don't need skills to be skilled like one character who had no idea that they've been transported to this world remarked that when she went to go get an apprenticeship as a scribe she didn't need to be taught a lot of the intro stuff she didn't need to be taught a lot of like the babies first things about like being a scribe and like arranging papers and this is like a lot of the the dredgery that we were taught in kindergarten and she's like I've I've never experienced this and every single character who managed to go off and get a job like that remarked that there was a similar thing Erin brought theater to the wandering inn and that is my one criticism is I truly do not think that even with a sys- like an entire world setting that has medieval stasis enforced we have storytellers and they have bards and troubadours and entertainers but they didn't have theater I part of I call bullshit they had theater it was just inaccessible and Erin brought it to the masses and if she had done that it probably would have hit so much better because the theater that Erin brought to the masses was Shakespeare but every other fantasy setting that does medieval stasis gets on my last nerve because I don't do anything with it in the wandering inn it's a major plot point it's a major facet world building there is a reason behind it and it's not great not great in the sense like it's not great for the people narratively speaking is fantastic but please read the wandering inn please read the wandering inn I've gone insane over this book series

voice_to_text: whenever someone describes a place as having southern charm I always think they mean well they used to own slaves but they can so my name is Shawna Miles and I am a southern black children's book writer and I set my middle grade spooky novel in Charleston South Carolina the follow up book The Rise of Easter Egway is set in Savannah Georgia I put both of these books in southern cities because they are very old cities and those cities also have deep African American roots the magic system that I built is based on Hoodoo and if you know anything about that it is a belief system that was kind of uh crafted by African Americans especially the Gullah Geechee people who live on the coast of South Carolina and Georgia so in this particular book where it's set in Charleston our main character Theo Tattley is 12 years old and he lives in a multi generational um family home on Bay Street these homes are famous they are also very very old and can harken back to pre slavery times and because of that the uh story is kind of based around him trying to keep his family home in his family and how they acquired the deed for the home not to give anything away but he ends up having to battle a Confederate demon now some people like to shy away from that sort of history but I think it's so much fun to get into it because we have such deep roots in the place the second book is set in Savannah in the same thing we get to encounter all kinds of ghosts friendly and not so friendly but more importantly all kinds of black people and we get to get into their history the food they eat and how awesome they are you can pick up both of my novels wherever you like to buy books the rise in ISA Iguay will be coming out in October so you can go ahead and pre order that and follow that Creator's Guide to Savannah

I love this trope so much that I can't stop writing it in my debut novel a lot of people live in this house my main character Rachel and her husband Joe were separated because the pandemic he gets trapped in India she gets trapped in Boston in a house full of 10 strangers in a communal living situation and it wasn't her idea to move in the first place because she just like I can't be around people I don't like people people don't like me whereas job is like what are you talking about you're so lovable and he just loves her so much he loves her so so much and she loves him but she's like more reserved as a person and there's something about that character dynamic that is so appealing to me to write you have a human who has been through all kinds of hardship and has been told that they aren't lovable or life has convinced them of the fact when in reality they're fabulous and their partner sees them like actually sees them and it's like I wish you could see yourself the way I see you and then throughout the story they eventually see themselves the partner sees them and they're like oh I'm not an asshole and I deserve love and better yet I can love people better because of that realization like Frederick Bachman's a Man Called UVE is that how you say it uh was just like you got the grumpiest old man in the world because he's he's grieving and all these people around him uh like weasel their way into his life and show him that life is worth living even though his wife is gone and it's just oh god it's those characters those characters get under your skin right uh I love characters who don't love themselves because it makes me wanna double down and love them more

video_description: #stitch with @Gvillesoul no shade and no hate intended. I love your take and video, indeed! I wanted to share that the book series is by #JuliaQuinn and if anyone has yet to read her novels, chances are you are missing out. As an avid reader and fan of Miss Quinn’s penmanship, the books are absolutely wonderful and absolutely romantic. Miss Rhimes did a beautiful job bringing them to life on-screen and spicing them up however they were Miss Quinn’s creation and I think we all deserve to read the originals as they were written before the storylines were changed for television. Thank you, Queen 👑and I hope you don’t mind the #stitch! 🫶🏼  The reading list js below for those that haven’t heard of them. 💗 Happy Reading! #fyp #fy #foryou #bridgerton #aboutbridgerton #booktok #booktokfyp #reply #stitchkindness #educationalpurposes #bridgertonscandal #simonanddaphne #thedukeandi #colinandpenelope #romancingmisterbridgerton #benedictandsophie #anofferfromagentleman #antonyandkate #theviscountwholovedme #eloiseandphillip #tosirphillipwithlove #francescaandmichael #whenhewaswicked #hyacinthandgareth #hyacinthbridgerton #itsinhiskiss #gregorybridgerton #gregoryandhermione  #onthewaytothewedding #ladywhistledown #ladywhistledownstrikesback #queencharlotte was not oart of the series however i am happy if was made because we get to see more of her and the king and her much needed friendship with #ladydanbury
voice_to_text: I just finished watching Bridgerton and I have a question for you guys hi friend I have a question for you have you actually done your research on who actually wrote the Bridgerton series it's not Shonda Rhimes it is Miss Julia Quinn she created the very first book called The Duke and I and that one was published in the year 2000 there's an entire series that lady lady whistle down my apologies lady whistle down talks about throughout the series so you get to see everything from Daphne to Anthony then Benedict then Colin and um let me see there's an F somewhere I can't remember which one but it even goes as far as hyacinth and her brother so there are also the further observations of Lady Whistledown so those beautiful things that are being said can be found in the book as well for the most part so I I don't wanna discredit Miss Rhymes but as an avid reader of Miss Julia Quinn that's who you should be talking about or directing things to her books are amazing and they are worth every weed that you can possibly give them I would suggest to anyone that is interested in Bridgerton to please find the actual book series by Miss Julia Quinn and start reading them they're amazing thank you

voice_to_text: if you're a fan of audio book narrator Stephen Pacey I need your help as you may know I just finished Artificial Wisdom and picked it up again two days later to reread almost always when I reread a book I reread it in a different medium than I read it the first time around the first time I read it I listen to the audiobook narrated by Stephen Pacey even though I have access to the ebook right now I'm listening to the audiobook again obviously I'm a huge fan of this book to be rereading it so soon but I'm also a huge fan of the audiobook because I'm listening to it again so soon I typically have just one audiobook going at a time and I had picked up another audiobook that I was really enjoying and I just paused it so that I could focus on artificialism again I have also recently been listening to books on graphic audio for the most part so there's a whole cast there's sound effects there's a lot going into it and on the first read through of artificialism I all of a sudden realized hey this isn't graphic audio I forgot for a moment because the narration was so good Steven Pacey does such a good job of giving each of the characters a unique voice then particular I love haymaker I already know that when I dive into Joe Abercrombie's work it's it's gonna be audio so I can hear Stephen Pacey's interpretation I do have the physical books coming in the mail and I'm really excited to read those as well but I already know that Artificial Wisdom is gonna be one of those books that I reread over and over again especially while I'm waiting for book two to come out I'm already envisioning listening to it again when we get to release date for book two just really great work and right now since apparently the book is sold out in the United States on release day which is incredible it sounds like it's a really great time to dive into an audiobook doesn't it

voice_to_text: Alright, what have you stopped buying because it's gotten so expensive? Honestly, books. Cause some of these hardcover books have gotten way too expensive. Let me give you an example that illustrates this. So I bought a children of blood and bone back in 2018 and it was $18. And yes, it is hardcover, so it should be pretty expensive. Now on the other hand, here's a book that I bought just last week. This one, also a hardback, cost 30. A hardcover book should not cost $30.

I definitely have considered it. I'm concerned when I see people who say they lost their shop or got shut down because it took more than three days to ship something. That's a little scary. I mean I don't — it would be shipped within three days, but you know I don't like that Sword of Damocles kind of over my head. And I have 16 titles and I'm concerned about like, how do I decide what to keep on hand cause I really think if you do a TikTok shop you have to be shipping it yourself because relying on dropshipment like IngramSpark, that's where a lot of people have trouble with that three day thing. So I'm still considering it. And then there's the idea that TikTok might be gone so…

voice_to_text: I think this is so true because when I was growing up and even still today I don't think about trailers or advertisements for books I don't recall seeing them very often and even if I do I can't recall the last time that I bought a book based off of one when I go buy a book it's usually just going into a bookstore because I love going into bookstores and I wander around until I see a cover that catches my eye and then I read the back and if I like the back I buy the book or if a person at the store has put down their recommendation of a book I read it I agree with the recommendation sounds like something I'd be interested in I buy that book but the main way that I have always gone about buying books has primarily been word of mouth a friend or family member says hey I read this book I think you'd like it and I generally trust them and I go pick that up and I think the booktok is kind of the technological next logical step of word of mouth you see one booktokker review a book say hey I really like this book is what it's about you okay maybe that sounds good and then you see another one and another one like all right well 10,000 people or whatever it is can't be wrong so I'm gonna check out this book too but it's so much more organic than an advertisement or marketing campaign or any other sort of a thing that a bigger publisher might try and push out there to get a book really in front of people and so I think that that's what's so great about booktok is a it's very representative of all the different subgenres all different types of authors all different types of stories people are reading what they wanna read talking about what they wanna read they're telling you if they liked it or not and then you as the viewer of Booktok get to decide I like this person I've generally agreed with the recommendations in the past I'm gonna trust them on this or you know that doesn't sound like something I'm interested in and you move on to the next one but that's what's so great about Booktok is there so much I mean my TikTok feed is almost all booktok and Barbara's rhubarb dance at this point so I'm doing something right here but throw my hat in the ring of course as a author here's Mattson Academy this is my book I published it in September last year second book comes out September this year and I would love more people to get a chance to read it and find out more about the world I created but I've been loving my experience on Booktok in the last year I bought books based off recommendations from Booktok I've reviewed and made recommendations as a member of Booktok and I intend to continue doing that and I intend to continue to participate in this wonderful community

voice_to_text: feeling like they're not like a real go person  I don’t know if you’ve ever had this sense of like not feeling like you're a real person or not being fully within your life it definitely resonated with me it was actually one of the reasons that I wanted to get into existential therapy to begin with I always had this feeling that I was like standing on the outside edge of my life and looking in and I couldn't get within my own experience I could only like observe it from the outside I don't know if it resonates with you I need to share a little bit about the approach in existential therapy there are often thought to be four dimensions of existence in this form of therapy so those are physical social psychological or personal and then spiritual this kind of work which is like values authenticity integrity sense of self sense of identity who am I that kind of thing this is often categorized within the personal or psychological dimension as with most topics in existential therapy there is a really broad and open approach taken to this topic and there is a sense that your sense of self or your identity will never be completely stable completely secure throughout every single aspect of your life so throughout all environments relationships situations whatever that you're actually an evolving sort of fluid more dynamic kind of human being for this question of like who am I or on a more foundational level like am I real like am I a real human being in this kind of scenario this is a question that can change throughout your life and is kind of like a process of figuring out like who you are this is a book called Existential Coaching How philosophy can help your clients live with greater awareness courage and ownership and when they're talking about the psychological dimension they name two components authenticity and identity and they say people can never become fully authentic and then stay that way forever we will inevitably weave in and out of authentic states as we go through life and continuously discover new blind spots as we evolve as people you're always in a process of becoming so in response to the situation described in the original video where you're kinda thinking like who am I or like am I the same as ever or like where am I situated in this context or in this environment I was saying not only is that probably quite a common phenomenon but it is also a foundational aspect of the psychological dimension of existence where you're figuring out like what is my identity in this context what is it in this environment and how is it changing as I move throughout my life And actually really the process of questioning it or calling it out or identifying it or observing it in yourself is the process of identity forming so where you think I'm not sure like who I am in this scenario that in itself is like an aspect of the journey towards an evolving sense of self

voice_to_text: obviously that didn't happen it is now May 27th and I'm just now getting around to making this video um let's dive into it uh I give these women like a 4.2/4.3 um I'm stealing my friend's scale she's in my book club and um she rates books based off of like how well like how much she's gonna remember it or is she likely to recommend it to somebody, did it impact her life so like 5 is she's going to actively recommend this book to people a 4 is um she might think about it every once in a while or somebody asks her if they should read it she's gonna be like yeah read it  a 3 is like it was okay, you enjoy it while you're reading it um if it gets brought up in conversation you might mention that you read it a 2 is probably never gonna think about it again a 1 is I don't know wish you never read it so um I'm stealing her scale so using that I'm giving this book like a 4.3 um if you were to come up to me and be like hey this book is in my TBR should I read it I'm gonna be like read it and then come back to me and tell me your thoughts so that's kind of the conversation that's gonna happen if somebody asks me about this book um so yeah so it's five women who are affected in some way of by the serial killer in LA and um it's five parts so each part is a different perspective and once we hear from one woman and kinda learn her like build up to this moment and what's happening right now um and her part is over you don't get her perspective again so that was really interesting because you don't really get closure um by the end of each part but you know she might one of the other women might show up in the next chapter one of the future not chapters but one of the future parts and um so that was interesting that you can't go back to be like cause it's chronological so um when one woman's part ends the next woman doesn't backtrack back to what was happening in that other part it keeps going so maybe parts one and two those women interact with each other part 2 kind of picks up from that interaction so it doesn't go back before that interaction um so you don't the story keeps going and you don't hear from the past women again which is really interesting but I really liked it um the way this author is able to develop these characters who are completely different from each other um they're all kind of living in the same area um but completely different women ages races professions I mean it felt like five different women you know just to be able to I don’t know get in the minds of that many people and being able to portray that was amazing so highly highly highly recommend this book um if you read it let me know how you like it um yeah so I know it's May 27th and I have the next um I'm supposed to have a um blind date with a voice_to_text: Desire The starting point of all achievement the first step towards riches the method by which desire for riches can be transmuted into its financial equivalent consists of six definite practical steps First. Fix in your mind the exact amount of money you desire it is not sufficient merely to say “I want plenty of money” be definite as to the amount (there is a psychological reason for definiteness which will be described in a subsequent chapter). Second. Determine exactly what you intend to give in return for the money you desire (there is no such reality as something for nothing.) Third. Establish a definite date when you intend to possess the money you desire Fourth. Create a definite plan for carrying out your desire and begin at once whether you are ready or not to put this plan into action. Fifth. Write out a clear concise statement of the amount of money you intend to acquire name the time limit for its acquisition state what you intend to give in return for the money and describe clearly the plan through which you intend to accumulate it Sixth. Read your written statement aloud twice daily once just before retiring at night and once after arising in the morning as you read see and feel and believe yourself already in possession of the money

voice_to_text: definitely watch that entire video from that creator it's an amazing video super interesting she breaks everything down like really quickly but it's essentially getting into what genres the publishers are spending money on what genres they recoup money on it doesn't matter how big of a reader you are whether you're really avid reader or you read occasionally I think everybody will find it interesting but I feel so validated because I did an entire podcast episode on this like back in April so basically what my podcast episode was about was this like very small pocket of people on Book Talk who are really pretentious they only read like literature write and you know they won't read anything that is you know somewhat entertaining or bestseller or whatever and so they have kind of pushed this narrative on book talk that so much of book talk has ruined the publishing industry entirely where because of book talk now things like you're calling hoovers are taking over etc etc and I called bullsh*t on that did a whole podcast episode on it so if you want you can go back and listen to it but again I feel really really validated actually seeing these real numbers because that was one thing I said in the podcast episode as I was like this is all observational it's all conjecture like I don't have actual numbers to back this up basically my whole point and podcast episode where I like formulated my argument was being 31 years old I can see that you know the romance genre like your  Colleen  Hoover's like your smutty spicy romance books has always been popular right like you have these like cliche romance books in the 80s and stuff like that and I believe that if you actually look at those numbers that genre has always been a very popular bestseller but now seeing this video which again you should go watch the whole thing it just adds another layer to the argument there was one other point that I had in my podcast episode that does get mentioned in that video so feeling kind of proud of myself feeling kind of intelligent but essentially it was just the point that you know when you do have these best sellers whatever that genre is and it's actually not spice and smut and stuff like sometimes it can be but not always and so once you have these best sellers the ones that are selling really really well they fund everything else is getting published so therefore that's what I'm saying in my podcast episode is like don't worry like the spice and smut is not taking over like might they be selling really well at the moment because of  Colleen  Hoover because of whatever and they're really popular yes but they are funding the weird girl literature the feminine rage literature or whatever it is that you're reading but again there's just like more to that video entirely so I do recommend that you go listen to the full thing but it did get me thinking about what books people buy because obviously I'm a big reader I have a podcast actually the second podcast centered around books and reading as you can see so I buy pretty much anything and everything however I even myself still have rules as to like what I like to buy and what I wanna have as a hard copy versus like a Kindle or an audiobook so I do wonder after seeing that video thinking about myself I want to ask you guys what are the books that you will buy physical copies of is there a specific genre do you also have like certain rules or whatever definitely let me know because I am super interested

video_description: #stitch with @jeZAbelle 💚  Hey Besties, are you looking for a book with this vibe? After The Shut Up Ring ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️🌟 🌶️🌶️ Characters 💙💙💙💙💙 Small Town Romance: left him at the alter, chronic illness (HSV-2), small town, best friends older brother, friends to lovers, it’s always been you, finding herself again📕 Out Now First Person, Present Tense, Dual POV (P)📚, (KU)📱: 256 📄 Thank you @Cate C Wells for this #gifted book. shut up ring (noun) 💍 a marriage proposal meant to get you off his back, intended to last indefinitely I waited eight years to marry the father of my children. I worked at our relationship. I was patient. I forgave—the thoughtless remarks, the disappointments, the test results when I was expecting our youngest that proved he hadn’t been “working late.” Then, when we finally made it to the altar, he looked deep into my eyes, smiled, and cracked a fat joke. That wasn’t the worst of it. His vows weren’t a promise to love. They were a final test of exactly what I’d do to get his ring on my finger—what I’d take—in front of family, friends, and their cell phones. Was I going to be internet famous? Another sad bride who must’ve known the kind of man she was marrying? My two little girls stared up at me with big, round eyes. Was I really going to laugh it off like I always did? In that moment, my house of cards came crashing down. When the moment was over, for some reason, my best friend’s older brother was on his feet with his chair knocked over like he was about to punch someone. This is the story of what happened next. Please check the author’s note for specific content warnings. Standalone. No cheating. HEA guaranteed. Thoughts: 💡 This book broke my heart and put it back together again so many times. I loved Angie’s determination and Brandon’s whole cinnamon roll heart but rough around the edges blue collar vibe. The way these two pinned for each other but had so much respect for one another  and focused on building one another up was brilliant.  Gah! I swear I will read anything from Cate C Wells because she hits it out of the park with every new premise she tries. ✨standalone Quote💬 I should be getting over it as it happens. That’s how this relationship works. He steamrolls me. I peel myself off the floor and bounce right back into shape. One day, she’ll see this, and she’ll understand every word of it. They both will. They’ll be ashamed of me. Like I’m ashamed of myself. “Everyone deserves to be treated with kindness and respect by the people who love them.” “And it is never too late to speak up for yourself.” “I won’t marry you,” I say, forcing myself to look Tyler in his bright red face. “I won’t do this. No.” 🏷️ #spicybooks #books  #booksoftiktok  #booktok #bookrecs #bookreviews #kindleunlimited #kindleunlimitedromance #bestfriendsbrother #bestfriendsbrothertrope #bestfriendsbrotherromance #bluecollarmen #hurtcomfort #angstybooks #angstyromance #romancebooks #booktok #smuttok #steamytok #spicytok #steamybookrecs #spicybookrecs #kindleromance #kindleromancebooks #kindlespicybooks #catecwells #spon

voice_to_text: What book trope is your relationship? Okay, this is really cute. So my husband and I were kind of fake dating, and then it turned into a he falls first. So basically, 14 years ago, I needed a prom date. And we met through friends of friends, and we went on a date, and the date was great, but I just wasn't really feeling it, which sounds awful to say now, but, like. And I don't think he really was, either. At least at the time, I didn't. Right? But I was like, hey, here's the situation. I really need a prom date. Can we just keep this thing going? And he was like, yeah. We just started hanging out, became friends, went to prom together. Prom was very romantic and lovey dovey, and things kind of changed that night for us. And then, like, a month later, he told me he loved me, and he loved me the entire time. So it was definitely a he falls first. And I was just like, oh, okay, let's try this. So we tried it, and 14 years later, two kids. I'm very happy, and he's still my best friend.

palavras nesse  nesse vídeo nessa audiência o advogado da defesa pegou  tipo fotos do Instagram da Mariana onde ela tava tipo fotos onde ela tava com biquíni ou com roupas mais curtas e tava usando isso pra mostrar "olha ela quer atenção" "olha como ela aqui nas redes sociais" tipo teve até um acontecimento que aconteceu comigo que não tem não foi nada sobre tipo abus0 nem nada disso mas por exemplo eu tava aqui no meu prédio com uma galera  com meus amigos era tipo 22h 23h da noite e era dentro do prédio e aí uns caras– é uma policial uma delegada (e o marido) se eu não me engano entrou no nosso prédio por circunstâncias que enfim não me cabem falar aqui porque não importa o motivo dela ter entrado mas ela entrou no nosso prédio sem morar lá e ela falou ela olhou pra mim e pras minhas amigas falou tipo "o que cês tão fazendo aqui esse horário?" "seus pais sabem que  cês tão fazendo aqui esse horário vestidas assim?" e aquilo pra mim foi o cúmulo e "o vestidas assim"  eu tava de calça e com uma blusa de manga porque tava calor minhas amigas tavam vestindo shorts  mais uma vez no nosso prédio seguras nossos pais sabendo que estávamos ali porque era tipo basicamente a gente tava no nosso quintal  e isso sem a gente ter feito nada eu e minhas amigas não tinha feito literalmente nada a delegada não tinha entrado lá por conta da gente tinha sido por outras circunstâncias como eu falei  por outras pessoas e a gente recebeu sem ter feito nada então isso coloca a pergunta tipo e se a gente tivesse ali por exemplo se eu tivesse ido falar com essa delegada porque ai alguma coisa aconteceu com a gente ela teria essa mesma atitude de olhar pra gente e falar assim "o que cês estão fazendo aqui esse horário vestidas assim?" isso também tudo ata (atar) como por exemplo  essa discussão que tá tendo nas redes sociais sobre homem ou urso onde basicamente as mulheres respondem se elas gostariam de ficar presas em algum local com um homem ou com um urso e muitas na verdade todas responde com  (inclusive urso é a resposta certa) e é por isso também que muitas mulheres quando acontece alguma coisa do sentido assim com elas elas não vão é a polícia porque sabemos que tipo não vai dar em nada por exemplo a Chanel falou aqui no livro dela sobre o que que ela teve que fazer pra quando ela foi na polícia e tipo basicamente violaram a menina uma segunda vez e humilharam ela ainda em corte de certa forma e tipo tudo isso pro cara ser condenado e tipo o cara foi condenado mas o que isso mudou na vida dela? tipo o cara claro tava— maravilha foi preso mas tipo ela ainda teve que sofrer as consequências sabe e tudo isso porque no vídeo dessa moça que eu coloquei no começo muitos caras tavam na– nos comentários falando assim "porque cê não chama a polícia primeiro?" "porque você deixou esse cara andar como você?" e tipo ela literalmente explicou porque ela deixou o cara andar com ela porque ela tava com medo de se ela falar "não" acontecesse alguma coisa com ela tipo claramente ia acontecer porque o cara se achou no direito de tipo  só porque ele andou e falou com ela ele tinha o direito de entrar e tomar alguma coisa dela e também só pra finalizar eu lembro de ter visto uma entrevista com um homem que escreveu um livro sobre como as mulheres deveriam aprender a falar  um livro que pelo que eu vi é realmente muito interessante porque de fato quando a gente é mulher a gente é meio que ensinado a ser boazinha com as pessoas então a gente ia ensinar a ser educado tipo se você ver um homem estranho falando bom dia tipo te olhando estranho você pra mim pelo menos é tipo meio que natural falar bom dia tipo depois meio que pensar meu "mas ué?" e apesar desse ensinamento ser interessante tipo assim você não precisa ser educada com todo mundo você não precisa parar pra ajudar ninguém nem nada disso você tem que aprender a tipo seguir em frente ignorar ou tipo negar sabe apesar de ser interessante nessa situação por exemplo ela falou ela demonstrou que ela tava com medo da segurança dela então ela não fez e é isso que muitos homens não entendem porque muitos homens não passa disso passam por isso* porque é um privilégio muito grande que eu vejo muitas vezes na rua de homem andando com fone e andando mexendo no celular  e andando tipo descontraído (despreocupado) porque eles não tem esse medo o pior medo que eles têm é tipo ser assaltado mas aí cê tá num bairro que ele sabe que não acontece, tudo bem mas tipo a gente não a gente tem que ter essa- você tem que tá ligado aos seus arredores porque pode acontecer milhões de coisas e é isso urso é a resposta certa

voice_to_text: I've heard a lot of people pointing out the fantasy trope where a woman has to give up all of her power to get married and have children out of nowhere because of course that's all we're good for but I never heard anyone pointing out how HARD the romance genre also tries to indoctrinate us with the 'forced apology' trope you tell me if you haven't read this okay so they meet he acquires power over her in some way she disobeys him or is forced to he saves her at the last minute of course but he gets hurt doing so so she feels guilty and has to apologize and recognize that he was right all along he graciously accept her apology they say I love you she gets to live with him a person that knows better than her about everything and the book ends girlies make sure to check your romances for misogyny seriously not even our hobbies are safe okay that's why it's important to read critically that doesn't mean you can't have fun at the same time though enjoy your romances girlies 💖

voice_to_text: do you guys remember last year when um I got duped in thinking that the author of hula was Native Hawaiian so I don't know why uh her AAPI Heritage Month post came up on my feed I don't know why cause I don't follow her um and saying how you know because of the talk about questioning her background and her right to tell a story she started digging doing some digging into her background and now she is finding out that she's possibly Hawaiian so I read this caption you can pause to read um and I was like oh my god so did she find out that she's actually Native Hawaiian is she Kanaka Maoli because if she is I want to correct myself and post that she is and I went down like the comments and I saw that there was another um indigenous like Kanaka Maoli uh writer who reached out to her and I went in a hole like and I found her on TikTok this is her page an interview with the author and I watched her I think her the full length is in her bio but I just watched the like in the seven or six parts that's posted on her TikTok um which is already illuminating um so my takeaway is that you're she's not kanaka Maoli right look clearly I am not Native Hawaiian or I'm not from Hawaii I just know cause after having real conversations with actual kanaka Maoli writers and reviewers and other P I book people um And the comments that I've received and DMs that I've received after that post I know that misrepresenting yourself as being Native Hawaiian and Kanaka Maoli like a like a a race and ethnicity is harmful and I think her saying that she's possibly Hawaiian and kind of still muddying it is still harmful right it still is taking away from indigenous people in Hawaii who have to speak up and advocate for themselves and this narrative that she's putting in I think takes away from them and I don't know is it just me

#stitch with @HollyGilmore ✨🍓“Hollow Brook Mutants” 🍓✨is a captivating YA contemporary science fiction/fantasy novel that explores the unexpected consequences of a single impulsive act. When fifteen-year-old Jenny Philips, grieving the loss of her parents, and her new friends, Alex and Stephen, inadvertently acquire supernatural abilities after sneaking into a mysterious farm, their summer takes a thrilling turn. Dubbing themselves “Mutants” to avoid being labeled as “Freaks,” the trio navigates the challenges of adolescence—bullies, boy problems, and the daunting task of hiding their powers. As they strive to protect their secret and each other, Jenny discovers the extent of her powers and her willingness to do anything for her friends, and the future she dreams of. #genz #millennial #booktok #authortok

voice_to_text: I don’t think booktok as a collective unit understands just how much power you have  over the publishing industry right now eleven months ago I self published a book called dating and dismemberment it was a monster romcom and I had no idea if anybody would ever read it but honestly I didn't care  because I wrote that book for myself I was going through a hard emotional time and writing that book brought me joy then to my great surprise booktok embraced it and loved it to the point where Entangled Publishing which published Fourth Wing picked it up and is going to be reissuing it this fall  along with two more books in the series we've already sold audio rights we've already sold foreign rights and there's been film interest and it's all because of you freaking maniacs in booktok that changed my life  thank you

voice_to_text: I'm curious, what do other girls put on the walls of their bedroom? I commissioned a painting from a artist on TikTok that I saw pop up, and I asked her to make a painting of Mr. Darcy's hand from pride and prejudice. And then I also collect butterflies and different art prints from places that I travel to. And then I have a photo of my dog that died a few years ago because I love her so very much. And then I collect pins from whenever I go to Broadway shows and hang them up here as well.

voice_to_text: so I currently have 74 unread books on my physical TBR mostly behind me, a few elsewhere on the shelves when I sat down and did this maths there had been 145 days so far in this year and I had read 51 books I haven't finished any more since then so that averaged out to a book every 2.84 days at that rate, it would take me 210 days or about 30 weeks to finish all of those books if I read absolutely nothing else which would take me through to Friday the twentieth of December this year however, although this is to the letter of what was asked it doesn't really feel to the spirit, it feels too easy so in those 145 days, I've read 16 new books off of my physical TBR the rest being library books, rereads eARCs, public domain, et cetera but that averages out to one book of the physical TBR every 9.06 days which is then 670.62 days or 95.8 weeks to finish all of them taking me through to March 25th, 2026 which is a Wednesday I did also DNF two books off the physical TBR that knocks about 10 weeks off but that is still 2026 but I could finish them this year if I really wanted to so I don't feel bad about it

voice_to_text: making writing and publishing a book look quick and easy because spoiler alert it's not I would know because I'm doing it and to caveat  this for the quick part I'm not talking about self publishing because self publishing is all you you can set your own timeline it can go as quick or as slow as you like indie publishing tends to be quicker than full traditional publishing because that's like submitting submitting your manuscript straight to the publishing house takes usually like a year or so where is traditional publishing where you got editors agents everything involved that takes years if you are traditional publishing you first you have to write your manuscript then you have to polish it and edit it then you have to start querying and querying can take weeks it can take months if you're lucky you could get a few offers straight out the gate but generally speaking if you're that lucky you've spent a long time already revising your manuscript to the point where it's they don't have to do much to it then once you've signed your agent you might do more edits with your agent because they know the market better than you might and then you'll go on submission to editors and if you're lucky enough for an editor to select your book for the publishing house they have to take it to acquisitions who will then make the decision and then once you've signed with a publishing house you will have to go through more edits with your editor at the publishing house and when all that is said and done you're probably looking at two years probably more depending on how long it took you to write your book some people can write a book really fast some people take over a year to write a book so you are looking at a minimum of like two years for traditional publishing and possibly longer depending on how long it takes you to work to work all these TV shows and movies to show people traditionally publishing of their books or their memoirs or whatever it is in months it's not realistic it really isnt
