voice_to_text: you don't understand where the fugg is it? THERE!! you're probably wondering what's in the bag let's take it back a little bit first sorry my voice is a little raspy I'm just getting over the flu so I was in sixth grade I had to read a book for class that traumatized me so bad that my mom actually had to come in and talk to my teacher and the principal and that book was Sadako in the Thousand Paper Cranes in case you're not familiar it's the story of a little girl in post World War 2 Japan who suffers radiation poisoning from the atomic bombs that we dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki and it's about her slowly passing of cancer in a hospital while she tries to fold 1,000 paper cranes because there's an ancient legend that the gods will cure a sickness or grant a wish or something to that effect if somebody folds 1,000 paper cranes so what made it more traumatizing was this is a true story like I'm supposed to just go to recess after I read the part when she finally stopped folding the cranes because her fingers were in so much pain that she just physically couldn't bend them to fold the paper anymore and I'm just supposed to go play like Foursquare so what's in the bag about 600 or so paper cranes that I folded between probably like sixth and eighth grade because they had us fold some because they do there's like a festival in Japan or something that they sent them off to and I just never stopped because I didn't know how to fugging process this book can't get rid of them no can't get rid of them I've held onto that bag for heccing 20 years because I didn't hit a thousand yet I can't get rid of them until I hit a thousand right y'all this book f'd me up

video_description: #stitch with @IAMTV as someone who grew up in predominantly in my mother’s home, i naturally felt closer to that side of the family.  but i went through a period where my dad would make comments like this and it led to us having a relatively strained relationship up until he passed away.  Its not to say I didn’t love my dad, cause I absolutely did, but those rough moments imprinted in my brain and kept me from really spending time with him when I got old enough to make my own decisions about our relationship.  #fyp #taylorswift #bbldrizzy #booktok #wwe #dysfunctionalfamily
voice_to_text: You know, this boy have the nerve to say he don't like me and don't. And can you blame him? I wouldn't like you either if this is what you do when you're angry. Instead of shaming him and videotaping him and trying to embarrass him, how about you sit down with him and ask him why he does not want to be around you and your family? You said that he's old enough to make his decisions. But in the same breath you also said it had something to do with his mother. So which one is it? Is he old enough to make his own decision, or is he being influenced by his mother? I would say it's the former as opposed to the latter. You might wanna figure out why he doesn't wanna be around you and your family instead of throwing all of the materialistic things that you do for him. That doesn't make up for all of the lost time that you may not have or some of the things that he may need for you to pour into him. But by shaming him, is not gonna make him like you or wanna be around you anymore. In fact, it's going to make him not wanna talk to you. And then you're gonna wonder why when he becomes an adult, why he doesn't fuck with you as a man. Figure it out.

#stitch with @Dr. Haley, MD 🫀 I’m a trad pub author-artist with two Big 5 publishers, and here’s what I think marketing is doing with this ARC reader review policy. I can’t think of a single circumstance in which a publisher would not want early presales and buzz is everything to them. If you’re worried, maybe wait until other people start buzzing because certainly they will. #booktok #arcreader #bookpublishing #authorsoftiktok #bookreview #bookreviewer
voice_to_text: less than four stars please wait until after publication date can you post a review before a book is published even if you're an art reader and why would a publisher ask you to hold off and why would an author ask you to hold off so if you look at the screen grab here I think what they're actually saying read the book and then post that review on pub day or thereafter because if you post it early on Amozan they're gonna know it's an arc and they know it's not funneled through their buying system that is restricted and can get the book flag so don't do that which is probably why they're putting that stipulation in with the arc book just so there's no confusion but goodread you can post reviews beforehand so I think this is either marketing just simplifying things by saying hey everybody post on pub day you also have to remember that there's a lot of turnover at publishers and they are very busy so it's a little funny to me that she's freaking out about getting in trouble with a big publisher they are regular people especially like marketing department and you're just there to help them you're not gonna get in trouble she's also really excited about this book and is afraid to hype it up because of the stipulation hype it there is no circumstance in which a publisher won't want you to hype their book they want that early buzz early buzz gives you the potential of getting on a bestseller list because all those presale orders count on pub day and that's how you get on things like New York Times best seller list although we all know that's rigged if the cover is public which means the book is on sale that is when you start hyping that's when you start hyping as an author too so what about this request not to post three or four star review early in the process like hold off for two weeks so I've been in book launch groups with other authors and it hasn't happened to me but some of these authors were getting reviewed poorly by other people in the launch group I was facilitating so they came to me and said hey what can we do about this pretty painful at the beginning of your book publication have three star review or even two star review because you only have three review and one is a two and one is a three you're gonna have a two and a half star book so I'm all about honest review but if you were in a launch group that contained your book early or if you're an indie publisher and you're sending those out and saying hey let's get some buzz going they might say don't post low review at least not really in the process because that does hurt a book you don't have a lot of control over that as a traditionally published author because people are gonna say what they wanna say that's why we say have good read or at least try to my personal policy as a fellow creative is not post bad reviews I follow my momma's advice if you don't have anything nice to say don't say anything unless the person is an a hole or the book is particularly bad or problematic in a way that hurts people then I might say something if you watch this far thank you I had a book come out this week and it only has three reviews right now even saying something like I like it give it some start that makes a big difference in a book and an author and an illustrator even when you're quote unquote established uphill battle everything counts thank you

voice_to_text: typically young children are like the most oppressed class uh so I'm a children's book author and I wholeheartedly believe that children are an oppressed class I wouldn't say like the most just because I don't believe in like ranking oppression cause think it's more helpful to talk about that specific intersection but I really agree with a lot of what this creator was saying in that video so I'm in a lot of conversations where we end up talking about book banning cause I write LGBTQ+ books and people like absolutely lose their minds when I tell them that I think that children should absolutely have a say over what kinds of media that they consume above their parents like not with their parents consent children should have access to what media they want to consume if we taught children more actively about consent and boundaries they would also be more equipped for navigating when they feel uncomfortable reading something or consuming a type of media and being able to say no for themselves now I'm not saying we should give kids like books only with like heavily adult themes and stuff but what I am saying is that they deserve autonomy to decide how they engage with those topics

voice_to_text: inferiority be italicist this is a tough one to answer and I'm gonna say sometimes if it's internal dialogue you're talking about then yes that should be in italics you can use quotation marks for that if you want but I think italicized looks better but the thing is interiority and internal dialogue share the like rectangle to square relationship internal dialogue is always interiority but not all interiority is internal dialogue interiority is more an expression of a character's feelings usually in a way where other characters would have to infer that information or pick up on the signs where it's not outright stated internal dialogue is among that because other characters wouldn't be able to hear their thoughts unless it's a whole telepathy thing but that's very specific and this is generally done through the body language of the character or through just the narrations themselves or just adding the voice of the character to that narration it can be something as simple as the POV character pulling their hand away when someone's hand gets too close to show that they're uncomfortable with them or here's an example of injecting character voice into a line of narration a little bit of a character opinion in this example Janet would probably be the POV character and neither of these are things you wanna put into italics because that would be super weird looking interiority is such an important aspect of storytelling of writing and I've really only just scratched the surface of it but internal dialogue really only makes up a small percentage of that and that's the only percentage I would recommend putting into italics I hope someone out there finds this helpful happy writing

voice_to_text: we're teaming up with Kindle Vella to find the next indie published SCI fi hi Kristen and Maddie my name is Devin Thorpe and I think that you guys would love my debut science fiction novel Fallen Angel and the Great News is I just put the first 11 chapters of it on Kindle Vella now I'm primarily known on TikTok because I just self published a werewolf vampire epic fantasy but back in 2020 during the lockdown I was reading a ton of Pierce Brown Red Rising I was obsessed with it so when everything shut down and I had a ton extra time that's when I wrote fallen angel my my first science fiction story but then i didn't do anything with it i just printed it out and let it sit on my bookshelf for the last four years and then i stumbled on y'all's video and it inspired me to publish each chapter as an episode on Kindle Vella if I had to give you a quick synopsis to kind of wet your appetite I would say it takes place 2,000 years in the future when artificial intelligence has taken over and quite literally made a religion made its own religion for humanity to worship it as a god our main character is an archangel known as the Angel of death he is a cyborg half human half robot who does the AI's bidding that is until an organization of humans jailbreak him and disrupt his coding this leads to our main character rediscovering his humanity and starting to question everything the AI has ever told him because the book is already done I finished it back in 2020 I will be releasing new episodes every single day the link is in my bio if you guys wanna check it out like I said the first 10 episodes are currently up there and free to read

I'm curious if anyone has done the Rory Gilmore Reading Challenge so I did do some research after posting that last video and I did find a creator saying that she went through all 399 books from the Rory Gilmore Reading Challenge and saw that most of them are written by old white men and that she actually doesn't want to do the reading challenge for that reason like because they're just not actually going to be a collection of books that she really wants to read with enough variety and diversity and uh different like viewpoints of life and things like that and I really agree with her I'll try to find her and link her in the comments and so I'm glad I did some research before embarking on it myself because she makes a really good point and I think that's actually why I never really embarked and committed on the journey was cause looking at the books did feel a little bit like bland even though she has the vibe of being like very academia and you'd be like well studied and so literature focus and whatever it really kind of falls flat in regard

#stitch with @Freedom Matthews | Author🏹🍂✨ Here are my current plans for my writing projects.  #writer #writertok #writersoftiktok #booktok #writing #writingcommunity #writingcommunityoftiktok #fyp #authorsoftiktok #author #writerslife #indieauthor #indieauthorsoftiktok #JenniferDrewett #NewLeavesOldScars #untitledproject
voice_to_text: What are your plans for your writing future? So my most immediate plan is to get ‘New Leaves, Old Scars’ published. It’s still in the developmental edit which is taking longer than I thought however it is a developmental edit of a book. I don't think… I I gave myself two months to get it done and that's really far too little time but it's okay we're still on track for my planned release date at the moment which is… I don't wanna say it just in case I don't meet the deadline cause that's just a bit embarrassing but I am aiming for end of October but before Halloween so make of that what you will. The good thing is though is once the developmental edit is done then I can send off to be proofread by someone I know and then once I've got that back then I can format it and then I can put it for pre order which I want to do maybe a month out but it depends on how I do it with Draft2Digital so fingers crossed! The other plan I have in the more immediate future is to continue working on the first draft of my new romance novel. I started it two and a half weeks ago and I've written most days except for when I had that horrible migraine. I couldn't look at a screen let alone write so yeah but I I've written pretty much every day even if it's only you know a few sentences. I'm on Chapter 7 at the moment so that's pretty exciting. It's it involves a character that I've had in my head for like nearly 20 years. I just haven't found the right story for her and I finally have this story and it just feels right this time. So yay! I'm hoping to have that one out next year. I'm hoping. It wouldn't be like you know Valentine's Day but it would be probably around October time but it it does depend on how I crack on with the book and how quickly I can turn it around. After that? Well I'm not 100% sure. So with the romance book I just mentioned I do wanna make that a series however I don't wanna not work on other things whilst I'm working on that series if that makes sense. So it it does depend. In my head all I can think of right now for the series is release a book every two years but I don't know for definite yet so we'll we'll we'll have to see and yeah those are my future plans for my writing at the moment. Obviously this isn't accounting for any more ideas I might have crack into my head but no one can see truly into the future so you know let's just see how it goes, eh?

voice_to_text: what's up wheel of time friend I love you your content's great let's make this book just as great okay so if you go back and watch that video for everyone else who's not dread pirate dad is that your name now right right right okay so there have been multiple names ha ha ha ha okay so you have a world you have world building you have magic systems interactions and all that kind of stuff all kind of like building out in your head it's a great start it sounds like you like figuring out the pieces of the story you're just having a hard time scening it got you covered a big problem is there's a giant craft divide so it's not like a fight divide it's like a how your brain works kinda divide so there are people who can just go I wanna write a story about bunnies eating humans whatever and they can sit down and go hmm I'm gonna describe the scene in the background and then oh that's a good character and they can just run with it just writing scenes and they kinda develop it as they go on the other hand there are people who need to plan I'm wondering if you might not be someone who needs to plan so instead of sitting down today maybe for the next week trying to write a scene I want you to try to write an outline just chapter one through 50 cause let's face it you're gonna write fantasy front one through 50 and that'll just be minimum and you wanna say okay plot beats we need your intro chapter that's gotta have a hooky bit about 10% through you wanna hook hook you can Google all this stuff halfway through you're gonna Wanna midpoint turn so like put that underneath chapter 25 midpoint turn something about what the reader understands of the story has to like flip right midpoint turn and then I'd say you really want your climax around the 85 90% Mark that's what I've noticed that actually hits really good and it gives you time to resolve some stuff so you're not leaving people sitting there reading the last chapter like this and then the books done and they're like huh I feel like I need aftercare so like the last 10% 5 10% depending on how your story works should really be after care don't leave people hanging with a heart problem and anxiety like you should let him down hit him and then and then bring him down a little bit more gently um so there you go so now you have 50 chapters with like okay here's where the big plot stuff has to happen and what I want you to do is I want you to start filling in that I want my midpoint turn to be this I want my intro chapter to set the the world up and one of the characters maybe you wanna intro second character chapter 2 or chapter 3 like start instead of working out your magic system in that amount of detail start working out what's gonna be in your chapters and that amount of detail before you know it you might have an outline and once you have an outline you might feel secure enough to start really getting words on the page and it might start flowing out so this doesn't work for everyone you do have to be a planner for this to work but the way you're describing planning out your magic system and planning out your world details and planning out everything this might be the way for you and then once you feel comfortable the words might come so I don't know if it'll work for you it's just an idea give it a shot good luck buddy you can do this

Tiktoker and professional interpreter, Amalia  makes a really good point! a lot of what's seen as rudeness in New Yorkers  is actually consideration New York City is densely populated  despite close quarters New Yorkers wanna respect your personal space and, yes, smiling at or making eye contact with a stranger does break the bubble  of his personal space now Amalia also points out  what's a fairly typical scenario in New York when a traveler will ask subway patrons  if they know where such and such a stop is at which point New Yorkers will readily break their bubble to offer what assistance and directions they can As soon as that aid is rendered, however, the invisible wall goes back up and people revert to respecting each other's bubbles interestingly British author Ben Coates in his book, Why the Dutch are Different among many other factors he will point to population density in The Netherlands to account for both Dutch tolerance  for a pretty wide range of difference but also a brutal directness  that is often shocking to say a British or American visitor and the Dutch, of course  as the founders of New Amsterdam apparently still have  a profound influence on the city's personality

Right. Because they were both horrible warlords that committed war crimes and just went conquering city after city brutally during the war, until they both had something traumatic happened to them where they lost someone important to them, had to rethink their life and turn their entire lifestyle around. voice_to_text: tell me about your writing journey when I was a young boy I picked up a horror book I can't remember the name of it but a spirits uh drowned a child in a river so that the spirit could have a friend forever that book absolutely terrified me so from there was my darkest sentence to the Makaba into horror etcetera but it gets a bit deeper than that I then didn't write for quite a while I've always written stories when I was younger but I really seriously got into writing when I met a uh narcissistic psychopath I only met him once and again this is maybe a bit of an unfair opinion of him but I met him and he had such an impact on me made me so upset and angry with how this person treat me and spoke to me I wrote a murder mystery about um his demise and I invited loads of friends around and we did it and it was that good and I thought hang on I've actually got storyline here I've got loads of characters so I then wrote my first book I then wrote a few other books as well and then it gets even deeper I was then in I I I wrote here and there not really taking too serious not really marketing not really making a serious go of it and then in 2020 I met a lady who changed the course of my life and not in well initially not in a good way but actually now in quite a good way so when I first met this person it was like world winning romance like absolutely incredible you know oh my god this person's here like where's this person been all my life anyway seven months down the line and lots and lots of bad things happen with this person needless to say I didn't know what borderline personality was I didn't know what narcissistic personality was covert narcissism didn't know what gaslighting was anyway she absolutely coerced control all the rest of it absolutely destroyed me in many many ways so then following the end of that relationship I started diving deep into trauma into trauma bonding into personality disorders into addiction into cptsd PTSD etcetera and I also have a background in crime investigation so I decided I would start writing thrillers still with a little bit of a dark touching there because our background is horror and from there I was able to start writing my crime series my Detective Law Waterton series which has been by far the best the best books I've ever written and I'm currently about to release book 4 in the series 2 so as a result of something terrible I educated myself and I used what I already had to create the story and this first book is here and it's a best seller on Amazon and you can download it and you can read it for free on Kindle Unlimited so yeah start with a bit of childhood fails then meeting someone save your people and then someone who tried to destroy my life but also made it much much better it's funny how the adverse things in your life can turn into positives isn't it

of like why aren't you like that seems reasonable why can't you just do that and often the communities in which this kind of reaction in this hub of this happening is dominated by white women um but I be of service women should prioritize other people's needs above their own that's where you get the expectations of strangers wanting you to smile because the expectation is that women should be putting other people at ease and comforting others and being there for other people whether they know them or not whether they're co workers or friends that's just a thing you're supposed to do that's the whole caretaker role one thing that we don't talk enough about is how on being conditioned in that way you also internalize the expectation that other women are supposed to do that for you and that they should know and they should prioritize you because you're a woman and they're a woman and they should know how hard it is for you so they should definitely go the extra mouths so should you right what that actually is that is not women supporting women that's why that term has essentially become like misogynistic and its use that is women policing other women women women when they see other women not conforming to those expectations of women we behavior of being supportive of being there for you of doing going the extra mile especially for other women that is policing them because they're not being the right kind of woman and it may not be verbalised in that way like I said like that's how we get a lot of feminism being uh flipped around and used as misogynistic you know beating sticks to punish women for not being uh uh an ideal of women that doesn't exist and is is sexist often a way that it manifests is an inability to have healthy boundaries between the types of relationships that women have with each other and other people like that healthy boundary of I don't need to perform for a stranger cause I don't know them no right this is why um in even a professional like office settings you will find women struggle to like separate or have a healthy understanding of a boundary between a co worker or peer or a colleague and a friend I when I sit down and I think about it it is very rare when I am talking to a woman for her to ever refer to co workers as co workers rather than friends or enemies that is by design because if we don't have an ability to draw healthy boundaries then we aren't as exploitable right then people can't expect us to always serve them and to be nice and polite to them and to be pleasant and not to be rude and not to draw boundaries ourselves and tell them to stop doing things that are absolutely unprofessional and inappropriate within any situation be it personal be it strangers be it even familial right that is how patriarchy and white supremacy break us down and make us incapable of being able to protect ourselves or support each other in a real meaningful way and that is the lifeblood of Mlms so much about how MLM's (Multi Level Marketing) work is about violating the boundaries between what is a friendship and a professional relationship like Hey Girl that whole thing is constructed on monetizing women's relationships by using their connections and their expectations of friendship and of performative women womanhood as a way to make money and to pray on each other if women don't have those types of friendships or relationships or didn't have the ability to cross lines between professional relationships distance acquaintance distant acquaintances or different you know distant familiar relationships in order to exploit those relationships to monetize them MLM’s wouldn't work the way they do and sadly that's a big part of how like a lot of social media works too because so much of how it is been marketed especially using as a marketing tool is to break down that that barrier between the person on the screen and the person watching the screen and to create an artificial sense of an a more intimate relationship than what actually exists no I'm not saying everybody on social media is fake what I'm saying is that so much about how all of this is presented and definitely used as a marketing tool is to cross that line and to assume that there is nothing beyond this that I am giving you the 100% me and this is part of how and it's part of why we struggle to understand that there is a boundary between a performer like an actor or celebrity and their personal life and that they get to have a life that isn't something that we're part of and that we don't need to know everything about and that that is what a boundary is like I don't need to know that whatever celebrity is pregnant or having a baby oh it's interesting if they wanna share that fine but I don't need to know what they look like when they go to get their Dunkin Donuts I don't need to know eh I don't need to know about their sexual proclivities I don't need to know that about YouTube personalities I don't need to know these things I don't need to know that about my coworkers I don't need to know those things but again because women are taught to not have boundaries around those things there it is a difficulty within these professional interactions and relationships to not see the professional's personal and by connecting our livelihoods to that interaction it is much easier to see something that is just a professional thing that you do that it is you know just seeing something like not liking your book isn't saying you're a bad person I am not personally 100% the person who was stomping video_description: #stitch with @JoshReadsBooks📚 I'm just an anxious reader I guess #booktok #reading
voice_to_text: I also probably prefer the Kindle and I'm a little bit conflicted about and it's for the same reasons that Josh gives in his video but I have another reason that I do prefer reading  from an e reader as opposed to a physical book and it has a lot to do  with the physicality of the book  and so the problem I have is that when I'm in this part of the book the very beginning  I see all the rest of it and I feel like I have a lot of work to go and that I'm just treading water yeah it's a very strange thing that I I feel like I need the see like pages actually turning um and that the amount of story left is somehow um a detriment to my reading um but it does result in some level of anxiety that that I'm just not I'm not getting anywhere in this book and it doesn't help that I am actually a pretty slow reader um I do the close reading first I I don't know how people can just speed read uh through anything but then there is uh the reverse where I get to this portion of the book and I am then filled with anxiety of how it is going to end how it is going to wrap up in however many pages and that I I almost feel like a Marathon runner with the finish line in insight but I am exhausted and it's just not coming quickly but it's also coming too quickly in the cases of stories where I'm really engaged with it and wondering how everything's gonna actually get resolved in the amount of physical pages that I have by the way Dune is a really good example of this because uh the final chapter of this book is it's so weird to have like a long such a long chapter that also feels so incredibly rushed yeah that's just a side uh little Tangent but yeah and then it just ends very abruptly so this was really bad uh for this kind of anxiety that I had about the ending of book and the reason why I prefer Kindles is that I don't really have that anxiety I'll see that like oh there's 10% of the book left but that doesn't really mean much it's signaling that things are going to be wrapping up soon but it doesn't correspond to like a number of clicks you know I can't but I could but I'm not about to click through and see how many times I have to click my Kindle to see till I get to the end of the chapter I just wanna do that for fear of losing my place um I just feel like I am able to read at a much more even pace uh without any expectations of where I am in the book itself um this might just be a thing that is is weird to myself but  I encounter it with pretty much every physical book that I intend to read from beginning to end

voice_to_text: hi prospective self published indie author here and I cosign that message because while early reviews can powerfully impact overall sales and even though ARC reviews can be a powerful part of an overall marketing strategy I'm gonna hold of all of our hands real quick and say something yes writing a book is very hard self and independently publishing a book and then trying to market that book that we wrote and put out by ourselves is also hard uh but none of that means we are automatically entitled to positive early reviews or the sales that can result from them it's your job to strategically select early reviewers that are part of your target audience with the knowledge that there's always a chance that anyone could take issue with whatever you create for whatever reason that's show business babe but if your target audience has something critical to say about what you've created a negative review isn't the issue but it's possible that what you made might be

#stitch with @Freedom Matthews | Author🏹🍂✨ This is my writing story from start to finish.  #writer #writertok #writersoftiktok #booktok #writing #writingcommunity #writingcommunityoftiktok #fyp #authorsoftiktok #author #writerslife #indieauthor #indieauthorsoftiktok #JenniferDrewett #writingstory #writingjourney #storytime
voice_to_text: Tell me about your writing journey. I guess I should start from the beginning cause this is actually a shockingly long story. Bear with me. I should preface this by saying that writing runs in my family. My great grandmother so my mum's maternal grandmother she wrote like poetry and stuff I think. And then my mum herself she's a published poet in her own right. She has… how many poetry collections? She's up like six or seven poetry collections out now and also she published a young adult novel called ‘Dart’ which is basically about Dartmoor during the Black Death which is actually really fascinating and not gonna lie. I'm not just saying that. She's my mum. I'm just saying if you see ‘Dart’ by Deborah Harvey you should pick it up. It wasn't necessarily guaranteed that I would turn to writing especially as when you consider what I've just said. You could have said “Oh! That's gonna skip generations maybe the next generations of your family will be writers” but no that's not what happened which is you know interesting. I better start from the beginning of my writing journey then. So my journey starts when I'm 7 I was in year three at primary school and we had been given a creative writing homework. It was essentially just to write a story of a certain I think of a certain word count but I'm not 100% sure on that. The most people told us I'd have a clear beginning, a clear middle, and a clear end. Alright! That works for a 7 year old. I did it. I don't remember too much about what actually happens in the story. In fact I don't remember at all. All I remember is that I'm pretty sure dragon was in it and there was some princesses who weren't like damsels in distress cause clearly I had some feminist energy in me when I was 7. Ha ha! I hand it in. I don't think too much of it until my teacher turned around and said that she'd liked it and she thought I could do this more often. I was like “What” and then I was like “Okay” cause I had enjoyed the process. I had actually enjoyed writing the story even at that age even though it was homework which I didn't like doing too much. So yeah it was really fascinating From there we jump till I was about 11. Now I'm moved on from writing short stories to plays. At this point I was in year six at primary school at this point and we were doing like I think it was towards the end of the year or maybe the middle of the year? I can't remember but we were doing a play and like a big play and there were the play was in segments. So each sort of group of between years three to six had had their own little segment and it would have like a theme and all that stuff. I thought that ours sucked. I'll be honest and that was unusual of me cause I was thought that would sort of just go with it and all the rest of it but I somehow developed the notion of “Oh I should tell my head head teacher this.” So I did and shockingly to me, even to this day, she let me rewrite our entire segment and used it in the play! She let the 11 year old rewrite the play! How weird is that? But yes, we move on from primary school to secondary school and that was a terrible time in my life. Namely because I was bullied for just like everything from the jump and I mean everything. I'm not gonna go into all the details right now but cause that's it that's a story in of itself. So yeah I ended up being very lonely and quite isolated at points and it was a real struggle. I'll be honest. So one of my main comforts was writing. I loved to write little stories but mostly plays and mostly dramas and it was it was a lot of fun for me. To the extent that I didn't wanna do my homework. Sorry Mum. Sorry Dad. Ha ha ha! I then ended up moving on to film scripts when I was about 16/ 17 because I started studying film studies at A-level which I really enjoyed for the most part cause I think film and TV and all the rest… all those mediums can be so transformative when they're good and they can really speak to people. They can change people's lives and I think for the better sometimes. Not always but most of the time it's for the better. I think I then continue… yeah… I continue doing that for quite a long time even when I dropped out of film school at university twice which is so embarrassing. Yeah I dropped out of university twice from university that I don't think even exist anymore. So make a fact what you will and then in my 20s I wrote but not a huge amount purely because I was going through a lot in my early 20s on top of everything I went through like with school and everything else and then I spent a lot of my 20s trying to process that stuff so that I can actually live a productive life and I… so that I could get through without all the trauma being constantly on my brain. Then I got to about 30/31 and I thought to myself: “You know, no one's ever gonna see these films I'm writing and this is just really depressing. What the hell am I going to do?” And then it occurred to me “Wait a minute. What if I turned it into a book? And then maybe people would actually like read it and then maybe someone, if it got really popular somehow, it would turn into a film on its own. Great!” So now we're here. I'm 34 I have one book out there called ‘To Love At Comic Con.’ I am working on the developmental edit for ‘New Leaves, Old Scars’ which I'm hoping will be out towards the end of October and I'm on the first draft of the book after that which has a character in it that I've been trying to develop since I was 15. This has been with me for nearly 20 years! So yeah that's my writing story or more specifically: How did Jenn become a writer? If you enjoyed that then you should stick around. Maybe follow me a little bit because I do enjoy doing these little sort of you know story time videos. They are quite fun.

voice_to_text: If you only read the books on your physical TBR, how long could you go without having to buy a new book? It's enough books for my lifetime. Your lifetime? And like seven other people's lifetimes. I have about 16 books in my house I haven't read yet. To the point that my husband knows what people to call when I die. Cause they know what to do with these books. They're gonna come by and put sticky notes on this. One goes this person. This one goes this person. Cause I know goddamn well I will never finish the books I have in my house. And that is if I never buy another book. Not one. This is the pain I live with daily.

voice_to_text: Now, I'm breaking up this response into two different sections. The first is the first book I ever wrote, the second is the first book I ever wrote with true intention of being published. Neither of which are published. The first one, I was about 15 when I wrote it, and I first wrote it handwriting and then I typed it on a manual huge Smith Corona tech writer with the ribbon and everything. It was a fantasy romance, and I suppose in today's standards it would probably be like YA cause I was YA. It also had a very distinct Christian fantasy undertone because I was raised in the church and so that's what I was doing. It was called Calpernia. I had ideas for future books. it was about a stolen kingdom and an unknown princess and the power to be to fulfill her destiny. It will never be published because I just don't think that way anymore and and I don't write fantasy. I was very into fantasy when I was a kid, and I just haven't had that pull since I'm in it, that's all. The second is called,  currently called Grey Clouds and this is the book that I wrote with the intention of hopefully being published with it. And this is the book that got me an agent, and this is the book that almost had a movie deal, and this is a book that I think is absolutely horrible. So, you know it was a contemporary romance. It’s  it's not a terrible idea and I may try to rehash the story eventually, but it's not on my radar anytime soon. Like, I wouldn't I wouldn't try to redo anything; I would just start fresh and and go from there. But that was the first one that I wrote with the idea of potentially being published with it. And again, never got that far. Supposedly — according to my agent — supposedly almost had a movie deal, I don't know. I fired the agent, so take that as well. Anyway, that's my story.

voice_to_text: I am 90% a chronological order writer and I have to be a friend recently asked me this question cause I was talking about this exciting battle that's coming up I'm like oh man as soon as I get there I'm gonna be writing so much faster he's like why don't you just write that now and for me the way that I write I'm I'm right halfway between a plotter and a pantser I've got my outline I know the general beats but so much of the discovery of the characters and their backstories their feelings their thoughts the themes in the way that I wanna present them the resonances of different story elements and different moments that that come back and rhyme in later parts of the story that gets discovered in between all of these like the really exciting stuff and so as much as I wanna like Skip Ahead I know that I'm going to be discovering things about my characters before I get to that point that's going to inform the way that I write the really exciting thing even though I know mostly what's gonna happen there like these character moments these these affectations these these bits about these characters that really give them their depth are gonna I'm gonna figure them out and then I'm gonna get to display them once I get to those exciting scenes so for me I I can't skip around I I sometimes envy the people who can who can like jump ahead to like the middle of the book and just like write this whole section but there's too much connective tissue that I lose if I if I do it that way

voice_to_text: Don't worry I am not here to convince anyone to like Dune. I have my own problems with it. I do like it overall as a story, but she mentioned specifically stylistic issues and I would agree with that. There are number of stylistic issues in the book That said... as someone who has contributed to a peer-reviewed book of essays on Dune scholarly essays I do feel the need to defend myself just a little bit. Here's the thing I it's totally fine I'm not here to yuck anyone's yum or yum anyone's yuck, but I do think that there's a tendency in academia to kind of needle at something and say here's why this thing is wrong, here's why I don't like it, here's why it's bad even. And I'm not saying that she did all of those things, she just said why she liked it and that's fine there's a long standing academic tradition of kind of these literary takedowns of works, ideas, authors, whatever it might be what I like to see just personally is when someone can go and look at something and say you know that really wasn't for me I really didn't like it and I do think there's some problems with it let me take a look at it anyway to kind of see why other people seem to react to it why other people seem to engage with it and why other people seem to draw some sort of meaning from it because whether you like it or not Dune has had a cultural impact on us in many ways and has have many other works so that's just for me personally I would challenge anyone who kind of looks at a book or looks at something that they don't like to really kind of dig into why other people do like it or what value other people see in it and I think a lot of times you might find that people will often acknowledge some of the flaws in there but say yeah you know but I liked it anyway and here's why I liked it and maybe you can just pick up some thoughts on why that is I totally get if people are coming at you yelling at you like you don't understand you don't this and that that's a turn off and nobody wants to hear that also the assumption of people who look like me that you just didn't understand it because you didn't like it um is rampant out there I've experienced it even myself as a as a fellow white male so I definitely will say that I I understand why that might turn you off as well all that to say just I think when you're kind of talking about something academically it's it's much better to kind of approach it from a let's investigate what's really going on here and uh where in its badness consists of steal a phrase from Dr. Corey Olsen and and really look at what the root of you know what it could be what it's trying to say and why there are people who associate with something and then you know kind of take it from there

voice_to_text: how long are you making those chapters I typically shoot for around 3,000 words now this isn't a hard and fast rule I have had chapters in the past that have been as little as 2,000 words and I've had chapters that have been close to 5,000 words however that is kind of my target I guess you could say once I start getting close to 3,000 words that's when I start looking for a good breaking point for my chapter where I can transition and wrap things up to then go into a new chapter but it really does depend it also depends on the genre fantasy tends to um lend itself to longer chapters than it then contemporary romance which is what I write so I'm not quite sure how much 10 pages is um because I don't write that way I go by word count versus page count but uh hopefully this helps

voice_to_text: You might get what I bet. Little girl with pink hair probably had a babysitter. 1965 here. I didn't have a babysitter after about second grade. I guess my mom's like, I screw it. I can't afford a babysitter. They. They all right. Had an old brother, but he was feral, too. So we just ran around and did what we wanna do. We didn't have to drink from the hose, per se, because we were home alone and we could stay home all we wanted to. So we could drink from the hose if we were outside, didn't want to come in. But pretty much we stayed at home alone and watched all my children. One life to live. And if we didn't really wanna watch your hospital, we would ride, like, our bicycles, like, five miles. I'm literally five miles to the city swimming pool to swim. After the second grade, I remember I've always been a library nerd. Draw my book, talk friends, you know? This was, um, so 1972, 73, 74, somewhere like that. I walked to the library, and it was a good walk, and it was a walk through town on busy streets. I was just finished the second grade, and I walked all the way across town to the library. That's your Gen X kids. That's what we did. We were feral. We did what we wanted to. We ran the neighborhood. We watch soap operas. We went swimming after. We rode our Bikes to swimming pool. If we wanted to go. My mom was at work. We rode our bikes. That's Gen X. That's why we're so cool. You think I would have let my kids do that? No way. That's why they're not as cool as we are.

voice_to_text: So of course you know, I have to use my book series as an example to answer this question So of course, starting from the top, you see Louise, then Trina, Sarai, and Rachelle Now of course if you read my books, you are already introduced to Rachelle, Sarai, and Louise in the first book But Trina, who's in orange on this cover, she's introduced in book 2. So, of course with Rachelle's situation in the first book, she had low self-esteem, because she had gotten out of a very toxic and emotionally @busive relationship with her ex  so she had to regain her self confidence, and through that she learned to embrace her sensuality, because one of the things she had to constantly deal with was slût shaming because she was a pinup model and she did boudoir modeling so she was shamed for that But when she meets her new love interest, who is a photographer, he gave her the courage to step outside of her comfort zone, and she started doing full n00d shoots So she fully embraced her sensuality and her sexuality, in a society that shames you for doing that, and I think that's a true show of strength Now with Sarai, Rachelle's best friend, her struggle in the first book was the fact that she was the "black sheep" of her family She was goth, she listened to heavy metal she was a horror enthusiast, she was an aspiring horror author, she was bisexual, and her family, aside from her father, looked down on her for that because they were a conservative Baptist family Like the only person in that family who truly accepted her was her father But when she got deeper into her spiritual practice, and discovered the powers she didn't know that she had, it gave her the courage and the confidence to embrace who she was unapologetically And when you get to the climatic scene later in the book where she stands up to her @busive relatives, she's not afraid to say that she's a Witch She's no longer afraid to say that because it's part of who she is, and she was no longer going to be ashamed of that, and that is it takes a really strong person to do that In a society that wants to put you in the box that that wants to tell you who you should be to unapologetically just say "This is who I am", it takes a really strong person to do that Now when we introduce Louise, she's already a strong character She comes from several generations of magical practitioners and root workers and she's kind of a mentor to the other characters, because it's through her and her family that Rachelle and Sarai learn how to hone their abilities But it's mentioned in the second book she wasn't always like that Her powers didn't show until her late teens, and she dealt with intense bullying throughout her adolescence So she wasn't always powerful She had to unlock that power And I truly believe her power comes from not just her supernatural abilities, but the fact that she's able to help empower other people I feel that's where her true strength comes from So then we have Trina, who's introduced in Book 2 Trina is a transgender woman, and when she's first introduced she's in a dangerous situation where if Louise had not intervened, Trina would have been unalived Trina was living on the streets, because her egg donor kicked her out and disowned her, because she refused to accept Trina So Louise and her family opened their home to her and you know they let her stay at their house She's immediately welcomed into the friend group with open arms They love and accept her for who she is She even goes to an anime convention with them and they got her to cosplay with them And Trina is an aspiring fashion model and through Louise and their friends' support, Trina is able to achieve that goal She's able to achieve her goal of being a fashion model And when she encounters her egg donor later in the book, she gets the strength and the courage to stand up to her And not only does she stand up to her and tell her about herself, she also cuts her off she disowns her in the end And I will say this: I have nothing but love and admiration for the trans community because it takes true courage and strength in this society to live your truth in a society that wants them to not exist it takes true courage to just be who you are in a society that hates you so hopefully that answers that question And for those that are interested and wanna know where they can get the books, you can go to my linktr.ee which is in my bio I have physical copies on Etsy I have a limited amount but if you get them through my Etsy shop I will personally autograph them you can also get the books on Amazon you can also get them directly from my publishers website which is also on my linktr.ee

voice_to_text: What is the best way to do audiobooks? Do you use your apple books or do you use audibles? In my opinion, there's not a quick and easy answer to this because it depends on several things. Where you live, how often you listen to audiobooks, what kind of audiobooks you wanna listen to, and how much you wanna spend. The cheapest way, if you live within the United States, is to get a library card and borrow audiobooks through Libby and hoopla. The downside of this is sometimes there are a lot of long waits, especially if it's a newer release book. And it's gonna be harder to find a lot of indie authors this way because a lot of them will choose to go audible exclusive. So you will not be able to get these through your library. And because of that, I think an audible subscription is really valuable for a lot of people. You can pay the lowest tier just to have the audible plus catalogue. That's not gonna be every audiobook, but that's going to be a lot of them. And you had unlimited listens and you're just borrowing through audible. But that's like $8 a month. If you want to add a credit onto that, which is probably their most popular plan, it's gonna be about $15 a month. You have access to that audible plus catalog, plus you get one credit a month that you can use to purchase any audiobook that you want. And you keep that forever. If you like to read e books as well, Kindle Unlimited is an excellent option because you pay the monthly subscription for that. But then you can borrow ebooks and get a discount on the audio. Sometimes there are sales going on with those. You can get them as cheap as $2 or up to about seven dollars and fifty cents. They also have their own catalog of read and listen for free. So these are audiobooks that are just included with your Kindle Unlimited subscription? But I do the borrow the ebook and then buy the audio for a discounted price a lot. There are many more subscription services, but you can also just buy the audiobooks outright. Many authors will sell them directly through their websites, or you can go through a website like chirp to purchase without any subscription at all. If you have any other questions, let me know. If I don't know the answer, I will definitely help you find it.

Oh, my god. I don't ever do anything like this, ever. I hate this kind of stuff. But when I see videos like this, it's really hard to stay quiet. As a mother, I get being child free by choice, and I love that for you, that is your choice. That's amazing. Like, live your damn life. Perfect. What I don't love is the mom shaming and the baby shaming that is this video. Like, how do you. I'm, like, at a loss for words, honestly, because this video just confirmed my worst nightmare. Okay? Like, babies throwing tantrums is going. It's gonna happen. Okay? They're little humans trying to learn these big feelings that they're feeling all of a sudden. And as a parent, the high anxiety parent at that, thankfully, thank the Lord. My son is so great in public 99% of the time, but that 1% that he is not. My anxiety is already up here, and I feel bad. I feel awful. I feel like I'm failing as a mom and that everyone is annoyed around me, but I'm also trying to give my kid Grace at the same time, and I'm worried that this exact thing is happening, but to my kid. I know that's not my kid in that video, but I feel so bad for not only that mother, but that baby that you chose to make a video about and post it for the world to see. That mom was already having A hard time? And imagine if she's scrolling through her TikTok page and sees that you're calling her baby a nightmare when she's already having a hard time. Not only that, but you don't have all of the facts. That kid could be on the spectrum, and that's okay. But not only that, but you're at an aquarium. Okay, an aquarium which is baby friendly. If you don't like kids, that is fine. That is your prerogative. But don't go to places that are baby friendly and then make videos like this. And mom shame and just all around. Like, what were you thinking? I just wanna know, like, what did you get out of posting this video other than confirming mine? And I'm sure whoever else, if their parent sees this video, you're confirming their worst nightmare. So I hope that's worth the laugh for you. I just. This is not my normal content. voice_to_text: if you only read the books on your physical TBR how long could you go without having to buy a new book okay so I have 132 books on my physical TBR um though that does not include certain books that I have duplicates of uh that I didn't really check cause I have like two versions of The Wheel of time um the first book and the seventh book um and I have a couple others like that like I have book called Destiny Falling that I was gifted two versions of um so if we're not including those it's probably closer to like 1:25 um that being said most of these are fantasy so what I normally would read in a month is about 20 to 25 books so be but because I'm doing mostly fantasy books in this I'm gonna say it's gonna drop down to 15 to 20 books so if we're doing 15 books a month it's going to be uh just under eight and a half months if we're saying I can do that 20 books a month and that I have the time to do it uh then we're going to be looking at just over six months so to be honest I think I could be doing like a lot a lot worse the problem with that though is that this is not gonna be at all accurate because I am a super heavy mood reader so even if I sat down I was like I'm gonna go through every single one of these books I can't I will be sitting there and I will be reading one book and then I'll go you know this is just not doing it for me I need a new book I need a book that is in the vibe that I want so in all reality a lot longer a lot longer probably two years because of me being a mood reader if we're talking about the actual reading speed that I have no problem 6 to 8 months easy but because I'm a mood reader two years minimum

voice_to_text: pardon the fact that I look a mess I'm still in my jammies I just woke up I haven't even had my coffee yet but I just had to say something to this because I've seen people get up in arms about anybody who loves their books in a way that "damages" them I have books with broken spines I have books with tape on them I have books that are practically falling apart I have books that are written in a lot of my books came this way because I buy books second hand some of my books are that way because I read them so much I'm not gonna tell you which ones are which I'm just gonna tell you that I have books that are well loved not destroyed well loved because there's two types of book readers and both of them have books that are well loved well...loved there are people with books that are well loved and then there are the people who treat their books like their grandmother's fine China set and put them on the wall and treat them like they're not supposed to ever look like anything other than they were just printed yesterday both are valid and don't let anybody tell you otherwise but especially don't let the people who treat their books like their grandmother's fine China set tell you that if your books look like this that you're destroying them you're not destroying them your books are well loved I know it you know it there's nothing wrong with enjoying your books your way let your books have broken spines dog-ear your pages take notes highlight your favorite parts love your books your way and don't let anybody tell you you're destroying your books just because your books are well loved toodles

video_description: #stitch with @Girl On Couch Forbidden lovers mixed with romantic suspense. Avail. on Kindle and in Paperback on Amazon. BLURB: All Ellie Merkowitz has ever known is living a sheltered upbringing. But that’s her normal life as a subservient, Orthodox Jewish woman. Her future is already laid out. Ellie will marry, have many children, and be giving to her husband and family. That is, until everything changes with one dream, and an unexpected trip in the middle of the night to meet the boy next door. Now, Ellie wants more out of her life. But as a recent high school graduate, she must first escape her narcissistic father. And more than anything, she needs answers about her troubled past and the dreams that have been haunting her for years.   Falling in love with his neighbor was never the plan for David Cohen—neither was helping her escape the night terrors that haunt her dreams. But he had no choice. After all, the girl in the red wig was never supposed to keep showing up in the middle of the night. But Ellie’s dreams had other intentions. video_description: #stitch with @Kole Lyndon Lee I love Neil. What's your draft process? #booktok #authortok #writersoftiktok #writingtips #neilgaiman
voice_to_text: it's always reassuring when famous authors talk about their process and it's at least close to what I'm doing when I'm writing so Neil goes on to talk about Neil because we're on a first name basis of course goes on to talk about how his first draft is really just him kind of throwing stuff out to see what sticks to see if anything comes out even remotely close to good and then he goes back through and starts to refine and add and take away to make whatever looked okay that much better and is actually very similar to the advice that Stephen King gives in his book "On Writing" which is appropriately his advice on how to write a book so I have tried to follow that loosely in my writing journey where my first drafts are a little bit of word vomit sometimes I just go go go I try not to get too hung up I try not to edit as I go just gotta get the words out there first and then I go back through do a quick clean edit to fix grammar and spelling and stuff and then I let other people read it as well as I'm rereading it to see what they liked what they didn't like what worked what doesn't what's too long what's too short and then with all that feedback and having a fresh view after having stepped away for a little bit then I can go back in and I can start to refine so for example Mattson Academy the first book that I've ever published I ended up making a lot of changes so just for some numbers perspective the first draft was 112,000 words the second draft was 136,000 words and the published version is under 100,000 words so it got much bigger I added a whole lot of things that I thought were really cool I really fleshed out a lot and tried to embiggen the world and add more time for characters that I really enjoyed and then I realized that that was just way too much and I had to really chop it down and get it to a point that it was marketable for lack of a better word so we ended up cutting out four or five whole chapters and certainly shrinking a whole bunch of them the original first chapter is actually up on my website just I mean I saved it I didn't get rid of anything why would you ever get rid of anything in a digital world I have everything saved and backed up and all that stuff so the first chapter is certainly there on my website anybody wants to read it uh this uh there's also a chapter one of my favorite chapters I didn't put it on my website after I cut it but what I did do was I ended up repurposing it and using it in book two albeit in a very different format but the idea and kind of the bones of that chapter are still there in book two so never any reason to throw anything away but it's true it just characters got shuffled around characters got added characters got cut as just you know the first draft really is just kind of getting the idea out in its roughest form it is first draft is just another way of saying rough draft right you just got to get it out there first it's really hard to edit it all up in your head although god knows I try I don't have nearly as many notes as I should but first draft rough second draft refining and then it's those later drafts where you're cleaning it up even more making sure everything flows making sure everything fits exactly the way that it should so that it's nice and clean and perfect so that hopefully you can get it out there either self publishing or get it in the hands of a publisher whatever works for you and that's just the way that I do it and I'd love to hear how other authors do it too uh cause it's always reassuring to know that you're not alone so thanks for listening to the ramble

video_description: #stitch with @Samuel Foree  ❓Got any recs for books that make you laugh, cry, and fist bump on repeat? After The Shut Up Ring By Cate C Wells @Cate C Wells  Romance: Single Mom, Friends to Lovers, Hurt/ Comfort, Finding Yourself Again Coming Soon (Friday, May 24, 2024) Thoughts💡 I absolutely loved this book and finished it in just a few hours. I’m always a fan of Cate’s work especially when she tries something new and brave. Blurb📖 shut up ring (noun) 💍 a marriage proposal meant to get you off his back, intended to last indefinitely. I waited eight years to marry the father of my children. I worked at our relationship. I was patient. I forgave—the thoughtless remarks, the disappointments, the test results when I was expecting our youngest that proved he hadn’t been “working late.” Then, when we finally made it to the altar, he looked deep into my eyes, smiled, and cracked a fat joke. That wasn’t the worst of it. His vows weren’t a promise to love. They were a final test of exactly what I’d do to get his ring on my finger—what I’d take—in front of family, friends, and their cell phones. Was I going to be internet famous? Another sad bride who must’ve known the kind of man she was marrying? My two little girls stared up at me with big, round eyes. Was I really going to laugh it off like I always did? In that moment, my house of cards came crashing down. When the moment was over, for some reason, my best friend’s older brother was on his feet with his chair knocked over like he was about to punch someone. This is the story of what happened next. Please check the author’s note for specific content warnings. Standalone. No cheating. HEA guaranteed. Quote💬 “How do I make you feel?” I ask, feeling like I’m at the edge of a high ledge with my “toes are curled over the edge. “Like I’ve got reasons,” he says. “For what?” His lips curve ever so slightly. “Everything.” 🏷️  ##bestfriendsbrother##bestfriendsbrothertrope##bestfriendsbrotherromance##bluecollarmen##hurtcomfort##angstybooks##angstyromance##romancebooks##booktok##smuttok##steamytok##spicytok##steamybookrecs##spicybookrecs##spicybooktok##booktokfyp##kindleromance##kindleromancebooks##kindlespicybooks##catecwells

voice_to_text: personally not a huge fan of the full recap chapter just to recap what was said in the stitch recap chapters are a thing at the beginning of books in the series where characters are kind of reflecting or talking about things that happened in the last book in order for the readers to get a refresher on what happened and they're saying that a lot of people probably wouldn't like this they don't really like this because when they're reading a series they're going through the entire series they don't need a refresher when it's waiting for the next book they reread the books from the series before this one so that they don't need a refresher love that not everyone likes rereading books so for some people it's really helpful which they also say but where do you kind of put the line are they good are they bad when do you wanna use them when do you not wanna use them here's my idea what if instead of having a chapter of the book we have like a prologue like a read Jesus I just said this word and I already forgot what the word is relapse is not the right word replay recap thank you um what if we have like a recap prologue that just basically summarize what's in the last book or the last couple books and then if you don't want the recap because you're reading it in the series and you don't need one you can just skip the prologue and you know you won't be missing anything important to this new book or anything important to the story because it's not a part of the new book it's not a part of the new story it is just a summary but if you're someone who doesn't like rereading me um and you're waiting for the next book to come out you might need that little refresher so then you can just read this really short refresher that's just telling you the basic bare bones summary of what happened in the last book then you don't need to reread if you do wanna reread then you don't have to read the prologue so that way people who don't want to sit through it don't have to because they're worried they're gonna miss something important in the first few chapters cause you will um probably and those who do want the recap will get the recap I don't really know books doing this but I feel like it could be implemented and I think it'd be really useful um so then everybody gets what they want slash need and honestly it sounds a lot better to get like a one page summary of what happened in the last book than have to sit through characters talking about things that we all know already happened but sometimes talking about them is like a good thing like it can be worked into stories really really well where they're reflecting and you actually wanna hear their mental stuff but sometimes it's just really obvious that they're just trying to give you a summary and in that case I'm like well uh I'd rather just read like a one paragraph summary than this back and forth that's saying the same thing that I read in the last book I don't know and it's just an idea but I think it could work pretty well

#stitch with @Kayla Charisse and sometimes I think I wanna do something but my brain is like no, I just outlined that next chapter perfectly. You must write. And suddenly I cant concentrate on anything else. #productivity #creative #hobbies #hobbytok #booktok  #writing #reading #fanfiction #contentcreator
voice_to_text: Question for my people who have multiple hobbies like gaming and writing and reading, watching TV, at this point, I've just given up, and I let the hobbies choose me. Sometimes also depends on what I'm doing that week or whether I'm busy or not. For example, I've been cat sitting at a friend's house all week, so I do not have my consoles with me. I do not have, like, all of my manga, manga books, whatever. I've also been pretty busy this week, so there will be no gaming, there will probably be no super productive or creative anything because I get home and I just wanna sleep. I did take a book with me. I have managed to read one chapter of that. So no gaming or creating for me this week, because I know I won't be able to do it simply because I don't have my stuff with me. Now. The rest of the time, I do catch myself being super overwhelmed and being like, okay, what? What do I wanna do? That I think I wanna write, but it's just not coming to me. I think I wanna sing, but it's not coming to me. I thought I was gonna read, but then I just stop after two pages because I'm not feeling it. And I catch myself scrolling my time away on TikTok. And at this point, I've just accepted that that's just the way it is. If I'm too overwhelmed to actually Do anything creative. Read, write, sing, content creation for TikTok. That. That means my head just isn't in the right space, and I really just don't want to. And if doing nothing is what I need, then doing nothing is what I will do. And the rest of the time, my hobby is just me. As in, I find a manhwa that's really interesting, and then I will hyperfixate on that, and I will not stop until I finished reading it. Or this book is particularly good, I will spend the next four days reading that and nothing else. And sometimes when I'm, like, really in the flow, or, as I say, my Muse comes back from vacation, and I really feel like, I must finish this chapter now, then that is what I'm gonna do. Next week, I hopefully will be on a long vacation. Hopefully, my creativity will come back to me. Like, I need to get my hands on Boulders Gate 3. I really want a romance Esterion. That's gonna take some time. And I will be binge watching Bridgeton the second I get home Monday evening. But, yeah, that's basically it. Let your hobbies choose. You do what you feel like doing most, and the second that you feel like you wanna do it. And if you don't scroll away the time on TikTok. Because of my force myself to do things, because I feel guilty that I'm not being productive enough, that I'm not being Creative enough. Then I don't wanna do it. Because you can't force me to do shit. Even I can't force myself to do shit. Let your hobby choose you. I'm pretty sure that was absolutely not helpful at all.

voice_to_text: so I love the question that's posed in this video because okay this is very creepy please just ignore it I'm in my parents house anyway she was saying she's a proponent of DNFing books and me too I've made plenty of videos where I'm like DNF the book don't stick with it but then she also brings up a question of like but aren't there times where you are like you feel an obligation almost to keep reading even if you're not vibing with it and if so what is that situation and for me what I've noticed this year specifically is that I am hesitant I'm more hesitant to DNF a book if it is an advanced reader copy that I have gotten through net galley or a publisher has sent to me and the only reason is because they gave me a free book and I feel like I should at least stick with it as long as I can before I'm like no I'm done but even then what I've noticed is especially because the only time that I really get to read physical books or ebooks is when I'm getting ready to go to bed and a big factor for me deciding whether that's interesting or not in that scenario is if it keeps me up or it makes me excited to get up the next morning to continue reading it and frankly a lot of books that I have gotten as arcs lately have not done that so most of the books that I have DNF this year have been arcs and I have felt really guilty about that I've stuck with them longer than what I probably would have in normal circumstances and that's been a pattern that I've noticed and have just kind of like had to deal with and so I thought that it was funny that that question came across my feed today specifically because I was just thinking about this last night when I was sitting down to read an arc and I was like ah do I wanna keep going with this but I feel like I should because pretty much every book I've DNF this year has been an arc but yeah would be curious if you uh if you DNF books have there been instances where like I don't know maybe I should just keep reading this for her she said she felt like if there was like an important message that was coming across which yes there's part of me that feels that way about books that are deemed like as important or have an important message I'm like should I keep reading this anyway but most of the time I just accept that there are so many books out there I will never had have enough time to read them all if I'm not vibing with it I'm out

voice_to_text: there's another layer to why that guy's tweet is completely wild and it's because public libraries actually buy quite a lot of copies of books right especially when a really popular book comes out let's say when Britney Spears book came out a lot of people wanted to read that I think we bought several hundred copies of that book in print and on top of that we paid for ebook licenses which are often like several hundred dollars for a certain set of time so we pay a lot for books and I'm - I work for what's considered a very large public library system but we're nowhere near the size of say like New York Public Library system I can't remember if they have 90 some branches someone will hopefully let me know in the comments but um it's routine for them to buy hundreds of copies of titles so you know by that guy dissing libraries he's also dissing a demographic that will buy hundreds of copies of your book if your book is really popular so that's something else ginger is also here to support that she loves libraries too

voice_to_text: the Black Dagger Brotherhood series I'm sorry, for those that don't know these are a still ongoing urban fantasy series about vampires and these books competed against all the other vampire romances from the early 00s let's take a moment to cry in millennial and elder Gen Z okay that was a moment and they are still going strong in the midst of the vampire renaissance that we are experiencing now this is not even the complete series there are at least 5-8 more, I don't know, one just came out a few weeks ago I am not usually a urban fantasy girlie but the way that J R Ward wrote just made sense to me okay her voice was so unique, the characters were so complex and she wrote ahead of her time the amount of disability rep sa awareness,  LGBTQ rep and so many other things, some of which she wasn't able to fully advocate for immediately and then got to say it with her chest in her later books, once the public opinion started to shift, is amazing and absolutely unmatched when you account for her mainstream success this one is blind, this one is too pretty, this one here was this one, this one, this one, this one deals with male sa this one he has EVERYTHING wrong with him okay  we love him but everything is wrong with this man this one deals with grief this one deals with grief this one here was the first book with an m/m pairing to hit the best seller list so you see what I mean  if this series at ended after the king it would have been wonderful it would have felt complete and that hurts me to say it because rage and Mary's storyline in the Beast is one of my absolute favorites, Butch and V's relationship alongside with their partners was so interesting to read and the last thing I thought would happen but I'm so glad it did because it made so much sense. alongside with this main series the author also started releasing these extra books and extra novellas following other characters and it added so much to the story it was wonderful and it took us to the feeling that the first books left us with which was a brilliant move on her part and even in the later books there were so many interesting characters introduced the problem was that that there was no follow through I stopped reading after the Jackal but everything after Dearest Evoe possibly even going as far as lover and *Unleashed* right here felt different it felt written by someone else more and more with each following book and I'm not alone in believing that anyway I will finish the series even if I end up regretting it because those books were my teenage years okay  the king was the first book that I ever read completely in English and I still reread all my favorites to this day once in a while they truly never get old least for me so I hope this lands me on that side of booktok because I definitely miss the fandom and I miss the humor
