voice_to_text: so y’all real quick while I let my eyes chill um this amazing writer amazing writer was kind enough to send me a copy of her book How to Marry Keanu Reeves in 90 Days and that was like two years ago and I started to read it about four times and I wanted to get into it but my family won't let me be great and sitting down and reading a book just doesn't happen and so just like two months ago less than that actually I needed to read something fun I needed to read something happy that had kindness and goodness because I realized that I read a whole lot of like nonfiction historical educational stuff especially about you know civil rights activism anti racism I read a lot of true crime and even my podcasts are along those lines I was I was kind of feeling overwhelmed with the current world and the so I tried to pick her book up again my family won't let me be great so I went to my library app (Libby) and said let me see if any of her books are available on audiobook and I happened to get Real Men Knit and the Black love story oh my goodness I needed that so much I needed that so much I did it was so good and sweet and rom-comy and I just oh my gosh and now I'm gonna look for the other ones and I'm gonna buy those through audible if they're available they better be and if not that something that should happen please check out her books check out her writing I am tickled and delighted

#stitch with @nik ★ cozy hobbies while I’ll always support buying from indies, ebooks and borrowing from the library is a great way to NOT accumulate physical copies that you then need to offload. Ebooks are great for this. I look at them as sort of a try before you buy because they are usually cheaper than the physical version. Because I don’t keep everything I read, this helps me basically weed out excess. If i do read a book I like enough to buy, I’ll just go buy the physical copy and add it to my library. If you don’t want to spend money, your local library is a banger, especially with the introduction of Libby. Even if your specific library is tiny (mine serves a town of 4k) it’ll likely be linked to a greater county or state borrowing system so you’re not limited to just what your tiny town’s library has on hand.  #booktok #sellingbooks #tradingbooks #donatingbooks #librarytiktok
voice_to_text: what are we doing with these after we finish them well if you don't want to accumulate a massive library and you actually want to offload these books there are number things that you can do with them Paperback Swap is a site I use fairly regularly although their interface hasn't been updated in like 10 15 years kinda clunky but it works well enough you post the books that you have people go through and request them you pay for shipping out and this is for us only and you use media mail so it's like literally the cheapest you can get and there's a cap on what you spend I think the most I've ever spent is like $4 and change you send it out they receive it they mark it received and you get a credit and then you can use that credit to request a book from someone else and if you request a used book from someone you it just cost you that credit and that's it so basically what you're paying is the cost of media mail shipping for that book or you can let the credits kind of accumulate and you can put them toward buying a brand new book through the site the more popular books and I saw you have a fair number of them in your piles those will go pretty quickly so you'll likely accumulate credits pretty fast there's also your local library most libraries to a use book sale every once in a while you can kind of dump them off on there or if you want to do kind of an exchange and a faster exchange than what you're gonna get on paperback swap if you have Arizona had Bookmans um Half Price Books is another one basically a used bookstore where you can sell them your used books and get either cash or store credit and basically just swap them out or if you're crafty and um don't mind actually destroying books you can use them for craft things like practicing book binding or or something like that the possibilities are endless

video_description: #stitch with @Lola 📚 yes, you can, but you should probably look at some other punk sub genres out there and see if any fit. And then make sure you have a clear understanding of why you’re using the punk categorization, so you can explain it to people. #punk #booktok #smcampbellauthor
voice_to_text: is it possible to create your own punk subgenre the short answer is yes because there are a ton of punk subgenres out there and they were created because things started not fitting into a neat category so a new one had to be made to more clearly fit the aesthetics and values punk is very much a marketing term that you can use as kind of a buzzword to create interest but you should decide exactly how you're going to define the punk parts of your book if you're talking about aesthetic values then you might wanna use more of it has a punk quality to it in the aesthetics I did a whole research paper on this on the difference between actual steampunk and Victorian futurism Victorian futurism is imagining a future or a world that is kind of advancing in its in its steam technology or the technology of its times to do similar things that we have today but not in the same ways true steampunk would be adhering to more punk values which is anti authoritarian themes social societal outcasts anti establishment and then putting it under the banner or the aesthetic look of the steam era so if you're going to create a punk subgenre for yourself or use one that exist you might wanna just make sure you're clarifying which parts of the punk are you using are you saying it has more of this kind of aesthetic look of this kind of punk sub genre or is it a punk book that upholds the punk values so it's like your book Buck Social Transdescent feature a lot of characters who are societal outcasts have a lot of anti establishment and anti authoritarian themes the whole punk genre has kinda gotten watered down to become more of just talking about the aesthetic values of things so you would describe cyberpunk and diesel punk and biopunk two things but that doesn't necessarily describe what the book is about or the themes that the punk movement was actually trying to progress

video_description: #stitch with @liz 🏛️ even silly paranormal books can have great lessons in them! ✨ #booktok #maximumride #vampireacademy #uglies #darkestpowers #yafantasy #yaparanormal #fyp
voice_to_text: this made me reflect on books from my own childhood and although a lot of them were paranormal or had kids with wings or like outwardly seemed like goofy middle grade young adult content that adults would just not think twice about they packed some powerful lessons and I can't talk about books from my childhood without mentioning Maximum Ride specifically in this case the Final Warning because although the earlier books talked a lot about how experimenting on people and animals without their consent can really cause a lot of harm like that's the basic you know their hybrids human animal hybrids like obvious lesson there but specifically in the final warning it really goes into environmental activism and showcasing how sometimes young people need to get kind of radical with their beliefs and what they do because adults don't care most of the time they're thinking all these problems I'll be dead before they're an issue so let's just pollute the planet and not care about global warming and it's not our issue but Maximum Ride was actually really digging into how toxic that is and potential ways to start counteracting that and how mobilizing can make a difference Vampire Academy was actually pretty pivotal for me regarding monarchies and powerful structures like that where tradition is so ingrained in things that anyone who challenges the tradition is a radical or can be like exiled from the society but Vampire Academy specifically the later books when Lissa is vying for the throne show that just because traditions have been done for generations doesn't mean they're good and doesn't mean we should keep them because they can actually be super harmful for the future and a lot of times have really really bad issues with classism and sexism ingrained in them the ugly series along with the giver really delved into how conforming to the status quo isn't always great especially if the government is taking advantage of the complacency of the people and have some dark secrets about yes the society functions but here's what the cost is for keeping it this way usually at the cost of art and culture and our own individuality the Darkest Powers in the Darkness Rising series delved into how gaslighting teenagers about their mental health conditions either making them seem worse than they are or just faking that they have issues at all granted this was because they had paranormal powers they were trying to mask but anyways gaslighting children or making them suppress their mental health issues is never good for anyone and never works out for the adults trying to conform or the adults trying to control them or for the children trying to chart their own path and figure out their own lives especially if there's a really bad secret the organizations are trying to hide that's why reading is so important even if it's books that seem on the outside like silly paranormal books or oh kids have wings and they're fighting these weird mutant creatures ah there's actually lessons to be learned and it's really important that kids can be allowed to read all these kinds of books

#stitch with @Cinema.Joe my fever dream movie is called STORYBOOK and it inspired me ironically to write a book #booktok #authorsoftiktok #writer
voice_to_text: What is your favorite dream movie? The movie that no one on this planet has seen except for you. It's movie called storybook, which I so randomly on TV one day. I feel like it was a lazy Sunday sometime in the 90s and then stuck in my brain for 20 something odd years. And I finally went on Reddit and basically was like, here are the details I remember from this movie. Can someone help find it? And I managed to identify it as this movie storybook because of that. And one of the things that is the detail that really stuck in my head for 20 years is that there was a scene basically where the kid, in order to pass some sort of obstacle, had to undergo basically multiple choice quiz of morality. So essentially he was trying to go through this cave and there was a giant rock he had to stand under. Well, the wizard asked him questions and if he gave the wrong answer or the bad answer, the rock would fall on his head and squish him. And the first question was something like, you find $100 on the ground, do you A. Pick it up and put it in your pocket? B. Look around to see who might have dropped it? C. Give it to the police or something along those lines. And the kid goes, I would pick it up. And the rock kind of above him rumbles as if it's Gonna fall on his head because it thinks it's gonna go put it in his pocket, and that's the wrong answer. And then the kid, quarter course corrects and goes. And I'd look around to see who dropped it, and good answer. Like, well done, kid, you pass. But even at 8 years old, I remember thinking there was a huge plot hole there, because how do I, as the viewer, how does the rock know that that is really what the kid would do? Would he really do that in a real life scenario where he didn't know? It was a testimony. Because we all know that the right answer is you don't keep the money that you found, moralistically, but how many of us actually would under pressurized circumstances? And that kind of stuck in my head as a plot hole for many years. And ultimately, this LED to me writing an entire book about this plot hole call the notorious virtues. And the concept of the book is basically people being tested to see if they are virtuous under circumstances where they don't know that they're being tested. So in this scenario, they would just find the hundred dollars, and the test would see what they do, rather than give them the choice where they know they're supposed to give a right answer. See what they would do in a real world scenario. And so, yeah, I feel by all accounts, is probably an awful movie. I Have not seen it since I was 8 years old, nor do I have any desire to. But it did inspire partly me to write 130,000 word book about this tiny plot hole I found in it. So, yeah. So, yeah, if anyone else has seen this movie, please give me a shout because I feel like I'm the only person on the planet who has.

voice_to_text: okay so that guy was talking about Taylor Swift and how according to him her lyrics just aren't as deep and analyzable as Kendrick Lamar's and the video I stitched is a gotcha that's like hey look how silly these Taylor lyrics look next to these images from children's books because children's books don't use language like Taylor uses language I do agree that he's wrong about Taylor but what annoyed me more as a children's library professional is the fact that he's also wrong about children's books like the implication that there's not just as much if not more effort and thought and intentionality put into writing a book for children then there is into your fave songs is ridiculous children don't know anything about anything until we tell them and these books are specifically designed to help them learn about concepts or process experiences that they've had while simultaneously teaching them the language and syntax that they need to communicate about those things in the future it's incredibly difficult and in the case of picture books specifically the words are working in tandem with the art like it's a very carefully thought out carefully balanced piece of literature and just because to you a grown adult it seems simple does not mean that there's not layers to analyze if you know what you're looking for but clearly you don't

voice_to_text: “I am overstimulated so” so I was rereading my copy of The Hobbit yes it's the movie cover but this is still the - the official text still the same damn thing but um turns out Bilbo did get over simulated and he had a full on meltdown in the very first chapter of The Hobbit ha ha ha ha okay so I should like I would like to read the excerpt to you so you know I'm not bullshitting you so this is Chapter 1 An Unexpected Party um my version is pages 16 and 17 um so this is after dinner this is after the song this is after Bilbo feels the magic and wanting to go and then regains his senses and thinks “I still need to get these stupid dwarves out of my house” and so we're finally getting to the point where Gandalf and Thorin are starting to explain what the heck is going on okay so I'm gonna start down here and it and this is gonna be very wordy I'm gonna warn you Tolkien's writing is very very wordy very common for the 30s 40s and 50s when everything was done on the radio and you have to use your imagination to actually understand the story half the time anyway “hush” said Gandalf “let Thorin speak” and this is how Thorn began “Gandalf dwarves and Mr Baggins” “we are met together in the house of our friend and fellow conspirator” “this most excellent and audacious hobbit” “may the hair on his toes never fall out” “All praise to his wine and ale” he paused for breath and for a polite remark from the hobbit but the compliments were quite lost on poor Bilbo Baggins he was wagging his mouth in protest at being called ‘audacious’ and worst of all ‘fellow conspirator’ ha ha ha but no noise came out he was so flummoxed ha ha ha so Thorin went on “we are meant to discuss our plans, our ways, means, policy, and devices” “we shall soon before the break of day” “start on our long journey” “a journey from which some of us or perhaps all of us” “except our friend and counselor the ingenious wizard Gandalf” “may never return it is a solemn moment” “our object I take it is well known to us all” “to the estimale Mister Baggins” (wait!) “to the *estimable* Mister Baggins” sorry “or and perhaps to one or two of the younger dwarves” “I think I should be right in naming Killi and Fili for instance” “the exact situation at the moment may require a little brief explanation” this was Thorn's style he was an *important* dwarf if he had been allowed he would have probably gone on like this until he was out of breath without telling anyone there anything that was not known already but he was rudely interrupted poor Bilbo could not bear it any longer at “may never return” he began to feel a little shriek coming up inside and very soon it burst out like the whistle of an engine coming out of the tunnel all the dwarves sprang up knocking over the table Gandalf struck a blue light at the end of his magical staff and in its firework glare the poor little Hobbit could be seen kneeling on the hearthrug shaking like a jelly that was melting then he fell flat on the floor and kept calling out “Struck by lightning!” “Struck by lightning!” over and over again and that was all they could get out of him for a *long time* so they took him and laid him out of the way on the drawing room sofa with a drink at his elbow and they went back to their business “Excitable little fellow” said Gandalf as they sat down again “gets funny weird fits” “but he is one of the best” “one of the best” “as fierce as a dragon in a pinch” it is in the text Bilbo had a meltdown he had a meltdown he was overstimulated he was terrified and he melted down in the text it's in the freaking text Bilbo's one of us Bilbo is a part of the Spoonie Community ha ha oh this makes me so happy like I'm I'm 33 now I am now old enough to be an an adult Hobbit okay not quite as old as Bilbo not quite as mature as him but ha ha the older I get the more like Bilbo I am becoming ha ha I have fun little adventures every once in a while but at the end of the day I am here in my Hobbit hole decompressing in front of the TV like Bilbo would do in front of his fire with a good old pipe of Old Toby ha ha ha ha yep Bilbo's turning into my spirit animal yep I love my Bilbo 🥰

voice_to_text: absolute fact pirates are actually a lot more orderly and meticulous when attacking a ship than we might think hello everyone my name is Doctor Rebecca Simon and I'm historian of the golden age of piracy and give Pat a follow his videos are brilliant and this one is just top tier he's comparing and contrasting how pirates are depicted in films versus real life in terms of how they attack a ship in films pirates are often like our our matey kill kill kill but in real life it was actually pretty orderly you wanted to get in and out as fast as you can because pirates wanted to survive they didn't want any members of their crew to get killed so what they would often do would be using some sort of scare tactics such as Samuel Bellamy who he and his crew would charge naked on the ships or Blackbeard putting fuses in his beard but the reality is they pirates wanted to talk to the other captain they wanted to look at the manifest they wanted to look at the logs they wanted to see what goods they had so that way they could take what they needed to replenish their own ship and also sell you can read more about these pirate tactics in my book Pirates Code Laws and Life Aboard Ship

video_description: #stitch with @jpatts_book_nook #booktok #booktokcommunity #booktoker #author #indieauthor #authorsoftiktok #howtowriteabook  @Claire 📚📖✍️⌨️ #booktok  @Elisa Greb ✍️📚
voice_to_text: so that was a question asked by uh book talk pal Jennifer couple days ago and what a question it is I mean wow how do you write a book there are volumes of books out there instructing you on how to write a book there is all kinds of media out there to help you uh in that chore um so yeah her question is you wide open um but there's been a couple of videos that have been posted since she asked that question I'm gonna tag them to this one that do a good um job of summarizing the entire process but what I wanna do is to focus on a specific area of Jennifer's question and that is how do you take the spark of an idea and decide whether or not it needs to be a book or not so I'm gonna start off with a quote and this quote is gonna maybe surprise a few people everybody I think if has heard part of this quote and the part being that everyone has a book in them and it sounds inspiring right well maybe not when you hear the full quote well that was like quote came from an American journalist by the name of Christopher Hitchens and the full quote is everyone has a book inside them which is exactly where it should I think in most cases remain so maybe the quote's not quite as inspiring as what people give it credit for anyway I think it's common for in in my opinion for writers and authors to have multiple ideas floating around in the back of their brains for books that they think that they wanna work on it's it's the process of this of picking out that idea the one that interest you the most and deciding whether or not to move forward with it um I've seen multiple videos here on TikTok of authors who are like 50% through 75% through of the first draft of a whip and an idea strikes them for another book and then they come on TikTok and say what do I do should I continue to work on this book and just jot down the idea for this book that I'm super excited for or should I jump onto this other idea and abandoned my other book put it in the back burner and jump onto this idea that I'm just hot to try on it's it's a conundrum and one that I'm not gonna answer here that's a whole other video to answer that question but it kinda leads into another question now myself I usually have several ideas for books um written down somewhere that have come across um my thought process and yo the question that Jennifer asked about how do you write a book it's it's taking those ideas would you mmm a lot of times are just flashes of inspiration that pops into your head they come in all kinds of different forms it could be that you think of a character that you wanna write about and then you gonna form a book around that character could be a specific plot device that you think about that you wanna develop um they can be all kinds of things now forgive my hesitation because I'm tryna keep my thoughts together as I go but fleshing out that idea however it comes to you and deciding whether or not it needs to be built can be done in a multiple multiple multitude of different ways myself I am a plotter which means if I get a spark of an idea for a book I have to plot it out before I decide whether or not to move forward with it and actually make it my next book I have to know that there's enough meat on those bones and actually I need to find out if there's enough bones to support the meat and that you know that just the flash of an idea is not enough to make the decision of my in my case there are other authors out there that get that flash of inspiration and they just run with it they run with their gut um they run with their um instinct and in most cases it serves them right um it doesn't work for me but you know doing that taking these ideas that you come across and deciding whether or not it needs to be a book that could be the make or break in your success rate as an author uh authors who pick inspirations and turn them in the books that nobody wants to read uh you know it's a bummer but it happens a lot of bad books that are out there are books that nobody wants to read I'm not gonna say they're bad books but a book that nobody wants to read you can't pull in readers to you know that's that was a bad investment in time for that author you need to be able to sift through these ideas that you have and pick the one that garners your attention that you can think through to say I will enjoy writing that I will enjoy fleshing that out and I think people will enjoy reading it as much as I enjoy writing it picking out that book from these ideas is the first step of process and then everything after that is just about how how you uh actually write what your idea is uh but to me it is a huge step and one that I think is overlooked a lot anyway that's my two cents for today it's Monday full week ahead of us we'll get through it uh everyone take care of one another out there and I'll be back again soon with some more content bye

it is so fast paced it remind me a bit of Dark Matter and Ready Player One the mystery part I felt like I was playing the game clue like was it Miss Scarlet in the library with revolver thank you Natalie really enjoyed the review and I love the comparison to clue um a game I played endlessly as a kid at school clue here one of the things that inspired me actually was The Murder of Roger Ackroyd by Andrew Christie I was reading it as I was plotting the book and I was sat there with a notebook determined that I was gonna be the one to actually solve this murder and of course I didn't and that really actually set me thinking how do you bury breadcrumbs um in the in the narrative the way that Christie did but also Christie set all of her murder mysteries in closed environments uh with no technology and it really struck me that when you have technology everywhere in the future watching you and tracking you and doing all these things actually having a murder mystery that isn't solved too easily it's gonna be doubly complicated and that's something I was really inspired to try and figure out how do you actually use technology to make solving a mystery harder not easier just a little postscript Natalie I remember that for the original book tour that we did last summer here in the UK we actually produced some little kudo cards as merchandise that we were sending around some of the reviewers and the idea was that people would get mainly settings and characters and then they kinda share what they have on social media gonna send you a little pack just to say thank you for your awesome video

video_description: #stitch with @Britt Marie Box | Writer I write chronologically when I write. I find this easier but I respect those who do it differently.  #writer #writertok #writersoftiktok #booktok #writing #writingcommunity #writingcommunityoftiktok #fyp #authorsoftiktok #author #writerslife #indieauthor #indieauthorsoftiktok #JenniferDrewett #chronologicalorder #adhd #autism
voice_to_text: Question for writers: do you write chronologically? You'll have to excuse me a little bit: It's 5:45 in the morning and I have not had enough sleep. So… Yay! Now I happen to write chronologically which means that obviously I start from the beginning and end at the end. I will however have ideas for stuff that comes up later. I try to write that down ahead of time and then once I hit those points then I use them if it's relevant. Obviously if the story takes me in other directions that might not be needed anymore or maybe it'll be later or earlier whatever but I try to write down the rough ideas ahead of time. This helps significantly because it helps shape the story a bit more without actually being too bitty about what I'm doing when. I do have ADHD and Autism so I do find the idea of working chaotically as it were by doing snippets here and there quite daunting and terrifying to be honest. I don't know I just like to have a very set order as to how I do things and it just logically makes sense to me to start from the beginning and end at the end but hey look each to their own. I think whatever works for you works for you so no hate no shade from here.

voice_to_text: um Hi. This is Eden your friendly neighborhood author um and I write books inspired by uh Jane Austen and Jane Austen is a brilliant author. She can make me feel and do a lot of things but you'll never make me hate Mrs Bennet. That's because Mrs. Bennet was just a girl. She was just a girl who is valued for her beauty and her good humor. And then she married a man. And then she didn't have sons. And he stopped valuing her. And then he got her daughters to stop valuing her. And then she started having issues with her "nerves." It is tragic. When you put it that way  and  she's that "figure of fun" when she's in the side of the story. If she was the center of a story she's Mrs Dalloway. um And yeah she didn't have a chance at real life and it's not fair. And speaking of people who deserve a chance at real life: this is Raghad. She is a 23 year old and supposed to be graduating like this month instead of running for her life and um fleeing the IOF and trying to stay alive with her family and crossing to Egypt. And um we can help her do that um this is her GoFundMe. um She's got a lot of family members including a lot of kids. Looking at the little little kids, the mom in my heart screams. I think of these kids especially,  in danger. How their mothers must feel. And you can see Raghad in her cap and gown. She said she was trying to to celebrate the graduation that she knew she wasn't gonna be able to have. All the people in this picture all the people trapped in a situation deserve a shot at a real life. And you can help them. I saw a creator -much bigger (following) than mine say to ask anyone to give a dollar. So if you have um less than $1,000 in your bank account (which is me 😅) give a dollar if you have more than that get five.  I think that's a great idea um I think you can think of it as giving a gift to all the mothers for Mother's Day. um Or giving a gift to Raghad for a graduation But a dollar, $5 and if  you can't give anything ---we get it it's hard times out here share, boost, like Thank you so much.

wizarding world kind of thing you know what I mean that I think a lot of us like muggles at this moment in time can really relate to the ideologies that LED to the creation of those did not end when Harry defeated Voldemort and they continued as Harry and Hermione and Ron and Ginny and Luna and Neville became adults and then inherited those systems what they chose to do with those systems moving forward we don't really know you know like that's the world of fanfic um but the last glimpse that we got of them they were the same systems and that's the cycle that we are going to find ourselves caught in if we don't look at those underlying ideologies and the ways in which they have been institutionalized and legitimized through our legislation through our education system through our law enforcement system and our criminal justice system through our media and our literature and our religions and our neighborhoods and communities and businesses right like they are embedded in all of these things and so in order to really stand a chance at never again actually being never again one of the things we are going to have to really really grapple with is the how and why of every single decision that we make as Americans because from the moment of our inception as a country blood was on our hands this country is built on the genocide and destruction of Turtle Island it is built on the enslavement of African peoples and we continue to reap the benefits of those horrific crimes against entire civilizations until we grapple with those very foundations on which this country has been founded we will continue to fund and support and legitimize things like the Zionist project

Here’s why I think we’re seeing a fair bit of this comparison.  ##fyp##foryoupage##xyzcba##booktok##scifi
voice_to_text: if you enjoyed Wrong Place Wrong Time or Dark Matter I've got the perfect book recommendation for you I had to stitch this on the weekend that Dark Matter came out because obviously the comparison  is incredible I love it thank you so much Francesca for your review  it was a few weeks ago now but I've saved it up for this moment there's a few things I think that link these two books No. 1 is obviously they're both techno thrillers and both the kind of techno thriller that somebody like Michael Crichton would have written I think we're both inspired by Crichton we both probably grew up reading him and secondly they're both books that are full of twists and turns and I very deliberately set out to write a book that was the kind of thing I wanted to read I love twisty books I love books that you just can't see exactly where it's going to end up dark matter was absolutely one of those for me I could not have predicted the ending and there's a 75% turn that absolutely took me by surprise and that was very much what I wanted to achieve with artificial wisdom as well there's a lot of people that contact me over DM and say did not see that final twist coming and that was that was very much the experience that I was looking for so if you like that kind of thing if you like twisty turny books and you like techno thrillers I think you'll love both of these books

#stitch with @ceciliaregina275  ❓Got any recs for books about MCs that leave abusive partners? After The Shut Up Ring By Cate C Wells @Cate C Wells  Romance: Single Mom, Friends to Lovers, Hurt/ Comfort, Finding Yourself Again Coming Soon (Friday, May 24, 2024) shut up ring (noun) 💍 a marriage proposal meant to get you off his back, intended to last indefinitely I waited eight years to marry the father of my children. I worked at our relationship. I was patient. I forgave—the thoughtless remarks, the disappointments, the test results when I was expecting our youngest that proved he hadn’t been “working late.” Then, when we finally made it to the altar, he looked deep into my eyes, smiled, and cracked a fat joke. That wasn’t the worst of it. His vows weren’t a promise to love. They were a final test of exactly what I’d do to get his ring on my finger—what I’d take—in front of family, friends, and their cell phones. Was I going to be internet famous?  Another sad bride who must’ve known the kind of man she was marrying? My two little girls stared up at me with big, round eyes. Was I really going to laugh it off like I always did? In that moment, my house of cards came crashing down. When the moment was over, for some reason, my best friend’s older brother was on his feet with his chair knocked over like he was about to punch someone. This is the story of what happened next. Please check the author’s note for specific content warnings. Standalone. No cheating. HEA guaranteed. 📖Quote📖 “How do I make you feel?” I ask, feeling like I’m at the edge of a high ledge with my “toes are curled over the edge. “Like I’ve got reasons,” he says. “For what?” His lips curve ever so slightly. “Everything.” 🏷️  #bestfriendsbrother #bestfriendsbrothertrope #bestfriendsbrotherromance #bluecollarmen #hurtcomfort #angstybooks #angstyromance #romancebooks #booktok #smuttok #steamytok #spicytok #steamybookrecs #spicybookrecs #kindleromance #kindleromancebooks #kindlespicybooks #catecwells

voice_to_text: hey y'all since we're discussing north and he's discussing Cory Booker I thought this would be a great time to recommend this book especially since Cory Booker portrays himself as this grassroots campaign um I think this is a wonderful book um for anyone to read this author specifically went to Newark  studied Newark and then stayed to witness the campaign themselves Cory Bookers campaign and then wrote about it um the title threw me off at first because post racial America I'm like where when hasn't happened yet um but what the author is referring to is post racial in the terms of people being elected to office so she was very specifically comparing Cory Bookers campaign to that of Mayor Gibson and that's Kenneth Gibson who in 69 was the first um Black mayor of Newark  so that's what she means by post racial as far as people being elected or running for office it's not the first time you see a lot of you know Black men or women running for office um outside of that this book is wildly informative the things you think you know about the people you support when in actuality in my own opinion I used to support Cory Booker but I feel like he sold Newark the residents out I feel like he wasn't really for the people and there's a lot of gentrification student policing um poverty you know housing crisis everything else so where is he like not speaking up for the students not speaking up for the marginalized community not speaking up for the people who are being housed out of their area or priced out of their area I thought it'd be a good time to recommend

Anyway, here’s a bit from ‘New Leaves, Old Scars’, out October 2024!  #writer #writertok #writersoftiktok #booktok #writing #writingcommunity #writingcommunityoftiktok #fyp #authorsoftiktok #author #writerslife #indieauthor #indieauthorsoftiktok #JenniferDrewett #NewLeavesOldScars #reading
voice_to_text: Stitch this and read me the first paragraph of your work in progress. Bear with me a little bit. I'm a little groggy post migraine. So… one moment… Sunshine shone through the astrical bar windows in the office. Rays of sunshine loomed over a young woman who sat behind the front desk. Her ashen hair was tightly placed in a ponytail to match her monochrome office wear. She scribbled away into her multi coloured, worn out notebook. A trickle of sweat slid down her nose as she focused on the page in front of her. A fantasy world came to life from her imagination to her notebook as the seconds ticked by. The notes were scattered in their presentation but she could understand what she was writing. She was absorbed in her writing. The seconds ticked by the - by to the sound of her approaching college’s clacky high heels. Hilda wrote of a witch walking along a disintegrated pavement, clacking in her heels as she walked. Hilda's colleague checked her watch as she stopped by the desk: it was 2:58PM She looked for an opening to grab the attention of the woman at the desk.

voice_to_text: do you wanna know what's profoundly humiliating is having to explain the fantasy book that you wrote to HR at your company because when my first book was sold uh and they wanted to make the deal announcement it's quite sort of you know usual for them to say ‘and she currently does this’ if it's not sort of a writing thing or so it's just something about the the author and so they wanted to put that I I currently work at Christie's the auction house the big auction house in London and I had to ask my boss slash HR whether that was okay to put that a staff member of our large company had written a book and I got a call from HR and they're like well what is the book about and I had not gotten into the habit of pitching my book and now I can do it like off the cuff I can do it asleep backwards in high heels but at the time I couldn't and so I'm like fumbling I'm like it's about a girl and a desert and magic and the H R person finally stops me and she's like basically I just need to know whether this book is about Christie’s she essentially all she wanted to know was that I hadn't written The Devil Wears Prada Christie's version uh and that I wasn't going to reveal all the company's deepest darkest uh inwards functions and secrets and I didn't actually have to awkwardly pitch my book to company HR but I did and it was extremely embarrassing

voice_to_text: For reasons known only by the TikTok gods, I still cannot record anything when I do a stitch. There's no sound. So I'm doing voiceover and you can hear my dog drinking in the background. I believe that prologues and epilogues exist and are valid, just as much as they may not be. It all depends on the story and on the author, .and I do not understand this idea of completely skipping them To me it's the equivalent of saying “you know what? Chapter 9 is always rubbish, so I just never read chapter nine.” How do you know it’s rubbish? You don't know. You just don't know. I say write the book with it if it needs it, and I say read it if the writer thought you should read it. So, epilogues and prologues count too!

Especially for one of the trickiest parts of writing the beginning of a book. #authortok #amwritingfiction #authorsoftiktok #writersoftiktok #bookeditor #fictioneditor #writertok #writing #editor #amwritingfantasy #amwritinganovel #amwritingya #amwritingabook #developmentaleditor #indieauthor #indieauthors #aspiringauthor #newauthor #writingtips #writingadvice #copyeditor #copyediting #lineeditor #developmentalediting #lineedit #amwritingromance #amwritingfantasyromance #amwritinghorror #amwritingthriller #booktok
voice_to_text: there to show us what normal life is like before the story comes on in yes yes yeah I just wanna jump in and emphasize the importance of what they're talking about and add just one little thing cause I've had this on my mind lately the concept of establishing normalcy at the beginning of your book and they explained it so well so go back and watch this video if you haven't already but if you're wondering why what they're talking about is important and why you [should usually] have that normal life section at the beginning of the story it's so that readers can understand what's been lost by the inciting incident what has changed or maybe what the protagonist is trying to get back to without it you run the risk of readers thinking of a inciting incident as just that an incident rather than something that they can get invested in something that they want to read more about think of an inciting incident as flipping a table right if you come in right as a table is flipped you'll think oh okay a table has flipped but if you knew what was on the table before the table flips then you're like oh man that nice dinner got ruined oh man there was a spider there no wonder they flipped it I wonder if that spider still around knowing what's on the table makes it more than just a table that has been flipped and that's not to say that you can't come in right as the table is flipped there are ways to make that work for you but I'd argue that that's more the exception than the rule per se and as for what I wanted to add all this is not to say that it has to be just the boring mundane life of your protagonist before the interesting stuff happens you can have unique things going on in their life and still establish that normalcy like the book could start with a festival that happens only every 50 years which is out of the ordinary it's a unique thing that's happening but like but on its own it would not represent a full change to the protagonist’s lifestyle so to speak in cases like this you can think of it more as the expected instead of normalcy that festival may not be part of the routine but it is part of what they expect they know is coming they know how to prepare for it et cetera until the inciting incident flips the table on oh I'm so glad this was on someone else's mind

voice_to_text: I have a theory that this is rooted in ableism and let me explain I personally have several disabilities but my biggest one is migraines whether or not the United States wants to admit it it is a disability it frequently impacts my life and makes my life difficult one of those things is reading and I love to read it hurts my head to read the pages it hurts my head to read certain fonts like it just fucking hurts and so I rely a lot on audiobooks and if a book doesn't have an audiobook the next convenient way for me to read is an e book because I can change the font I can change the background and on top of that I have sensory issues so like the texture of pages can really cause it to be difficult to read so I got this book in a book box for the love of April French by Penny Ames and I was really excited to read it because it is an LGBTQ quite a book with a trans author and a trans FMC and it takes place in the Spring Club but I could not stand the texture of the pages and I took literal months trying to read this and the ebook was like 1099 and I eventually caved because I wanted to finish the book and I couldn't do it like this and I think the publishing companies are aware of that and they're gonna take advantage of disabilities and try to get more money out of people

voice_to_text: Please tell me, you guys, where do you put your bookmarks? Cause I'm. I'm. I'm upset. So not that anybody else probably does this, but this is just me. And I hope other people do it, because I think it's genius. Here's what I do. Currently reading this series, but I have magnet bookmarks. And the point, I cut the other side off so that it's not a point, but my point marks which row or line that I end off of. And if it's like, I end on a full page, then I'll put it so that the point is on this page. And that's where I know I need to start, because there are times that I can't finish the chapter. Please tell me somebody else does that, because I think it's genius.

voice_to_text: so go check out Seth's video he was asked a question about dealing with busy lives and and trying to find time to write and dealing with writer's block and so of course I decided that I would chime in with my answer that I wasn't asked about and if you don't know me I am C Britt the author of my zombie apocalypse Monstra Inter and I'm currently working on a fantasy novel tentatively titled Crimson and first of all I wanna say if you want to write and you're busy like everybody is sometimes you just gotta cram it in wherever you can if you have time on your lunch break you type out notes on your phone if you have time while you're waiting on a doctor's appointment you do it while you're sitting there um sometimes for some people it's not gonna work to say I'm gonna sit down at 6 p m every night and do this cause their schedules are just too chaotic sometimes for some people you're gonna have to just fit it in wherever five minutes here 10 minutes there it still gets written even if you're only doing a couple minutes at a time a few hundred words here and there it still gets written eventually so try not to stress too much about having a set time I know a lot of people talk about having a set time to write but if you can't do that you can't do that and I'm I don't have a super hectic schedule but for me sometimes I know I've got something going on this evening I'm not going to have time to write this evening I'm gonna do it at lunch so that's that is something to keep in mind if you are trying to write something and you have a busy schedule as far as the writer's block um I have a few different methods for dealing with that first of all I kind of analyze how long has this writer's block been going on did I write yesterday and now all of a sudden I can't write today if it's one or two days that probably means I just need to take a break and go do something else I know they a lot of people want to harp on that you have to write every day but that doesn't work for everybody it does not work for me I stressed myself out too much back when I was trying to do the right everyday no matter what so if I have a day that I just am not feeling it I go do something else play a video game watch a movie read a book anything just anything that does not have anything to do with writing now if this feeling has been going on for any stretch of time if it's been a week or a month or something then it gets the point I need to force myself to do something because I get stuck in this rut of well I couldn't do it yesterday I couldn't do it the day before and it just kind of feels overwhelming so I have to kind of get to a point where I just do it I know a lot of people talk about writing when they have passion or whatever but sometimes sometimes it's just sit down and do it and that can involve beat my head against the wall until I figure out where to go with the story or sometimes that means editing and proofreading past chapters I know they say don't do that till the end but it works for me if I go back through and start reading stuff that I've previously written and I'm start editing and stuff either I'm making progress on something that is going to have to be done eventually anyway and my story is still progressing because of that or I go back and read something that sparks an idea I find a detail that I had forgotten I included I remember a character that I haven't done anything with for a while something along those lines and that might get the ball rolling if not that if that doesn't work or if I don't wanna do that sometimes my technique is write anything and I mean anything like something that I know 100% that will get thrown away it has nothing in the world to do with my work in progress I kind of consider it um almost improv with myself I will sit down and I will start with some ridiculous mundane concept and I'll just type out Bob got to work on Saturday's computer and then I go okay what crazy thing happened to Bob next and I have to come up with the most off the wall ridiculous thing and then play off that so Bob sat down at his desk and his co worker walked up to him but today the co worker skin was green and he had antennas how does Bob react to that Bob's eyes bug out and he says what happened to you something like that and then you have to play it off with some crazy idea that happened to that yeah don't worry about punctuation or spelling or grammar or anything just a rough quick fast as you can improv idea that just is absolutely bonkers it will get thrown away nobody will ever see it but it gets that creative mindset going and gets the gets me into that writing mindset and again this may not work for everybody but it's something that I do that works for me so maybe it can help somebody else out and I know those moments are sucky when you have when you run into something like that but you gotta play around with it don't just listen to all the writing advice that says you have to write every day don't just listen to the stuff that says you have to wait for editing at the end or whatever those techniques may not all work for you if they don't work for you that's fine you just have to figure out what works for you

voice_to_text: yes I at this point have exclusively written first person POV and alternating POV between my two main characters and I completely recognize that it's a matter of taste whether you prefer single POV first person, third person past, present tense but I find that when it comes to both reading and writing romance I prefer to see inside what every person is thinking because as we know a lot of the time the things we say and do don't necessarily reflect what we're actually thinking and feeling I will say the thing that I do not do is leave off on a cliffhanger in one character's POV as the person who made this video was talking about and then not come back to their POV and just leave you waiting on that cliffhanger no never that is evil and I will never do that to my readers mostly because I know that they're probably about as impatient as I am

voice_to_text: so I am not an only child I am a middle child middle of three specifically and I am aroace and this got me thinking about [something] just this whole idea that your journey your experience as an aroace person is affected by the examples you have in your life what the people who are closest to you and a little older than you what they do what they want and what they indicate that you should want or think or do because something that I find kind of remarkable about my family is that all of the stereotypical pressure to participate in romance as our society determines we should do romance there was no pressure there was never any oh is that your boyfriend when I was hanging out with a boy there was never any birds and bees talk or indication that I would want any there was never any when you gonna bring someone home when you gonna give us grandkids or great grandkids like I remember that my parents would say you know jokingly that when we grew up they would move to be near whoever had kids first but like that was always treated some really far away thing there was no pressure about it so it really wasn't until I got to like middle school and then I transferred to a junior high and the people around me my age were just going so gaga over people in this really dramatic way that was the first time that I perceived any difference between my experience and what must be normal because no one who mattered in my life no one who loved me had yet tried to tell me or show me accidentally that there was something that I was not but that I should be and I think in part that helped me a lot that gave me a relatively solid foundation to go on this journey of self discovery from my parents my siblings and even my extended family had already shown me just through their actions and the lack of actions my whole life that when I would finally come out to them even if they didn't understand the labels or why they were important they had already voice_to_text: What opinion will you defend like this? Quit reading a book if you are not enjoying it. I love to read, and sometimes it's hard to put down a book unfinished. But I've realized it's really important, and it really helps with reading to put down a book if I'm not enjoying it. I find that when I'm trying to make my way through a book that I'm not really enjoying, I tend to read less. I do other things more, and so my reading backs up. But when I'm reading books that I'm excited about, I'm using every available minute to read, and I zoom through a book, and then I have more time for more books that I enjoy.

Getting the amazing opportunity to be an arc reader for Casey's book born to rule. I have to say it was phenomenal. My full review is up on Goodreads and will be up on Amazon a week out from its release date. This book has amazing world building. It has depth of character, it pulls you in right away, multiple perspectives, and it takes a big switch in time. However, it does it in such a way that it's super seamless and it doesn't take forever to make the connection between why it started where it did and then where it jumps to, which I think is just Chef's Kiss. Such an amazing read though. Just everything about it and I cannot wait for the next one.
video_description: #stitch with @Kacie Ross | Fantasy Author #booktok #arcreader #fantasylove without question this debut novest is amazing. She builds the surface of the world quickly in the first couple of chapters. From there each page adds a new layer of world building. Similarily with the chacters, in the beginning there are questions, some things were onbvious from context but I was worried I would have to wait chapters to find out more about the significant chacters and and actions. I was happy to be wrong! Kacie did an amazing job of quickly and without taking you out of the story building the world building character back in. When introducing a new character, Kacie gives great detail to this charcter foreshadowing her importance. She takes a bit over a chapter to reavel the chacters import. At every turn the book becomes more and more amazing. Druids, magic, humans, war, romance, sacrifice, and mystery. Oh, and shifters though in a way I have never read them. I am in love with this book!!! Cannot wait to read more by Kacie!

voice_to_text: you should go back and watch the Ops full video if you haven't seen it right there she's talking about a book she read called Big Magic I have not read that book but the lesson she Learned from it was that you don't have to be perfect at something to do it you don't have to even be really good at something to do it if you want to write then write this was a lesson I didn't figure out until my 30s just the general do something for the joy of it and you don't have to be good at it that lesson and when I figured that out I started drawing and I started painting and eventually I started writing again I picked up my guitar and I Learned the ukulele and I'm not good at much of it except for writing and I'm decent at drawing and painting but the point isn't how good you are at it it is how much joy does it bring you you can always get better at something but what matters is how you feel while you're doing it a part of that lesson is accepting the fact that you might not be the next huge name in art or literature but that's okay you don't have to be if you're loving what you're creating it's almost certainly going to bring other people joy as well and really what more can you ask for happy Thursday book friends

voice_to_text: Normalize posting why you broke up on the internet. I feel like enough time has passed where I can actually share the story. But one thing people don't tell you about going through breakups as an adult is how crazy people get over pets. I was fully living with my boyfriend, with my dog and my cat that I had had before the relationship. They were mine, when he randomly kicked me out one day and was like, we're done. We have no chemistry. Like, we were not compatible. And in hindsight, was he wrong? No, because Lewis and Clark themselves could draw him a map and he would not be able to find. But come to find out, the real reason is that he had a new girlfriend who he was seeing while I was still his girlfriend. Okay, whatever. Cheating is cheating. That sucked, obviously. But the audacity of this man, in just the nicest way. He has all my stuff waiting for me in garbage bags outside the apartment, so I cannot go in. Like, I have no more access to his apartment, and I have my dog with me. What I don't have, what's not waiting outside for me is my cat. My cat? What's his reasoning? Where's my cat? Can I have my cat? Maybe? Madison, my new girlfriend, has just really bonded with your cat, and she loves those kind of cats, and I. I just can't separate them. So we're keeping the cat. For Madison, my new girlfriend. And, I mean, I'm just gobsmacked at this point, but I'm trying to pull a legally blonde. Like, I'm taking the damn dog, but I don't have access, and I don't have a would be lawyer who can, like, tell him he legally needs to give me my cat. So I had to get creative. And again, I'm locked out of this apartment. But he has a pet door on the apartment, so I was like, fuck this. I'm getting my freaking cat while he left. And I tried to hoist myself up to his little, like, raised balcony to get into the pet door, and I couldn't really reach, but just my luck, there were these three guys who were waiting, and they were like, are you really obviously trying to, like, burgle this man's apartment? But I explained what was happening, and they helped me, like, get through the bed door and collect my things. But can you actually believe that he tried to steal my cat and give it to his new girlfriend like that? It's not like, here's her tea towel she left over. It was my fucking cat. It's been years, but I hope him and Madison are well and truly. Puck

What's something that movies get wrong, that drives you crazy, but other people don't care about it all? When you want to shorten Leonardo da Vinci's name to one word, it is Leonardo, not Da Vinci. Da Vinci means from the town of Vinci. It is as if my name were all one of Toronto and you called me Mrs. Of Toronto. That is incorrect. It is Leonardo. That is because Leonardo da Vinci was an illegitimate child. He doesn't have a real last name. But that doesn't make his last name of town he was from. That's insane. And yes, I'm speaking to you. voice_to_text: if you're querying author I highly recommend you check out Alice's series about querying and comp titles it's really interesting I am not a literary agent but I have seen a weird number of query letters as an author mostly because I've done critiques on them and I just wanna quickly add something to what Alice said here which is that a lot of the time the critique that I give back about comp titles is that I need them in order to understand what the vibe of your book is or more accurately to not misunderstand it I'll give you an easy example I read a query letter one time where the theme of it revolves around to genetic manipulation of children and I just remembered literally saying I need a comp title because I need to understand whether this is genetic manipulation in the vibe of Kazuo Ishiguro’s Never Let Me Go or whether this is genetic manipulation of children in the vibe of Baby Geniuses both things about genetic manipulation but both extremely different vibes and I wouldn't wanna think that I'm going into like a fun baby geniuses type romp and then get something really dark and serious and or vice versa so that is something that is really crucial it's you it might be obvious to you I think a lot of the time that's what I find so it's obvious to the author what the vibe is but my experience might be different my expectations might be different ideally you should be able to also convey this in the rest of the query like I would hope a query that's very sort of cozy ☠️ mystery doesn't sound the same as a query that is sort of a gory 💀💀💀💀 story but um not always so yeah I don't think you need to overthink sometimes what your query has in similarities in terms of like well this one's also about a girl who does X it's not about that it's about vibes essentially it's about me understanding what I'm getting myself into a lot of time with the queries as well as everything that Alice says so yeah just wanted to add that on

voice_to_text: Question for anyone who's drafting a novel: how long did it take you to write the first draft? So, I actually did the first draft for ‘New Leaves, Old Scars’ in 33 days ‘cause I started it during NaNoWriMo hence why it took a very short period of time. But for the project I'm gonna release after ‘New Leaves, Old Scars’, I'm not sure what my target's gonna be. I think I want to have a first draft done by the end of the year cause the the aim is to get it out there next year but realistically I imagine I'll probably have a first draft done probably just before I release ‘New Leaves, Old Scars’. Not 100% sure on that one but seems to be the way to go. At the very least, it will probably still be in the very early draft stages when I go on my writing holiday to Malta in October so there's that at least. Ha ha!

There's also a slight bilingual bonus with this at least with Benelim cause Benelim is basically the Italian word 'bene' with the word Nephilim. And this is similar thing to with the Maelim cause again Mal is a common you know form of evil especially and we're talking about like in romance languages. voice_to_text: I do lean more towards female protagonists in a lot of my books and part of that is just because I prefer reading about female protagonists but my Oracle Chronicles have six major point of view characters and multiple minor point of view characters and they're pretty equally split between men and women so the best advice I've run across for writing characters in general and it was specifically helpful for me to sit down and think through my male characters was when you're building your culture and society in a fantasy world to also keep in mind what is considered the ideal woman and the ideal man within that culture which might be really different from what it looks like in our current modern day culture where we live and then think about how that character is going to respond with to their cultures idea of what a man or a woman should be there's going to be some that work very very hard to fit into that mold even if they're struggling with that there's gonna be others that fit into that mold very easily and you're going to have some that reject that mold for some reason or another they don't want to play by society's rules and they're going to create and identity of masculinity or femininity outside of what is their cultural norms but I found that extremely helpful when I sat down to break down my main male characters and how they're going to interact with one another how they're going to interact with the other characters in the story and what their character arcs are going to be in responding to adjusting to and dealing with how they interact with their society's concept of what they should be to man you know in the middle of a war and imprisonment with magic and subtrofuge and all that because those are fun but that's the best advice I've run across it also works for my female characters what's the ideal woman how do they react to that how do they either fit in with that or reject that or overcome it and become themselves

voice_to_text: How are some of y'all going around living life not caring what people think about you? Like, truly read this book. It was a Japanese mega bestseller. It was eventually translated into English. It's fantastic. It's based on the thought of a Japanese professor who, um, studied Socratic philosophy, ancient Greek philosophy. And he also became obsessed with Alfred Adler, who's one of the big three founders of psycho therapy, along with Sigmund Freud and Carl Young. And he's sort of the forgotten third, Alfred Adler. So this is a Japanese take, um, on a. An Austrian psychologist which also takes in Socratic philosophy, and it's written as a Socratic dialogue. It's a wonderful book. It's good for all ages to. Teenagers will get a lot out of it because it's written in an easy to approach dialogue. Adults will get a lot out of it. There's a lot of good core things to address this idea of how you can not care what people think about you. There's a concept in here called the separation of tasks. And so you often think when you're worried about something, you really stop and think and you say, is that my task, or am I worried about something that is somebody else's task? somebody's opinion of you is something that really you're imagining. You have no idea what somebody else's opinion is of you. You have no idea. You have no idea how strongly held the opinion is. Even if it's Good. And so that's their task. And so you eventually have to train yourself to really only focus on your tasks. And it's wonderful. There's so many other nuggets in this short, easy to approach book. Um, but that, that is how you do it. And it really is the core philosophy of the book. And you can see it in the title there. The courage to be disliked.

#stitch with @Pearlmania500 PLEASE SEE QUERY LETTER BELOW! Dear Literary Agents of Tiktok, I’m seeking representation for my debut YA fantasy novel of 80,000 words, THE WARLOCK’S SHADOW. In a mystical world where magic and modern life seamlessly coexist, fifteen-year-old Alex is an ordinary teenager with huge dreams of following in his late father’s footsteps to become a Knight; an elite dragon-riding, magic-wielding, protector of the world. There’s only one problem: he sucks at magic. While attending school he undergoes an affinity ritual to discover that he aligns with the mysterious element of darkness, something extremely rare and associated with black magic users called Warlocks. The only Warlock Alex knew of is Blight, the same man who tried to enslave all dragons in pursuit of world domination--as well as his father’s murderer. Disheartened when no domesticated dragon egg bonds with him as it does for classmates, Alex stumbles across a wild dragon egg in the nearby woods. It immediately hatches for him alone, unleashing his previously untapped magical gifts. Intrigue mounts when his mother passes down a cryptic amulet, a gift from his late father later that evening. Meanwhile, black magic cults are on the rise and Alex’s amulet begins to pulse with energy and his own magic starts to go haywire. Curious about the amulet’s behavior Alex finds his father’s journal while researching and discovers an upcoming cosmic event called the Celestial Shadow. The event in question would weaken the boundary between their world and the Void which is imprisoning the Warlock Blight. Cults worshiping Blight plan on using this event to free him. Alex and his friends vow to stop whoever is behind the plot to bring back Blight. Should they fail, life as they know it will be turned upside down. THE WARLOCK’S SHADOW is a unique combination of “How to Train Your Dragon 2” and “Harry Potter”.  This work is aimed at a young adult audience seeking an immersive escape into a world where magic is not just a part of life but a force that shapes destinies. #seekingliteraryrepresentation #seekingliteraryagent #yafantasybooks #yafantasy #youngadultbooktok #queryingauthors #bookquery #indieauthor #literaryagent #booktok

voice_to_text: BBR that I predict I'll rate 5 stars so first we have out on a limb by Hannah Bonamyeop not to be smug or anything but I was correct I rated this book 5 stars and I'm gonna tell you why so the main tropes are accidental pregnancy and then false proximity and roommate the male main character is boar he has prosthetic leg and the female main character is win and she has an underdeveloped hand they meet at their mutual friends's party it's a Halloween party and they're both dressed as pirates and they have a one night stand and this one night stand leads to the accidental pregnancy uh this is my favourite book which contains accidental pregnancy trope I usually really don't like it it's kind of like a common thing between readers that we don't like it that we don't like the accidental pregnancy trope but it's really good there is a really mature and necessary conversation on whether or not she wants to keep the baby um I think this is so needed for a book like this it's not soft under the rug and it's outright written on the page whether or not she will keep it and the options that are available for her and I really appreciate that this was mentioned and talked about that it wasn't just a given that she would keep the baby Bo and win eventually move in together because of Win's living arrangements they're they're really bad basically and they get to know each other they just wanna live as roommates they wanna just know each other as friends and then it goes from there and oh my god with both characters being disabled as well it goes into a lot of um the kind of thought process that disabled people have around being parents um and all one of the internal monologues contains when thinking that she won't be able to be a great mother because she's got an under underdeveloped hand and actually the her hand is based off the author's own hand as well and so her experiences are lived experiences by the author which I think is fantastic so overall the book is heartwarming it's beautiful it's amazingly written it intertwines gut wrenching emotion with humour at the same time so if you need me I will be reading every single one of Hannah Bonham Young's books

voice_to_text: our children cannot read let alone writing a paragraph if you haven't watched that video watch it um do a little research on the discourse going around talking about literacy in um America and in our classrooms where kids literally don't know how to read and then come back because I'm not an educator and I wanna talk about like the policy and the political reasoning behind this lack of literacy because it's definitely there and it's scary and it's strange and we should be talking about it um so join me on a little adventure shall we as you probably noticed by now a lot of educators have practically been begging parents to read with their children and to not leave teaching their kids how to read up to school alone because it is very easy to slip through the cracks in the public education system and also we're not learning how to read in the most effective way and you mean more than just class time to learn how to read you need like individual one on one practice and like learning how to love reading as well and that's where parents come in where they can read to their child read with their child um like replace screen time with books whatever those are all things that can be done but there's also this level of understanding that that is not accessible to everyone especially single parent household low income households like it is not possible to read with your child for an hour every day if you're working super long hours or if you're struggling to put food on the table it's just not possible and there is a solution for that matter of fact and that solution is the public library the American public library system is probably the most democratic the most free the most fair the most accessible animals community oriented institution that exists in America today it is everything should just operate the way that the library system operates in my opinion we'd be living in a much better world because everything is accessible everything is free getting a library card is most places free taking out books free the internet free printing cheap to free right most libraries are getting rid of their finding system to make it more accessible like the American public library system Chef's Kiss no notes delicious we love her we love her deeply truly you know who doesn't like her Republicans Republicans don't like her Republicans are passing all these book bans because they're homophobic and racist and terrible and they're incentivizing libraries to take these books off their shelves by saying that they're not going to fund them if those books are in their children sections or in their libraries at all and as I just mentioned the public library system no notes they are not the people who are going to be boring education boring knowledge and boring books that's like not what the institution of the public library system does so it's putting these libraries in really horrible positions where it's either we lose our accessibility to everyone or we lose our like relatability and our like need in the community for everyone we're not providing what the community needs anymore we're not providing what libraries are meant to provide freedom and learning and like solidarity with one another you know community if you will like those are the things that the library provides that they're not able to provide if they can't put in books written by queer authors or can't put in books that talk about race or do that and not get funded so those books can't get checked out for free anymore you know of course the Republican Party is going to attack these institutions of democracy that exist in our communities of course they are they want us to be as individualistic as possible they don't want us to have access to education or bettering our society they don't want us to learn about queer people or people of colour or people of different faiths but at least the liberals the Democrats they've got it under control right wrong Democrats across the country are cutting funding to libraries but I specifically want to talk about the New York Public Library because I think that the budget cuts of the New York Public Library is facing um and where that money is going is incredibly telling as to why these political institutions want to ensure that we are not literate as a population and within our communities especially minorities community so especially communities of colours especially poor communities this The New York Public Library's entire sad story explains exactly why and it's it's terrifying Mayor Eric Adams is planning on cutting the New York Public Library budget by $58 million $58 million that is a huge portion of the public library's budget and it is going to change operations the first thing that it's going to change is hours of operation so instead of being able to be open late in the evenings and on weekends they're going to have to cut weekend hours The New Republic library has already come out and said that with these budget cuts that's the first thing that's gonna have to go and that is incredibly devastating because if we rewind back to the beginning of this video when we're talking about accessibility parents who work the only time that they have with their kids to teach their kids how to read to teach their kids to love to read is during the weekend and now they don't have this free accessible option to do that and that to me is absolutely bonkers bonkers but it gets worse now fella where is all that money going I'm so glad you asked the N y P d that money is going to the N y P d let that sink in yes this NYPD same NYPD that's been arresting peaceful student protesters this is just recent NYPD behavior they have a long horrible history that NYPD so what does this have to do with literacy right at our base core we're taking an institution that excels in providing accessible knowledge education and literacy to individuals taking that money away putting it into an institution that penalizes individuals who don't have proper education see how it's cyclical see how if more kids knew how to read less kids would end up going to jail when they're older like it's really that immediate connection but it goes deeper than that the NYPD was essentially called into quell public unrest and this public unrest came from students college students specifically college students who were some of the last individuals to gone through elementary public education and receive phonics based reading skills so we are more literate than the generations that are coming after us if we were the last ones to receive this type of education right the MIT was brought in to destroy these encampments and the reason why is because the institution was scared that the encampments were self sufficient they weren't going anywhere they weren't ever going to go anywhere and that was because a community was pitching it they were bringing resources money food hence every awareness everything that the encampment needed to survive and the only way to cut that off was to destroy the encampment completely which was violent and the opposite of community right what I find most striking about the encampments was how much reading was happening all of the videos that I saw all the images I saw free libraries that started at Columbia and was at pretty much every other encampment that came after it students were sitting there reading Angela Davis they were reading theory they were reading Palestinian authors and this gets to my wrapping up point right you need to know a lot to effectively talk about specific political issues in general but specifically with Palestine the people who are really fighting for liberation have done a ton of reading like they need to be knowledgeable about things to even know that what is happening in Palestine is wrong right and that is why literacy is so important because that is how we find justice like we need to understand how things work by reading about it by reading theory by reading accounts by reading poetry and if people don't know how to read then there is no more descent and that is why our institutions are trying to destroy literacy in any way that they subtly can but who knows maybe I'm crazy sorry if that didn't make sense

voice_to_text: Who said that? I find that previous stitch so funny because I know we've been having this discussion about Robin Lee in her book the idea of you and how she changed the characters from black to white in order for her to get published and ultimately become a movie on Amazon. And when I was writing the build up, I had a couple people, not many, but a couple people were telling me, you should make Porter white. And I said, no, this is a black story. Porter is a black man. Yes, he is a light skin black man, but he is a black man. Based on his life experiences, going to HBCU, being in fraternity, all these things. He is a black man in a black city. And so I stuck to my guns. I did not change. And look, that young ladies holding my book in her hand. I say all that to say, do not change. Stick to your guns. If you have a story to tell, tell it the way you want to tell it. Don't change for no damn body, no matter how bad you want it.
