voice_to_text: so that's a scene from LA Chimera which is gonna be my favorite movie of the year and it's one of my favorite scenes from that movie in it Arthur who's played by Josh O’Connor and Italia played by Carol Durate a little like brass bell it's like a children's rattle and she asked him what it is when he hands it to her and he sort of shrugs and then when she rings it she sort of alights with recognition and says Campanello Campanello specifically refers like a little bell like a hand bell whereas Campana which the word comes from means like big bell like in a church one of my big takeaways when I first watched La Chimera is like why doesn't Josh O’Connor's character know the word for bell bells are very important to Italian culture um bells tell you what time it is bell towers are really important for city pride one of the words for city pride in Italian literally comes from the word bell tower it just felt like a very rudimentary word for him to not know after speaking Italian pretty competently for 95% of the movie we do see him learn some words or misuse some words and I was able to extract meaning from those moments script is telling us something when he's learning these certain words like what are we learning when he learns the word for bell so after I left the movie I did some research I was like what's going on with the word bell why doesn't he know I found I thought it was super interesting and I wrote about it this week restorative romance  this newsletter is about ghost it's about Petrarch it's about Dante it's about avant-garde poetry voice_to_text: Hey! So one of my absolute favorite authors of all time, Mrs. Gail Delaney, is here on TikTok. And yeah, like the stitch says, she is clearing out her bookshelves and she's put together some bundles of some of her books that she's trying to move. and I looked through them and I'm so pissed because there are some really good deals on these bundles! Uh, some of them are mystery book bundles- you don't know what you're getting. But like, there was a bundle of her hardcover books from the Phoenix Rebellion series. And it's like, four hardcover books! It's like, the first like, part of the series. And it's like 35 bucks for four hardcover books! That's insane! And like, honestly, she's super nice. So if you asked her, (nicely!) she would probably sign them for you too at the same time. They're not all her books. They're like, books that she's collected over the years as like someone that was running her own publishing house in addition to being an author. So like, there's all kinds of different genres. She writes romance... um... with varying degrees of spice. absolutely (*cheeky grin*) You know those stories that you just get like sucked into and you pick it up and you start reading and you swear... Just one more page...  (One hour later) Just one more page... (5 hours later) Just one more page... And then like... nine hours later, you finish the book... and you're sad... and you don't know where you are... (That can't be just me right?) That's Gail. So yeah, So if you're looking for a really good deal on some new stuff to read- Some stuff is like six to 16 years out of print she said. Like, some of these books you can't get a hold of any other way. That's fun. Um... But yeah, I'm not sponsored or anything like that. I swear! =P I just love Gail's work. And I really think that if you are interested in reading some romance, and SCI fi romance, or some... some historical romance... or Oh! she's got she's actually got a series that I haven't started yet. It's a it's like a Sherlock Holmes spicy romance story- Baker Street That's on my to do list. But yeah, book bundles! Save yourself some money! Get some awesome books! Help out an amazing author! Even if you don't wanna do that, if this is your first time hearing that name- Gail Delaney, she's amazing! I love her! 💜 Again, I'm not sponsored. Just a fan. Just wanna help out one of my favorite authors. Love you Gail! 💜 Books!!! 📚 Cheap books! Cheap... mystery... books!  📖 Yeah, check out the link!

video_description: #stitch with @Cass Paredes | Author/Editor I’m a character first kind of woman. Fellow writers: do you write characters or plot first?  #writer #writertok #writersoftiktok #booktok #writing #writingcommunity #writingcommunityoftiktok #fyp #authorsoftiktok #author #writerslife #indieauthor #indieauthorsoftiktok #JenniferDrewett #character #plot
voice_to_text: …and start planning your book what comes to you first: the characters or the plot? Oh yeah! I can answer this! Ha ha! It's the characters for me. I- I'll be honest: I'm a very character driven person. Not just when it comes to reading but also to when I'm like watching stuff on TV. I'm always really fascinated by the journeys the characters go through rather than just the ancillary plots that happen along the way. Oh you know, the plot is obviously important of course ha ha and you know I I understand that but I'm very much into the characters. I wanna know what's happening with them and how their journey is going. How did we get here? What could possibly happen next? Like that's you know the psychology of a character is really interesting to me. It is pretty much always the character that comes first. I'm gonna give you an example: so there's a project I want to start once I finish ‘New Leaves, Old Scars’ I'm pretty I'm about 90% sure that this is the thing I'm gonna start next and the… and the thing that came first was the character. The character's been in my brain since I was for 15. 16 maybe at the oldest and I'm 34 so this character has been whirring around my head to some extent for about 18 years 19 years nearly. No! Hang on a minute! Wait a second! If I was 15 at the time, I'm turning 35 this year. Oh my god… it's been nearly 20 years. I'm actually having a really big, major realisation. I have to go…

voice_to_text: completely agree and here are some of my exceptions firstly we have getting the knife by Tamsyn Muir um and I think the thing that makes me love this cover so much even though as a character on it is the fact that it's still showing a lot of the personality of the story the main thing that I like so much about ornate decorative covers that are more stylized and pattern is that it gives the reader a feel of what the book what the world what the atmosphere of the book will be like and I think that this cover for getting the 9th does this exact same thing even though there's a character on the cover because of the bones and the like galaxy or whatever the dislike dust that's going on at the bottom down here it really makes you like enveloped in the vibe of the book before you can picking it up and I love that next up we have the unbroken by Seal Clark and I think my reasonings for liking this cover are very similar to my reasonings for Gideon the ninth I think because of the like dark mysterious color palette of this book and the shadows like on the main character's face on the cover it just makes everything feel so mysterious and dark and eerie that it just like calls to me to pick up this book even though it's not as gorgeous and decorative as the cover that usually I'm drawn towards um I think also her pose here is particularly interesting and unusual which adds to this element of like oh I'm intrigued that makes me gravitate towards this book so next up we have this Poison Heart by Kailyn Barron and I think here it's a very simple reasoning of I just love these colors I just think it's so rich and vibrant and the background is so intricate and decorative with the plants around here in the foreground and the like more faint outlines of leaves in the background that even though it just has a character it maintains the level of interest and detail that I like on my non character covers and then finally we have the book that inspired this whole video one of my favorite character covers of all time Sorcerer Thrones by Margaret Rogerson this book is so magical the story is so interesting and gripping yet so cozy and comforting to me at the same time and I think this cover just perfectly reflects it with it's like shimmery glossy coating and the muted like yummy mysterious almost foggy colors of this book I can talk forever about how much I love this cover um but this is definitely my favorite and Charlie Bowwater is one of my favorite bookish artists as well so I think this is just like the epitome of a character cover

#stitch with @beth reekles ok let’s talk about why this book took 5 years #Booktok #author #writing
voice_to_text: I just saw an author post on TikTok that she has written three books so far in 2024  I saw this video a couple of days ago and had thoughts so I wanted to make a reply to it and the reason I didn't do it a couple of days ago ironically is because I was turning a book around in 12 hours well actually first I line edited 125,000 word book in just over two weeks was only supposed to have two weeks to do it and then when I sent it back New York got it back to me midnight New York time and I got it to copy edits yesterday at about midday New York time so that was the 12 hours Beth Weekles one stitching here has a great response about what her process actually looks like but I just wanna talk about briefly how the same way that writing a book quickly doesn't equal a bad book taking a long time with a book doesn't equal a good book and I should know that sounded weird that sounded like I'm saying my next book isn't good what I'm saying is that it's not any better than if I had taken less time with it so for context my name is Alwyn Hamilton I have a book called The Notorious Virtues that was supposed to come out in 2020 initially thank god it didn't uh but it's now coming out in 2025 and I can do a full story time on what happened there but for now I'm going to touch on the fact that this book took five years so yeah The Notorious Virtues took five years not because it is a better book than someone who wrote a book in three months I probably actually did initially write the first draft of this book in three months maybe a little bit less from and it entered the sort of publishing process some things happened I had editors change leave come back on maternity leave come back a global pandemic happened some other things happened um but all in all the reason the book took five years is not because it was a perfect book that I was polishing to perfection and that is why it's taking so long and those five years are going to make it through the literary masterpiece of my life any more than a book that took a couple of months to write make it not a literary masterpiece what made up the bulk of those five years is not me polishing the same book to perfection I have probably rewritten this book I'm going to easily conservatively say six times from scratch and it's 125,000 word book I have probably written half a million words that will never be seen by readers in those five years and I am always a big fan of saying that there is no such thing as wasted words that you're doing work to show that that is not the direction that you wanna go or you're sort of working out of character there's always a reason that you're doing that right and it is never wasted work however in my case a lot of it was work that was coming from and just making me feel more sort of insecure and crazy about this book I had a lot of sort of spirals trying to write this I tried to quit several times um there was a moment where the reason that I didn't quit was because I knew that if I quit on this book I would be quitting on writing all together I wasn't quite ready to do that even though I was ready to quit on this book those five years represent long periods of being completely mobilized by struggling with this book struggling with self doubt struggling with my identity as a writer what I wanted it to be it doesn't represent me sort of crafting the perfect story this all began with Beth talking about finishing three books this year I have finished officially as of yesterday although it still has work to do um one book in the last 5 years and I am extremely proud of that however I'm also extremely in a nice way envious of Beth for how much work she has been able to do in a short period of time and also incredibly impressed by it because so much of what took me five years was coming from my own sort of internal life and internal insecurities and I think it takes a tremendous self awareness self confidence lack of ego in a negative way in order to do what she has done and I think that is kind of what is behind writing books swiftly it is not polishing them to perfection a short amount of time to write a book does not make it better than a long amount of time to write a book my book that taken five years to write is it any better than a book that I would have taken a year to write probably not it's just this is the process that got me here and one of the things about authors is that we all have such radically different process I know people who are lucky if they write 500 words a day but those 500 words are perfect words that never change I know people who write 5,000 words a day but those words will all be scrapped and rewritten to new better words by the end of the process everyone's process is incredibly different and um I think also all of our process for each different book is different I'm really hoping that the process I have for this book is never the process for another book I write again and yeah one day I hope to have as many books as Beth has although I'll probably never catch up to her because I've taken this five year slow down but again it's not a race she's written 14 books my fourth book will be coming out in April of next year finally after much much struggling and I'm excited for you to read it but I also don't think that it is any way a perfect book because it's taken five years instead of five months

voice_to_text: Home is where the bodies are tells the story of three estranged siblings who must return home when their mother passed. So I got the book today. Really excited to read it. And awesome cover. Um, and Drew, Geneva's husband, does a awesome job at selling it. Definitely got my attention. And so basically, three siblings reunite after the passing of their mother. And as they're going through things in the inner house, they stumble upon a box of old VHS tapes, you know, family vacation videos, stuff like that. So for nostalgic, nostalgic reasons, they decide to watch them. Until they stumble upon a video that is labeled The Summer of 1999. In that video, they discover that their parents have kept a horrible, dark secret from them since then. So. And then they have to decide, do we keep uncovering the past, or should we just not talk about it again? And there you have it. So I am super excited to read this. Um, what got my attention was, um, the three siblings. Um, I'm the youngest of three, and I'm also the only son, and my middle name is Michael, which is the first name of the younger brother in this book, so. And I'm hoping that's the only similarities that I have with this. Um, yeah, I mean, the difference is both my parents are so alive and well and both still together, and there is no dark secrets that they have kept from us. For the past 25 years. I hope so. Rachel, Haley, if you guys are seeing this, don't you think this would be a fun siblings book to read together?

You wanna know what happens to little girls who aren't allowed to express their emotions in childhood? We become adults who still have issues expressing their feelings. So we start reading books to see if that will help. And guess what? It does. But we also discover that we have a lot more issues than we originally thought. A lot. So we start reading more, and we decide to go online to see if we're the only ones with this problem. Only discover online. There's an entire community of people that have the same issue. And they're all little weird, but they're super, super cool. And we work together, and we have discovered the cure. And the cure is buying more books. So this is your daily reminder to go out and buy a book, because it will help your mental health and it's just the right thing to do. And because I told you to. So here are some recommendations for you to buy. Um, but do yourself a favor and check triggers, because some of them are, um, a little weird. Okay, bye.

voice_to_text: I am mildly fighting with some booksellers over the other app thread because I put up the topic up for debate is should any booksellers charge a cover charge or fee for an author signing panel and my short opinion on this is no but there's a lot more to unpack here there's a lot of hate and frankly one sided hate from indie bookstores towards indie authors and yes I understand that indie authors do do some frustrating things to indie bookstore for example putting their books on shelves for readers to find that takes away from sales that the store could have been potentially making because they have no way to charge for that book there are also indie authors that don't put money or attention into formatting or their cover design or editing and by having these books on the shelves for indie bookstores that decreases the credibility of those particular store and from a marketing perspective readers aren't necessarily going to bookstores to request an indie book the same way that they would request a traditional publishing book I think this is for three reasons one because indie authors don't typically have the marketing dollars to put behind their books like a traditional published author would also because readers are assuming that the bookstore probably doesn't even carry indie books unless they ask for it and indie authors aren't putting effort into encouraging the readers to buy from indie bookstores because they're begging them to carry them on their shelves when they do get them on the shelves the indie bookstore acts like they're doing them a favour and it's so much easier to just point people to your own website or Amazon that's it I don't think any of that is a reason to hate in the authors and now even traditional authors are feeling this sense of better than you from these bookstores and it really does come across like these indie bookstores think that they're doing authors a favour by carrying their books and having them on the shelf and this becomes super apparent when they do things like charging a cover charge for an author event where they're not even paying the author for the most part a musician wouldn't be playing at a concert venue unless they were getting paid or a percentage of the ticket sales people don't just go to concert venues to sit and listen to nothing and while some of the bigger bookstores seem to get this a lot of the indie bookstores seem to be struggling with this and I personally am struggling with why as an indie author it has been so much easier on the whole to work with Barnes and noble then it has been to work with a lot of indie bookstores and there are some indie bookstores that have been fantastic to work with and I've Learned so much from and has really helped my brand but at the same time there have been a lot more that have been just awful and yes my book has been on the shelves of Barnes and noble but when it's on the shelves at an indie bookstore I promote them like crazy and I shout it from the rooftops because I know that they're like me they're just trying to make it and I want them to succeed so we can succeed together so let's dive into this scenario the indie bookstore is saying  when the author's books don't sell or people don't show up for the event they can't make any money off of it and for a traditionally published author you're pretty much facing the same consequences if you buy a whole bunch of copies of the book for people to come out for the event and people bought the book elsewhere no one makes any money from that event when indie authors do it a lot of times what will happen is that the bookstore will return all those books that they bought or offer to sell them back to the indie author and the authors will end up having to pay for that they will lose money so there is risk on both sides and that's just how business works if you're taking a risk by hosting an author event and getting all of those books in you're still taking the risk that people might not show up and as an author especially as an indie author you're taking a risk that you might have to pay back that money or that you've just wasted a whole bunch of your time the author and the bookstore should be in this together they should both be promoting the event and they should both hope that people turn out and drive sale when people turn out they both win if they don't turn out the bookstore shouldn't be scrambling to make the best of it while the author gets nothing for the time that they're donating people have mentioned that the bookstore is spending more money and is taking a greater risk than the author because they have staff and bills to pay and they're providing snacks and while sometimes this is a risk most times and especially with indie bookstores it's more likely that they're doing these signings during normal business hours so the staff would be there anyways the bills to pay would still exist and often times it's the author who brings the snack and in this particular case there were no snacks to speak up if we look at how larger bookstores do these signings like Barnes Noble you buy the book to get a seat or a place in line to attend the event you can't get in line to get a sign copy without a wristband you can't get a wristband without buying a book any bookstores could easily do that too but for some reason this one chose not to and hide behind the excuse of people are bringing in outside books and they can't stop it by working together with the author to ensure that nobody without a wristband get the signed copy of the book then you can prevent people from bringing their own outside copies of the book because they'll need to buy the book to get a wristband if indie bookstores would treat authors fairly and yes some do it would be so much better for them because they would encourage their readers to buy from an indie store versus buying on Amazon this would not only help bookstores sell more of that particular authors books but also other books that readers might discover while they're in the store but so long as these bookstores are only focused on their own goal and continue to demonstrate to authors they don't care and this is not a partnership they're not gonna get any return from the author and while there are cases like if it's a really big author and you're trying to limit the amount of people who are attending the event that I understand that you're selling and you have like an entrance fee or something it doesn't make sense when you're trying to attract more people to assign it I'm pretty sure that all artists can agree that exposure does not equal sales and donating your time and expertise for someone who's just profiting off you while all you get is exposure is only helpful to the person who is getting the money as an author I know of course I'm biased but I also always always support my local indie bookstore and I love them to pieces and they supported me in return so let me know in the comments below if you agree or disagree and let's continue this discourse

voice_to_text: everybody go watch Kelly's video um it's pretty important I know it seems like minor in the grand scheme of things but with all the censorship and puritanical 🐂 💩 that's going on right now um we should be very aware when companies are trying to enforce censorship without telling us I'm paying for a membership company doesn't get to tell me what shows up in my search or not it certainly does not get to decide for me especially when they're still making money off of those titles and not paying the authors of those titles nearly enough and not only is this like gross and insulting to readers but like as a narrator I have a problem with it um because I had this happen to me I was asked for my audible link to send it to a publisher and when I went to go grab it I was like I'm missing titles what's going on here um and it was titles by the same author so I looked up the author nothing showed up under her name and then I looked at the title of the book and it didn't show up in the drop down when you do a search but it did show up once I completed the search and I was like okay well weird maybe it's my cookies or the cache on my phone or something so cleared all that still no luck and I was okay well I've had audible glitches before where things will show up and then not show up and then show up again um so I'll wait a day I wait a day um it's still not showing up on my phone but the full list does show up on my downstairs computer like that's really weird and then the next day it's gone again so I reach out to the author I'm like is there something going on with the titles I don't know about I don't know what it could be but you're not showing up the titles aren't showing up and she said oh that's weird it's not showing up for me either I'll reach out to the publishing company well and that's when I started to do a little digging and I think I was a Reddit thread I found where they were like oh yeah there's this new preference option in settings that they've automatically checked for you and I go in on the desktop setting on my phone and sure enough that checkbox has been clicked for me it was not checked on the downstairs computer because I wasn't signed in so if you are a reader or a narrator or something go in and check that box uncheck that box I should say um and I really hope publishing companies and casting directors are made aware that there might be titles missing because audible has decided they know what we should and shouldn't see in our searches I woke up a little salty this morning

#stitch with @Nerdymixedpan #MillennialTok #MillennialChildhood #90sKids #90sDisney #90sDisneyFilms #DisneyTok #DisneyAdults #DisneyChildhoodCrushes #MarriageMaterialDisneyCharacters #Quasimodo #DisneysTheHunchbackOfNotreDame #BlindTok #BlindnessInFiction #BlindnessAndRomance #BlindTropes #DisfiguredGuyBlindGirlPairing #BookTok #FrenchLiterature #VictorHugo #VictorHugoFans #VictorHugoNovels #NotreDameDeParis #TheHunchbackOfNotreDame #LHommeQuiRit #TheManWhoLaughs #FYP
voice_to_text: I was eight years old when Disney's “The Hunchback of Notre Dame” came out and I know this might seem cliche given that I am visually impaired and Quasimodo is disfigured and there's the whole disfigured guy/blind girl romantic parent trope and fiction, to the point where the author of “Hunchback of Notre Dame” himself, Victor Hugo, wrote another novel including it. It’s called “The Man Who Laughs”.  Look it up if you haven't yet. It’s fantastic. But “The Hunchback of Notre Dame”. Disney's “The Hunchback of Notre Dame”. Not only did that film make me give my little eight-year-old heart to Quasimodo because he was the first character with disabilities that I came across who wasn't like a magical creature, like a troll or a dwarf or something, but he was one of my first, most intense Disney childhood crushes. Oh, my gods, I love that man. He can sing, he is a skilled craftsman, he is an absolute sweetheart. If need be, he can whisk you away to the cathedral to save you. He is a deep, spiritual person who learns over the course of his story that those of us with disabilities and other marginalized outcasts, we are the faces of the divine, too. Oh, my goodness, I loved Quasimodo so much! I had a little handheld puppet of him. I collected every little bit of “The Hunchback of Notre Dame” merch I could possibly find. I should have saved it, because it's hard to find nowadays. I was like, “Esmeralda girl, you love Phoebus, you wanna go out and be with him? Great. All the happiness in the world to you. I will gladly take Quasimodo for myself.” He is 100% marriage material, abso-fucking-lutely.

voice_to_text: so what made me write my first book well my first book was actually it started off as a therapy activity for my students I had an idea about writing stories and I'm gonna look this way um my students were going to be putting themselves into the stories after we dissected them and um just it was it was gonna be a lot of fun and I did do it with other stories with other students but this story just would not stay two pages and that was my max uh length that it could be and it just I just kept getting more and more ideas and I couldn't stop and then I finally one day just looked at my husband I'm like I can write a whole book on this and he said go for it and so I did and that was in 2,017 I believe and I wrote the first one and it just kept coming and then the second one and the third one so I actually have all three books uh first one's Glowing Hearts that one's out second one Beaming Hearts is coming out in June um third one I'm not gonna say the name but hopefully that'll come out before the end of the year and it just needs to be edited the last one and um yeah it just just took a life of its own and um published it on my own cause I wanted it out and not collecting dust in my computer didn't realize what I was doing and um just grateful for the book community that I have found on social media and the support from them and my book is about warrior women and I say that we're all warriors at heart and I really believe as in the authors we do need to be warriors um and I am just grateful to be in this warrior in the author army with all of you and I'm so grateful for the readers that have taken a chance on my book too and so excited to see where it's gonna go and um that's how my journey started and I hope this is only the beginning I'm so happy to share it with all of you be safe bye

video_description: #stitch with @texas garden fairy (MJ) #ableism #dyslexia #audiobooks #accessibility #visualimpairment #notfunny #reading #booktok
voice_to_text: Kendrick Lamar is for people who read. Drake is for people who listen audiobooks. Hey girl, could you. Could you explain the joke to me? I mean, I get it. You think people who consume books with their eyes are superior to people who consume them with their ears. I mean, you would be wrong, and that's why the joke's not funny. I mean, I get it, I get it. Maybe I'm a stick in the MUD here, but audiobooks are a totally valid way to consume literature, and they're not inferior to paper books or Kindle books. They are appropriate technology and accessibility for people with all kinds of disabilities, from dyslexia to other learning disabilities to visual impairment. I mean, the diss here is really to audiobooks and audiobook listeners for comparing them to Drake. We can consume literature in a huge diversity of ways. Would you say if someone reads a book with their hands using Braille that that is inferior to reading it with their eyes? No. So why would you say that listening to a book and consuming it that way is inferior to reading it with your eyes? Ableism just isn't funny. And having books read to you versus reading them yourself are both valid ways to enjoy literature.

voice_to_text: two things come to mind the first one I was five or six years old and my sister was dog sitting for someone house sitting and dog sitting and she took me over to these people's house now this is partly on her because I was five and she had been told the dog wasn't a big fan of kids it was big chow chow no I mean we ended up having a chow chow later in my life no hate to chow chows but they look like big fluffy teddy bears right so my sister left me alone in a room with this big dog and I went to hug the big fluffy teddy bear and it bit me in the face it really didn't like it nipped me it warned me right I just had this little Mark right there that I had to get stitches um but that was on partly on my sister like I said but partly on me because like don't hug the great big bear looking dog with sharp teeth Cara come on the second one I was in seventh grade and during our lunch hour there were always some kind of pick up games that happened in the gym and I think I didn't have a lot of friends yet at that school in seventh grade and I didn't know what to do with myself during lunchtime so I went to play volleyball in the gym I was not a volleyball player by the way I was a soccer player but these were just you know whatever games open to everyone so I went to play and the ball was coming towards me and I was getting ready and I didn't see the boy in front of me backing up he didn't see me because he was backing up and he had instead of like you're supposed to hold your hands like this I think for volleyball he had his hands like this and he came back to try to get it and I'm looking at the ball so I don't see him coming and he hit me in the eye fairly hard but I don't think that was even what did most of the damage I fell backwards slammed my head on the court and ended up with a concussion so that's how you get a concussion playing volleyball for a whopping 10 minutes in seventh grade lunch games I don't know I don't know how I did it

video_description: #stitch with @Cass Paredes | Author/Editor  What comes first in your writing? Characters? Plot? Something else?  #booktok #indieauthor #familiarslegacy
voice_to_text: this is such an excellent question so I had to jump on here and answer it um I know everybody's answer is going to be different but for me it's not necessarily characters or plot that comes first it's a basic concept for the story um and then based on that I come up with characters next and then the plot comes after I tend to be a bit of a Pantser when I'm writing not fully I usually have like a beginning and an end um in my mind when I start to write but the middle is kind of a big mystery to me a lot of times um and it's really just what are my characters doing what would they do um what drives the story and um it really has to do with the original concept that I come up with and then it has to do with the characters that I come up with for that concept for instance in my four book series The Familiars Legacy um I came up with just the basic concept of magical bounty hunters um and from there I was like okay it's an alternate dimension and from there I came up with my main characters um quite a few characters came along the way and surprised me um but my main characters were there from the get go and they really helped to form what was going to happen throughout the rest of the series so very much concept characters plot last and I'm really curious what other authors um have to say about this what would your answer to this question be um feel free to type it out in the comments or do a stitch like I did with the original poster I'm just really curious to hear what other people have to say

And I want to use it as a reference point as to why so many Z!0s feel emboldened to behave the way that they do. So, caste is an ingrained hierarchal classification of peoples, and in the United States that's largely based on (visibly identifiable) race. And according to the Pew Research Center, the majority of J€w!sh people in the United States identify as ◻️. So, this self-identification- they believe - affords them protections of that caste. Now, we know that supremacists of the Casper 👻 variety don't believe that J€ws belong in the same level of caste that they do, but at this time, they are willing to put that aside for the sake of common interest. That common interest is a continued suppression of peoples of lower caste. And in this instance, we know that those people of lower caste are POC. They’re Ar*b. They’re 🍉. They’re 🤲🏼. So, it's almost the “the enemy of my enemy is my friend”.

voice_to_text: So, I tried to find that comment so that I could reply back to it, but it was not available. So, I'm just going to say this. It is of the utmost importance, to decolonize our hearts and minds concerning the world, more specifically, Africa. It is of the utmost importance for us to deconstruct in our hearts and minds the lies that have been taught to us concerning Africa through a Westernized, Eurocentric viewpoint. Now, a great book to read that will help begin that process of decolonization and deconstruction, is a book by Walter Rodney called "How Europe Underdeveloped Africa" this is a great book, that will increase your understanding concerning world history, African history, how things came to be. Reading is fundamental, and understanding history will help us not to make stupid and idiotic comments.

voice_to_text: a slow burn or do you prefer they get right to it if I have to choose between the two of those I will probably go with a slow burn I'm kind of one of those people that likes the middle ground I don't always like it when it's drawn out now if it's a really good buildup where there's a lot of tension and angst and then we get a big payoff at the end I'm good with that um but a lot of times when they jump right in not always but a lot of times when they jump right in um and there's a lot going on right there in the beginning it tends to take up the bulk of the story very quickly um almost too much so for my liking I read a story once where these characters the couple could not be in the same room together without doing it um they got together in the third chapter of the book and they just were going at it like bunnies the whole rest of the book and while I am all for a spicy romance I write spicy romance the fact that they could not be in the same room together alone without things progressing in that direction ever like there was no let's sit on the couch and cuddle or um you know let's just go on a date type of a thing um it was a little much for me so I would have to say slow burn would be my preference between those two

video_description: #stitch with @Danielle 💀 information overload and overstimulation because of it is extremely hard to deal with especially when the life of an author is kind of lonley unless you have a large community to reference. #information #overload #overstimulation #writing #newwriter #newauthor #authorcommunity #indieauthorsoftiktok #booktok #authortok #struggles #informationdump #authorresources
voice_to_text: Information overload as a new author there are so many different resources out there and there's so many different opinions on how to do something there could be five different ways to do it and the first thing that caught me was plotting there are so many different books out there for plotting and so many different recommendations that for my first book I didn't plot at all I just started writing and just continued writing until I had like 90,000 words and then I didn't know what to do with it so I went to developmental editor but this is something that I found really difficult as a writer in deciphering through all of the resources and information and it can be extremely overwhelming and overstimulating but if you have something that you have problems with drop in the comments and let's see if us as authors in this community can help each other out

video_description: #stitch with @Elise’s Good Reads 📚 Review of Appetite for Innocence by Lucinda Berry #lucindaberry #appetiteforinnocence #mysterythriller #bookrecview #bookrecs #booktok #bookish #reading
voice_to_text: if any of you have read Lucinda Berry let me know appetite for innocence really gave me back faith in Lucinda Berry this was so good and if you're a true crime girly you're gonna love this one you have a dual timeline and dual POV so you have Ella who is a kidnapping victim from this guy and she is one of the only ones who escape and then there's Sarah who is the first victim that we know of um of the same guy so the interesting part about this is that you kind of experience what they went through before and after the kidnapping and after they um escaped so it was really interesting I loved seeing the different points of view and there was a twist it kind of wasn't super surprising for me and I don't know if that's just because I watch a lot of horror films but it was really good it really kept me on my toes and I would definitely recommend this one

video_description: #stitch with @gianna 🎀 god I love reading so much but a book is now $32 and so little of that actually goes to the author and the lower levels assistants putting in the work to get it published #booktok #fantasybooktok #publishing #supplychain #logistics
voice_to_text: I work in supply chain management and I have an answer for this that I'm 99% sure is correct no shade to the author because this is actually one of my favourite book series right now I'm pretty sure it looks like that because they want to give the appearance of the book is actually bigger and more pages than what it actually is so that way they can charge you what they wanna charge you think about it if they made it the same height as the other book it would be much thinner with the font size in retail and I guess supply chain management we call the shrinkflation in which brands put less product in their packaging but then try to make it look like it's the same or they make the packaging a little bit smaller each time but the price is still the same they do that so that PCOGS or product cost of good sold is lower and therefore the profit margin is higher supply chain secrets

#stitch with @Listenwithbritt🎧📚 | Booktok #rebeccayarros #apollycon #fourthwing #booktok #romantasy #fantasy #fantasybooktok #scifi #sciencefictionbooks #octaviabutler #octaviabutlerknew #parableofthesower #kindred #lilithsbrood
voice_to_text: so a lot of people are making fun of that choice and yes I get it but the search on that video is Octavia Butler which is telling me that this is maybe a lot of people's first time hearing about Octavia Butler so I would like to do my part and tell people some ideas of where to start with her work if you are unfamiliar with her Octavia butler was a science fiction author and in addition to just writing phenomenal works of fiction she explored a lot of themes of race and power dynamics and just like what it means to be human and exist in our world if I am convinced that anyone is a time traveller or a prophet it is Octavia Butler she knew what was coming for us and she tried to warn us and we didn't listen but we can look back on her work and see what it can tell us about the future if you are a fan of dystopian fiction I think you should read a parable of the sower and its sequel  parable of the talents I mean I think everyone should read this I think you should be required to read it um this one has a forward by Gloria Steinem  if you're looking for them in the wild this cover or ones that look like this maybe a little bit more common parable series was a series of books that was published in the 90s but takes place in the mid 2020s um it takes place on earth after it has experienced like an environmental and political collapse and follows a teenager Lauren as she kinda has to find her own way in the world I don't have words for what this these books mean to me they are phenomenal and so meaningful but also just so fast paced and like you won't be able to put them down the parable series was actually intended to be a trilogy but unfortunately Octavia Butler died before completing the final book Parable of the Trickster if you are a fan of historical fiction or time travel novels I would read Kindred and I cannot find my copy of it right now um this follows Dana who is a black woman who keeps getting transported back in time from the 1970s to the 19th century antebellum slavery south um and every time she gets transported back she stays for a longer period of time A little more removed from our own world I've actually only read the first one right now  but this is about like a race of aliens and their plans for humanity after a nuclear disaster basically destroys earth and while being like alien science fiction it also deals with themes of like power dynamics and just like what it means to be human and it just it'll make you think it'll keep you hooked and it is it's phenomenal that is all the Octavia Butler work that I have read but I know that a lot of her other work I think it's also kind of alien based science fiction so if you're interested in that you should look into her other work and if you are a fan of vampire stories then you should read fledgling plus if you're a fan of short stories or kind of just like dabbling in the science fiction genre I would read Octavia's Brood which is a collection of short stories that were inspired by Octavia Butler's work the tagline is Science Fiction Stories from Social Justice Movements they are all great and one of them is written by LaVar Burton all this to say that Octavia Butler was a visionary and a writer of immense talent and I hope that Rebecca Yarros’s I think very well intentioned gaffe introduces more people to Octavia's work

People, this will literally tap tap tap you until there are two separate but equal halves of you. I can’t fix that, not with all the gauze or duct tape in the world. Unless you want to be an uncomfortable scarecrow the rest of your life, please don’t do this. But I’ll let you try to explain it, that will be interesting. Please..dont meet me like this.
